answer: Certain materials, such as books, music, and magazines, being removed from libraries shouldn't be removed. These materials give people a chance to understand how the real world operates. Having certain materials like books and music definitely should not be removed because most books and music can show most people how bad the statement in the book is or how bad the lyrics are in a song, and help that person to avoid the type of thing that the book or song is saying to the reader or listener. People should give every type of music at least a try and not always doubt what they hear about what people say about that type of music. I always hear about people saying how bad the band @PERSON1 A.M. is, just because in the lyrics it talks about drugs and how much cursing each song has. Really, the band is talking about one man's life and how he turns his life from being a drug addict to having the best life someone could ever live. People always doubted him and never gave his music a chance. Another example would be @PERSON1's book, '@CAPS1 @CAPS2 @CAPS3 @CAPS4'. It talks about drug addicts, homeless people, people who have been born with disfigured arms or even someone who lost their legs, and tells how beautiful each and every one of them really is. His book taught me a few things and made me think differently about people. It doesn't matter how they look or how they talk; no matter what, that person is beautiful. As far as movies and magazines have gone within the last few years, I think that they also shouldn't be taken from libraries. I think so for the same reason of how I feel about the books and music. Of course, we see previews of movies and think that they may not be good, but libraries shouldn't leave them out. Movies are a great way to learn how to treat others and how to act around other people when you don't know how to act. If you act differently around people that you've never been around before, then you could feel embarrassed or maybe even get into trouble. Movies can help people learn about the real world by seeing how to do those type of things as we get older. The same goes for the magazines; they also help people see what not to do or to help them understand the consequences of something that shouldn't be done. Knowing what to do from a magazine could possibly save your life or perhaps maybe even someone else's life. I don't understand why some libraries would want to ban certain materials that help people understand the things that happen in someone else's life and to help them not make the same mistakes as that person once did. In conclusion, libraries should keep these diverse materials to offer a well - rounded view of the world.

Write a persuasive essay to a newspaper reflecting your views on censorship in libraries. Do you believe that certain materials should be removed? I firmly believe they should not. There is no person in charge who should arbitrarily decide to remove books, music, movies, magazines, etc. There is no valid argument for such removal. Why do I think so? Well, if we start removing materials based on someone's idea of what's appropriate, we limit the access to knowledge and different perspectives. For example, if a student needs a particular book for a school project and it's removed because some find it offensive, that student's educational progress is hindered. Also, we all have different views on what is offensive. What one person finds offensive, another may find thought - provoking. We should respect this diversity. I understand that there are concerns about protecting children, but instead of removing materials from libraries, we can have proper guidance and age - appropriate sections. My e - mail address is @EMAIL1, and I hope through this essay, the newspaper can spread the message that libraries should remain a place of free access to all kinds of materials. In conclusion, censorship in libraries is not the solution; rather, education and guidance are the keys to dealing with potentially offensive materials.

Do you think that libraries should remove certain materials off the shelves? People have different opinions of what's good and what's bad. I have read and seen a lot of books in my lifetime. I often hear people telling me, 'oh, don't read that book, it's a bad book.' But I ask myself, 'how do I know it's a bad book when I haven't even given it a chance?' There are indeed some books, music, movies, and magazines out there that are offensive. Yet we still have the curiosity to read, listen, watch, and look at them. If we tried to remove all the offensive books from the libraries, we wouldn't have anything left on the shelves. Katherine Paterson said, 'If I have the right to remove that book from the shelf that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Katherine Paterson makes a great point out of her quote. Why should we have to remove a book if just some people think it's offensive? Ask yourself the question again, 'how do you know it's a bad book when you haven't even given it a chance?' Don't judge a book by what you hear. Find out what your own opinion is. In conclusion, libraries should keep a wide range of materials so that people can form their own opinions through personal exploration.

In @DATE1's world, there are many things found offensive. Everyone has their own opinion on what is offensive and what is not. Many parents are becoming upset because they think their children are viewing things that they should not. Other people are upset because they think the libraries are offending their culture or way of life. This is even taken to the extreme where people want censorship on libraries to avoid this, which is wrong. Some people are becoming concerned about the materials in libraries. They find these things to be offensive. Everyone is entitled to their own opinion, but there really is nothing anyone can do if someone is offended. The world is a public place and everywhere we go, something might be found offensive. The library is a place for study. It is never intended to offend someone or bring bad to the world. It is simply a place to inform, and if someone is offended by what they see, they should stay away from the library. I have been to the library many times, and in none of those visits have I ever seen anything offensive. Everything I have ever witnessed at the library is for learning and research. There are certain sections in the library. If a parent does not want their child seeing something, they should keep their child in the children's section. I can assure you, there is nothing offensive in the children's section, or else the library would not have it in that section. The owners of these libraries know what is going to upset people and what will not. If there was truly offensive materials in the library, those materials would be taken out. Also, if a person complains and the materials are removed, it could lessen someone else's chance of getting the materials they need. One person could think the material is offensive, but someone else might want to learn more about it. If one is offended by a certain material, all they simply must do is not look at it. The library can be compared to a big computer. One can basically find anything there. Asking the library to censor their materials is like asking the internet to censor theirs. It is a way of learning and researching, and it would be almost impossible to censor everything there. Everyone is going to be offended at some point in their life. If the libraries removed everything that could offend someone, they would have no materials left. People need to stop being so easily offended and realize the library is not trying to harm anyone. There does not need to be any censorship in libraries. It is simply trying to teach people about the world and let them enjoy books, music, movies, or whatever else one might go to the library to find. In conclusion, libraries should maintain their role as a free - access source of knowledge without the burden of excessive censorship.

In life, you have the 'offensive things'. The little stuff that gets under our skin and eats away at us. No, it is not easy to get over, but these things will make you stronger. Sometimes there are books, magazines, music, and movies that offend us. The only reason why we get offended is because the subject either reflects our personality or our life. It's not the authors' fault; they write what they feel and what is the truth. Okay, so libraries are full of books, movies, music, etc. You can't just take books off the shelves just because they offend you. Other people may like the book you hate. There are more books in the library you can read. Another reason people shouldn't remove offensive material out of the library is that it will hurt whoever's company got the book published and also the writers. Writers and publishers would lose so much money because the library sells their books, magazines, movies. They make thousands of copies of their product, which takes money. So, to make their money back, they sell to thousands of bookstores. Most of the offensive material will open the world's eyes. Everybody needs to see what's going on in the world. Books, newspapers tell the truth about a subject. Now, the writers' intent isn't to hurt you but to help you. Why can't the world be more open? I know in my own life, I have read books that at first, the book offended me. I would get so mad, I would put the book down and walk away. But then, my eyes would open and finally it hit me. The offensive part out of the book helped me gain a new understanding. The views I used to have would be gone. It is strange how you finally open up, and your life changes. Some people might even find this paper offensive. But if nobody is stepping on your toes and getting under your skin, you won't ever change. 'Offended' is a word used lightly; yes, people use it a lot but do they really mean it. Some people need to say 'well, this book bugs me'. Stop being so self - centered and get over it. Life is too short to worry and feel offended. Every single book, magazine, movie, and music needs to be left alone. Those materials may reflect other people's life and help others with theirs. Just read another book or watch a different movie. Please do not remove anything from the shelves because it will only do more damage. In conclusion, libraries should preserve all materials to allow for personal growth and a broader understanding of the world.

How would you feel if your favorite book was taken off the shelves of your school or public library? I, along with many other students, would find this discouraging and disastrous, so I do not believe that censorship should affect books that are on the shelves. Otherwise, a demolished love of reading, crushed individuality, and a separated population would be born.  Like the beloved Harry Potter series by J.K. Rowling, many books and series are being taken out of libraries' collections due to people in society finding them offensive. In this case, the world of witchcraft in which this story blooms is against some religious beliefs; therefore, some individuals within a religion campaign to have these books banned. Fortunately, none of the libraries I visit, with their eclectic collections, had banned this series, or I would not have the strong thirst for literature as I do now. All books have the potential to pull a student into the wonderful world of reading, like Harry Potter did for me, so taking away books that are most likely to spark an interest or start a firework of creativity would not only affect this generation, but the futures of all.  If this censorship was to be allowed, who is to say what all could be censored? Who would be the final judge as to what books should be banned? It would all come down to power and who was willing enough to take it. This struggle to be on top has the possibility of separating people apart like political parties. Disagreements could turn into debates, and those could turn into fights. It can be concluded that people are stubborn for their beliefs, and to have someone choose what everyone is allowed to believe would be wrong. For instance, it would be like a conservative forcing a liberal to not believe in certain social reforms; a vegetarian commanding that meat can no longer be eaten; a woman taking away men's voting rights. Censorship would lead to the disrespect of other's opinions, and disrespect is never a beneficial thing.  Each and every person has a different opinion on what is offensive or not, so to censor books would be to censor all individual mentality. Without each person's unique thoughts and beliefs, the world would become similarly vapid and dull. Differences in beliefs is what adds variety to the population and what makes a person special; additionally, free thought is a right all people should have. If someone was to limit the mental, literary stimulants that are out in the world, the amount of creativity and individuality would decrease.  To conclude, censorship would be a disrespect to individuality, personal beliefs, and the overall joy of reading a good book. Just because one might not believe in what a story says, it does not mean that the piece of literature should be forbidden. No one is being forced to read the books that grace the hundreds of shelves in a library, so if someone is offended, simply do not read it. So how would you feel if your favorite book was gone from all libraries? Disrespected? That is how I would feel.

The idea of the removal of 'offensive' material from libraries is understandable. Some believe that this material is not appropriate for anyone to view. However, because we all have different opinions on what is offensive, I believe that books found to be offensive should not be removed from the shelves of the library.  First, I believe that if this policy were to be in effect in libraries, there would not be many books left on the shelf. Offensive is a relative word. What might be offensive to one person might not be to another. Everyone has a different opinion on different matters based on their beliefs and life experiences. Many books have things people disagree with, but expressing this is a part of freedom of speech. Therefore, if everyone complained that they found a certain book or movie to be offensive, there would hardly be anything left, as Katherine Paterson said.  The purpose of a library is to provide the people who go to the library a resource. If the sources were censored in such a way, it would be hard to get information. Sometimes, it is beneficial, even, to read an opposing view or side to have more knowledge on a certain topic and see things from a different perspective.  However, some books might not be entirely appropriate to certain people. For example, some material in the library might not be best for small children to read or view. In this case, I do not necessarily feel that they should be removed from the shelves rather than placed in an area these children do not have access to.  Having books, music, movies, or magazines removed from the shelves if they are found to be offensive is in my opinion, a ridiculous notion. It hinders expression. People have different opinions about what is offensive to them and it would be very boring if everyone thought the same. If someone finds something particularly offensive, I believe they just should not view it. In conclusion, libraries should maintain a diverse collection to uphold the principles of free access to information and individual thought.

All authors write for a purpose, whether it be to teach, entertain, or persuade an audience. No author writes something and says, 'I hope no one picks this off of the shelf!' So, if every author wants to express something through their writing, then why should we not let them be heard. We all have the freedom of speech, right? So, why not the freedom of writing? Libraries should not remove a book, music, movie, or magazine from the shelf just because they found it offensive.  Everyone will read a book that they don't like, it's natural, but that doesn't mean that no one will like it. Authors write for an audience, but maybe you are not in that audience; so, it doesn't appeal to you and might even seem offensive. Not everyone believes in the same ideas. You could think about an issue one way and your neighbor think about it a totally different way. Like for instance, you're reading a book about a young girl that is going through many problems in her life. She has gotten into some really horrible situations. Some of these situations you read about are so awful that you wouldn't want anyone else to read it. But, did you ever think that maybe there's another girl that is or has gone through some of these same situations. Maybe this girl comes to a library and finds this book; suddenly she finds guidance in it. She finds something she can depend on in her life that she's never had before. She feels like she has a friend in this book that can handle the situations with her. So, would you really want to take that book off of the shelf and not let that girl ever find her guidance?  Situations happen like this all of the time. People find something special in what they read that other people might not find. When a librarian takes a book off of that shelf, an opportunity is forever gone. No one will ever be able to learn of what was to become of that writing and of those ideas. We all have a right to learn, to explore new ideas, and to expand our minds. No one should have the right to take that away. In conclusion, libraries should preserve the diverse range of written materials to ensure that everyone has the chance to discover something meaningful.

Personally, I don't think libraries, movie stores, etc., should sell any of the items mentioned if they are found offensive to the public. I believe it offends a large number of people. When talking about censorship in libraries, I don't think the library staff should decide what goes on the shelves. The people of the community should have a say because they are the ones who use the library.  I believe that everyone is entitled to their own opinion, but I think certain materials should be removed. For example, some music can be offensive. A lot of students in school have likely come across a book or magazine with profanity that offended them. Some individuals find such things amusing, but for others, it truly bothers them. Not only racial slurs but also profanity can disappoint people. Many parents don't want their children hearing or uttering such words. I firmly believe that if something is offensive, it should be removed from library shelves, and you should share this view too. Regarding movies and music, if they really offend someone, the creators should either change the lyrics or get rid of the work. A good song or great movie shouldn't rely on offending others. One can't create something that mocks another race or depicts the killing of a particular group. When it comes to school libraries, the appropriateness of books depends on the age - group. There shouldn't be any offensive or profane content in elementary or middle - school libraries. Young students aren't old enough or mature enough to encounter such material in books or magazines. So, if a student brings home a class - reading book and the parent dislikes the content, they should have the right to object. And if the content is truly bad, it should be removed from the school. Even high - school students, who are more mature, can be offended by the books they read in school. For instance, 'To Kill a Mockingbird' is a well - known and good book that many students read. However, a lot of African - American students might be offended by the racial slurs used in it. They feel uncomfortable when fellow students and teachers say those words. Schools and libraries shouldn't force students to read books they're uncomfortable with, nor should libraries stock such books. Take me as an example. Next year, I'll have to read that book, and I'm not looking forward to it. I'm half African - American, and I don't like hearing such offensive language. It'll be an awkward experience for me. I also have friends who felt uncomfortable reading that book. There are even children's books that parents want removed from school libraries. The most challenged book in school libraries is 'Harry Potter'. My librarian told me this. It's a good book, but some parents don't want their kids reading about witchcraft and wizards, so they try to get the books out of the library. And they should be able to do so if they don't want their children exposed to such content. In conclusion, if a certain number of people complain about a movie, song, book, or magazine, there shouldn't be a debate. It should be removed. In a school, if students or parents complain in sufficient numbers, the librarian or school shouldn't oppose. Offensive materials should be taken care of by getting rid of them. Parents don't want their kids exposed to inappropriate content, and some people are offended or uncomfortable with certain books or movies. Entertainment should be removed from the world if it offends people.

Do you think that certain books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed from shelves because someone finds them offensive? This includes magazines, books, movies, and even music. I firmly believe it's not right that the opinions of a few people, based on what they find offensive, should matter. There are two main reasons for this. Firstly, people pick these items out themselves, and secondly, when they go to the library, they're looking for something they'll enjoy. The first reason I think certain books, music, movies, and magazines shouldn't be removed from the shelves is that people choose them on their own. No one is likely to pick up a book, magazine, watch a movie, or listen to music that appears, seems, or sounds offensive. Most people don't take being offended lightly. For example, why would someone buy an item that doesn't appeal to them? It just doesn't make sense. The second reason is that when you go to the library, you're on the hunt for an interesting book, a particular type of music, a movie, or a magazine. You'll probably end up with something that catches your eye and suits your taste. So, if a book, music, movie, or magazine looks offensive, simply don't get it. Usually, if something is going to offend you, it'll be quite obvious from its appearance, the way it seems, or even the sound it makes. In my opinion, if certain books, music, movies, and magazines are offensive to some people, they shouldn't be taken off the shelf. Dear Newspaper, how would you feel if someone wrote a book about how bad the newspapers are, and then tore you down so badly that no one wanted to touch another newspaper? Think about it. I firmly believe that certain materials such as books, music, movies, etc., that are found offensive should not be allowed to be removed from a library's bookshelves, let alone even be on the shelves. Now, let's take a moment to think about this. What if a sexist book fell into the hands of an innocent child who could just read enough to get through the book? That child could end up adopting the kind of life that the book portrays. If I were a parent, I know for sure that I would never want my children exposed to harmful reading materials until they can distinguish right from wrong and have a clear judgment on such matters. From another perspective, what if that one book, which claims that black people are bad and nasty, fell into the wrong hands? For this purpose, let's say a drunken, old - fashioned man who happens to think we should continue slavery. That one book could stimulate this white man's thoughts, and he could try to put his thoughts into action. He might throw what the book says about black people in a young black woman's face. Then, after seeing the impact it has on her, he could rape and beat her. Only to let her live and make her his own slave for as long as she's alive. Can you imagine this world when only she knows how badly she's hurting? She's the only one who knows how long she will have to deal with the pain before she stops fighting for her life. Just think, all that I've told you about, and the examples I've given, all started with that one single offensive book. These are all valid reasons for those books to be banned from libraries or at least be firmly fixed to the shelves. In conclusion, offensive materials can have far - reaching and dangerous consequences, and we must take steps to protect the public, especially the vulnerable, from their influence.

I've recently read a letter from Katherine Paterson about censorship in libraries. This is my opinion expressed in words about how I feel about the whole topic. I'd like to think that it's because I have a horrible memory, but the truth is, they were just unappealing and unmemorable books. In all aspects, these books could be considered a waste of my time. Back then, I guess I only read them because I had nothing better to do, which is a shame because you should read books because you want to. I stopped reading books at around seventh grade because every book I picked up seemed to be extremely boring, and it would take the first one hundred pages to actually have something decent happen. Luckily, there is light at the end of this tunnel. Every now and then, you come across a book that changes your life. Not literally, but it feels that way at the time (which is what you should feel when reading a great book). These are the books I remember. These 'life - changing' books all have things in them that would interest anyone who picks them up. Unfortunately, these things would be viewed as inappropriate to a select audience. For example, one book might talk about murder and be viewed as highly offensive by a person whose mother had been murdered, whereas the same book could be viewed as a piece of art by someone who has escaped the terribleness of death. Apparently, it has gotten to the point where people would have the books censored or have them removed from the libraries completely. I can stand idle no longer. Books all go through a long, drawn - out process before they are shelf - ready. They need to be written, read, and selected to be published. For some books, this can take years. To completely alienate these books is extremely unfair to the time and effort that was put into them. If you don't like the books, don't read them. It's as simple as that. If that's not enough reason for you, think of it this way: a book about a child getting raped and fighting to overcome it could serve as inspiration for rape victims. Or, a book about someone's parents dying could help a child in the same situation overcome the grief. All books serve a purpose and should remain firmly on the shelves of local book stores, regardless of the methods used in them. Even if they don't appeal to you, it could be a completely different experience for someone else halfway across the world. Let these books serve their purpose. In conclusion, we should respect the diversity of books and not let a few people's sensitivities limit the access to valuable literature.

Do I believe that some books, movies, magazines, or etc., should be removed due to the fact some people might find them offensive? NO, I firmly believe that everyone should have the chance to see them, rather than just the people who did and thought they were offensive. Someone could really like a particular item, or a whole group of people could. Even if some people find an object offensive, someone else might need that object for something like school work.   Let's say the libraries remove a human trafficking book from the libraries because people find it offensive. Then a local school has a project on human trafficking. The students go to the libraries to get some books on it. Now, due to somebody else's dislike of the books, these kids don't get to use those books to do their research. It simply wouldn't be fair to everyone to remove objects from the libraries just because some other people find them offensive. The library is a public place that everyone has the right to go to and borrow stuff from. So, no, I don't believe that libraries should remove books, movies, magazines, or etc., due to the fact that some other people find them offensive. It's important to preserve the freedom of access to a wide range of materials for all patrons.

Twilight, Harry Potter, or even The Vampire Diaries series are books that many guardians do not allow their children to read due to their beliefs on what is real and what is not. Magic, spells, and vampires  many of us know are not real, but others do not believe in what it is that is being taught to the younger readers. My personal view on censorship would be a very low tolerable standard due to different people having diverse interests, more variety in the available materials, and different reading or viewing materials being accessible. But there would be certain circumstances where I would have to put my foot down and censor things such as sex and drugs, just because that is not suitable for young children to be reading at that young of age.  The reason why I would have a low tolerance of the censorship is because different people like different things. If someone was an athlete, they might not find a book about cooking and cleaning very appealing. As if a person that was a cook might not find a book about athletics too appealing either. Just because one person has different beliefs or what their standard is for offensive would not change my stand - point on the censorship of certain articles. Different beliefs of certain people are understandable, but just because you don't believe it doesn't mean that everyone else is going to right there not believing it with you. Don't ruin it for the others who enjoy the interesting fact of a male vampire falling in love with a normal human girl just like you and me.  Another reason why my stance on censorship in libraries is lenient is because it would give my library more variety. If there were twenty different Harry Potter books on the shelves, many people would be able to look at them and check them out as they please. Also, if you didn't know what kind of book you wanted to check out, you could look around and get a mystery, drama, comical, or even a horror book. Having a wide range to select from would keep the guests always coming back for more. I know that when my library had a series of books that I found interesting, I was back in there after I finished each one.  Also, having different reading or viewing materials on hand is important in a library due to the fact that some books these days are now turned into films, which makes people more eager to finish that book in less than a week so that on the weekend they can watch the movie. Most people say that the movies are never better than the original book itself, but an opinion is easier to be based off of reading the book and then watching the movie, not just by stopping after reading the book.  In conclusion, my low - tolerance approach to censorship in libraries is based on the need to accommodate different people's interests, provide a wide variety of materials, and support the connection between reading and viewing. We should respect the diverse preferences of library users and not impose overly strict censorship standards.

I strongly disagree. I think that materials should not be removed from the library. After all, all the materials are part of the library and are meant for the school and for us too. All the materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, and CDs, should not be removed from the library. I have my own reasons why materials should not be removed from the shelf. Sometimes, when I don't find any interesting things to do, I go to my tiny library at home and pick any book that I like. But when I don't like or don't find any interesting book at home, I go to the library to find some interesting books.  However, when the libraries or the school have offensive books, magazines, movies, etc., it's a problem. That offensive stuff should be removed from the library because it's not good for the children. For example, when they want to read a book, like a cartoon or animal book, and they don't find what they want, they are going to get mad. And what about the parents? If they need to find some information about a book or they just want to read and they find offensive stuff, some parents are going to get mad. Not all parents, right, but some will, and they maybe won't come back again.  I've never experienced something like this in my life because in my school and the library that I go to, they don't have anything offensive or inappropriate. That's why I respect the people who work at the library and at the school because they respect us too. That's why I never go to places that I don't know. Suppose I go to a library that I don't know and I bring my parent and my little brother. If this library has offensive materials, my parents are going to get mad at me. They are going to say that I don't have respect and that I brought my brother to an inappropriate place. They are going to be mad at me for bringing my family to an offensive place, and it's not my fault, right?  In conclusion, while I believe in the importance of having a wide range of materials in the library, offensive materials should be removed to ensure a positive experience for both children and parents.

No, I do not think that books, magazines, movies, and music should be removed. However, I do think that the books, magazines, movies, and music should be monitored by age. The reason why is because younger children should not be reading, listening, or watching material that is intended for adults or teenagers.  The way these types of things can be monitored is by using the child's library card. The card could have their name, age, grade, and date of birth clearly printed on it. If there is a certain book, magazine, movie, or music that the child wants, a parent has to be there with them. The parent needs to show a form of identification so that the librarian knows that the parent is of age and can make an appropriate decision about the child's access to the material.  Teenagers should also be monitored. Even though they are almost adults, some parents may not agree with some of the material. So, if their parents do not want them reading certain things, there should be stickers on their cards indicating restricted access.  In conclusion, rather than removing materials, age - based monitoring is a more reasonable approach. It allows for a balance between providing access to a wide range of materials and protecting younger users from inappropriate content. This way, we can ensure that everyone can enjoy the library's resources in a safe and appropriate manner.

Picture yourself walking through the library with your child. Now, think of how hard you worked to teach your child respect and manners. Imagine all of those values going down the drain by them reading one bad magazine or listening to one explicit song.  I wholeheartedly agree with the censorship in libraries today. Most people wonder where their children learn curse words or sexual behavior and do not consider media as the problem. Libraries have continued to keep children's areas clean of explicit materials and are careful so that magazines such as 'Playboy' do not reach their shelves.  Explicit material should be removed if it is found offensive. I have seen offensive material get into the wrong hands, such as kids. That childish innocence disappears when they hear songs about money, sex, and abuse. Some books could give them the wrong idea and encourage them to make unlawful decisions. One example is a teen pregnancy book. The ideas in the book are either to keep the baby and deal with the consequences or abort the baby and move on with life. Some media says to abort the baby just because it is easier. Would you want your child to have the idea in their head that they should react first before they think?  In conclusion, censorship should be kept in libraries. It helps everyone altogether not to worry about what wrong things their kids are doing, or how they snatched the wrong idea. By maintaining censorship, we can create a more respectful and appropriate environment in libraries. Please help us promote censorship in libraries to make a more respectful environment for all library users, especially the younger ones who are still developing their values and beliefs.

I feel as though we are allowing kids these days to act as they please and do whatever they desire. We are inadvertently making them think that we don't care about what they are involved in, but that's far from the truth. We need to establish clear boundaries for what kids should and shouldn't be able to do. We need to show them that we are aware of what they're doing.  I think that there should be an age policy for libraries. If there are any books that contain any types of adult content, they should be placed in the adult section. If you ever wish to check out books, movies, or magazines from that section, you would have to be eighteen or older. If that's too much to ask for, then you should at least have the parents sign a consent form.  Books, movies, and magazines with any type of adult content can be hazardous to children, whether it affects their actions or behaviors. It can impact their lives depending on what age they were introduced to such things. We need to show them that we care.  I know from personal experiences that being exposed to this kind of content can drastically change people, not over time but quickly. Nowadays, the media is portraying that money, alcohol, fame, and drugs are good things. This is what we are including in our movies, books, and magazines, and it's being instilled in the minds of children. We are giving them the impression that it's okay, but it most certainly isn't.  These are all the reasons why we should implement censorships and restrictions on libraries. We are allowing the children of today to grow up too fast and introducing them to things way too early. In a way, we are brainwashing them on how to live a destructive life through adult - oriented things. By taking these necessary steps, we can better protect our children and guide them towards a healthier and more positive future.

The media is destroying our youth! This is a statement we hear on a daily basis. Teachers are constantly telling us this, while parents and grandparents are sharing how much different their world used to be. They explain how the media of their time wasn't as explicit about sex and violence. They go on to mention how they didn't have violent video games teaching children that killing is acceptable. Because of these accounts, we tend to think that the media is responsible for the wrongdoings in the world today.  The truth is that it isn't the media's fault; it is the parents. It is the parents' responsibility to teach the children of the world the difference between right and wrong. If these parents do their jobs correctly, then the youth today will not need for everything to be censored. It is my firm belief that there should not be any censorships. When there is censorship, people can govern what we learn, destroy what goes against their beliefs, and violate our God - given right to freedom of speech.  Censorship will destroy the knowledge available today. We have witnessed censorship in our history. When we look back, we see that the Nazis' censored and destroyed anything that went against them. We despised it when they had book burnings and destroyed the customs, art, and music that the government felt was wrong for their people. How would we be any different if we did it? We could potentially be destroying someone's way of life. We would be destroying what could possibly be tomorrow's masterpiece. In censoring, we would be destroying history. By destroying history, we would be destroying the brilliance that is learning.  If we allow censorship, anything that goes against our own personal beliefs would be destroyed. If you ask any Christian if they would allow their children to read the Muslim book of faith, the Quran, they would tell you no. It would be the same if you asked a Muslim if they would let their children read the Bible. The point is that if there is censorship, we would be destroying other people's beliefs. No one has the right to govern what others believe in the world.  Also, in censorship, we would be exterminating our freedom of speech and the freedom to express ourselves. If we don't allow people to read what someone else has written because we believe it is wrong, then we are taking away their ability to learn new ideas because everyone has different opinions and theories. Every newspaper would shut down because they would all be saying the same thing. No one would want to read them because they would already know what they would have to say. When we start giving up rights such as freedom of speech, we will not be able to stop those people who took those rights from taking more.  Of course, there will always be things in the media, in books, and in music that we don't like. There will be cursing, nudity, and violence everywhere we turn. This is not because we want it there, but because these things are a part of life. They are the dark parts that we don't want to see. If you don't want to see, don't look. Just don't close everyone else's eyes because you don't like what you see. We must safeguard our learning, our beliefs, and our freedom of speech, as they are the cornerstones of a free and progressive society.

Censorship in libraries should not be a major concern. There are materials in libraries that some people find offensive. To address this problem, not everything should be censored. Why can't those who find it offensive simply avoid it? I believe it should be an individual's choice whether to read something or not. If they find it offensive, they should simply put it down.  The book 'To Kill a Mockingbird' has offended many people. I have read it and was not offended. I found it to be very interesting and educational. Many people think the book should be censored. But if it is censored, the story would be completely altered, and it would lose its essence. I would have learned nothing instead of learning how people lived in America's history.  If all the books and magazines that were offensive to one person were removed from the shelves, and all the books offensive to another were taken away, what would be left? Maybe just little kids' books about kittens? Well, that's hardly sufficient.  I am strongly against censorship. I believe that if a material is offensive to you, then you shouldn't read it or listen to it. But don't ruin it for the rest of us. By respecting each other's choices and the diversity of literature, we can maintain a rich and inclusive library environment.

The library is a place of learning, discovery, and knowledge, accessible to anyone willing to spend time exploring the rows and rows of information. It includes children's books, novels for young adults, encyclopedias, biographies, music, and movies, offering us a vast array of opportunities to discover something new. However, there are other things that can be found in the library as well. Books containing racial slurs, sexual content, and offensive religious comments can be accidentally encountered while searching for something else. A parent should not have to worry about their child coming across a book or magazine with inappropriate content like this. I believe that offensive books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed from the shelves of our libraries.  I would like to begin by stating that I have a serious issue with books that include comments, remarks, or names referring to people of a certain race. Imagine if an African American woman brought her daughter of 10 years into the library to find information about a school project. Instead of finding the birth date of Martin Luther King Jr., she found a book making fun of African Americans and calling them inappropriate names. Children should not have to make such a discovery in a public facility, where fun and interesting facts should be found, not racial slurs. This type of event could cause serious emotional and mental damage to a child. That is why these types of things should be taken off the shelves immediately!  Another issue I have is with sexual content in libraries. I do understand that several books contain some sort of sexual content, but I am referring to a novel describing a sex scene in extreme detail, or images of almost - naked women on the cover. If someone is searching for a book of that kind, they can go to a sex store nearby and satisfy their need for sexual reading. That type of book, however, should not be in the library. It makes our society look bad and taints our places of knowledge.  Lastly, I would like to express my feelings about offensive religious comments in libraries. Every person in the United States is entitled to their own choice of religion. They can practice it freely, which is unfortunately not the case for others in different countries. If we have the uncommon right of freedom of religion, then why would we put books in our libraries that include rude comments towards different religions? A Jewish woman should not have to go to a library and come across a book stating her religion is a waste and stupid. This is not the truth, and it should not be in our libraries!  Even though I feel this way about inappropriate books, I understand that there has to be some sort of limit when it comes to censorship. Many people fear that once we start removing certain books from libraries, more and more books will be taken from the public until almost all our libraries are empty. Yes, if we do not censor within certain limits, this could happen. This is not what I want to happen. I simply want the people of this community to consider what is easily accessible to our children. The least we can do, as parents, is to remove books, movies, magazines, and music containing racial slurs, sexual content, and offensive religious comments from the libraries. By doing so, we can create a safer and more positive learning environment for everyone.

Two of the many privileges that we have as Americans are freedom of speech and freedom of expression. Although some bodies of work may be perceived as offensive or inappropriate, I believe that they should still be available to the public. Some might agree with the topic being expressed, even if it is offensive or inappropriate, and others may not; but they should not be removed from libraries because of their negativity.  These offensive or harsh pieces of literature could even be used to show the public what is considered rude, offensive, or inappropriate, and should be thought of as learning tools instead of being banned. Every person has a right to an opinion, and others may or may not agree with what that person has to say, but it does not change the fact that they have the right to their beliefs.  Katherine Paterson says, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf'. I myself have read literature that is considered offensive, but as disturbing as the literature was, I am glad that I was educated on what people thought was acceptable behavior so that I know, and can teach others that despite what the book said, we now know that it was describing how people should not be living.  I believe that it would be a grave mistake to remove these materials from the public eye, because many are ignorant of the historical beliefs of others that have affected our nation and other countries across the globe. All of these books are educational, though some are harsh, and they should be used to show what is right and wrong. If they are taken off of shelves in the libraries, then people, especially children, could start to think that a certain idea, that may be incorrect or offensive, is completely appropriate and acceptable. As someone once said, 'Those who do not know their history are bound to repeat it'.  By removing the problem, we would be creating another issue. For example, many books have been written over history that convey hatred and discrimination towards other cultures, ethnicities, religions, and lifestyles. If these works of literature were banned and not available to the public, many people would not know that it is wrong to show hatred towards others just because they are different. This type of literature provides useful information: it allows people to see how a large number of people thought life should have been years ago, and it teaches the people of today that it actually was how people should not be living. By keeping these materials accessible, we can ensure that future generations are well - informed and less likely to repeat the mistakes of the past.

Libraries are well - known as places where a person can go to find material on almost any topic they could want to learn about. Whether that material is a well - bound book, an engaging movie, or an interesting magazine, libraries offer a vast array of resources. Anyone can use the library, and it is a truly valuable resource to many people. So why do some libraries insist on removing some of those valuable materials from their shelves? In past years, censorship in libraries has been the focus of many news reports. In almost all cases, library patrons have been angry that certain materials have been deemed unsuitable to be offered at the library. I have to say that I wholeheartedly agree with them. People have a right to choose what books they want to read, what movies they want to watch, and what music they want to listen to. People have opinions; people disagree. What one person loves, another person could hate. But just because one person dislikes or is offended by a material on a library shelf does not mean that the opportunity to use that material should be denied to all other patrons. I feel that if a resource is checked out by just one individual, and that one individual is able to learn from or enjoy the resource, then the library has achieved its purpose and helped the community by offering that material. In conclusion, censorship in libraries is limiting and wrong. It creates barriers for those who want to learn and it takes away people's freedom to make decisions for themselves. Everyone should be able to decide whether to pick up a library material, and censorship makes that impossible.

Katherine Paterson stated this quote, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf.' I whole - heartedly agree. I feel that some of the books we have in our local libraries today just shouldn't be there. Offensive books, music, movies, and magazines can give students and young children the wrong impact on life or their environment around them. Nowadays, what children see is sometimes what they do. So if books, music, movies, and magazines give them the idea that what they say or do is cool, then kids will most likely do it. An observation when I look at kids in my community playing is that they follow one another. When they're playing tag and hide - and - seek, it's evident. So movies, books, music, and magazines play a big part in the way they behave. My own experience with offensive books would be that there are books that are made by a certain author. In these books, they use cruel language, use women's body parts as symbols, and many more rude things. My little sister came across one of these books. When she asked me about it, it was hard for me to explain to her that this was no book for a child her age to be reading. So the best way for me to put it was that it was an adult book, to get any images out of her head that I felt she shouldn't have. Another experience I've seen was with my little cousin. He was looking at a magazine out of the library. The magazine was offensive to women. It was a Playboy bunny magazine. Now I don't know if you've ever heard of these magazines, but I think it is very wrong that they use women's bodies for men to view. I also feel that those types of magazines should not be in a library. I believe it gives children, mainly young men, the wrong thoughts about women. My overall thoughts on censorship in libraries are that not everyone is going to feel the same way I do. There are parents that allow their children to read, listen, and watch whatever they want. I'm here to say I don't feel that is the way to go about things, because it can influence your children to do inappropriate things. I hope you take my personal experience with you and help your children read, listen, and watch age - appropriate books, music, movies, and magazines.

Do I think that certain materials such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from libraries? No, because people might need to know a certain information, certain lessons are taught in different sources, and all sources are valuable assets. Now, you just might need certain information, and in those sources there are an unnumbered amount of lessons to learn. For example, if I were to go in a library and need a book on religion, I would need a book or movie to teach me on that particular subject. Or even when it comes to sex - related information, I would need a magazine or movie to watch to know new information. There are different lessons taught in different aspects. For example, some people learn by example, through movies, music, and magazines. If it were to be me looking for a source on music theory, I might need one of those things to get what I need. Finally, those things are assets. Don't get me wrong; we don't need them on a daily basis in an obvious way, but in a sense we sort of do. We use search engines for everything, every day. So what do you think? In conclusion, I believe we need those sources because someone might need certain information, there are different lessons learned and taught in different things, and lastly, all sources are valuable assets.

The right to remove a book off of a shelf is not a good thing to do. My view on the subject is that, if this begins, there will only be empty shelves in libraries across the country. Once the removing of books starts, there will be hardly any left. We use books every day. For students, we use them to learn and for entertainment during some classes. Books help us learn things, like new words we've never heard of before, or some major point in history we should know about. Even as adults, some of them like to read in their free time. I think it's wrong to remove a book off of the shelf just because a few or a bunch of people think it's inappropriate. If it is, the libraries should have a section for those books that doesn't let the little kids go in that section. But there is a problem for this idea: what books should go into this section of the library? A way to solve that question would be to elect a nationwide library service to set it up and have people vote on which books to remove or put into a special section in the libraries across the nation. This idea goes the same for everything found at a library. Another solution to this matter is that the libraries across the nation have another labeling system like the Dewey Decimal System but use both. This new system could contain information like reviews from critics about the book, or what happened during the book. This would inform the reader more on what he is about to be engrossed in for the next week or so. The books, music, magazines found in libraries should be left there for a reason. Somebody wrote or composed them for a reason, so people like you and me can enjoy good stories in books, read informative magazines, and listen to good music.

Libraries should never remove any material just because it might be found offensive. Something that is offensive to one person might not be to another. If the material was so offensive that it went against the law, then it probably wouldn't have been published in the first place. People often get offended if they read, see, or listen to something that goes against their personal views, ethics, or religion. But people need to learn to understand that other people think differently and have different values. Though people's opinions differ, each opinion is equally important to that certain person. So many media sources today are censored that it is essential to keep a place where people can freely obtain material and express opinions. As a student, I often have a hard time finding meaningful literature in the school library because it is so censored. I am not complaining about this because I understand that schools have to be careful of what they are exposing students to. But if I am looking for something maybe more religious, derogatory, or less accepted, it is nice to have a public library where I can find these things. In closing, if people are offended by something on the shelves of a library, then they shouldn't read, watch, or listen to it. But do not censor everything so that people who do enjoy these materials can no longer easily access them. Libraries should remain a haven of free access to diverse materials for all.

I don't believe books should be taken off of the shelves for being offensive. Some books that are found offensive by one person might not offend another. People, regardless of the month (@MONTH1), have the right to say that a book is offensive if that is how they feel, but they do not have the right to deny others the right to read that book. I understand that parents want to protect children. Parents should have in - depth conversations with their children and explain to them in detail why they don't want them reading that specific book. Parents might also just let their children read it and then patiently explain why they don't approve. I feel the same way about the censorship of music and movies. When I was twelve years old, I started to listen to music that I enjoyed instead of the music my mother played. My mother was really concerned about the lyrical content of the songs I would listen to. She firmly refused to buy me the music and would not let me listen to it. I went to my friends' houses and listened to explicit music and watched rated (@CAPS1) movies. She could never really stop me because that explicit language was being said wherever I went. I think instead of trying to deny teenagers the music, the parents should explain the reasons clearly and let them make the decision. I think censorship should be left up to the parents of that child. Sometimes when parents try to pull their kids closer, they actually push them away. That's why I think it's so important for the parent and the child to always talk and be comfortable with each other. In conclusion, open communication between parents and children is the key to handling the issue of offensive media, rather than strict censorship.

Many people go to libraries; such as children, parents, and grandparents. I have come to realize that their purpose for going to this community - loving place is to find peace and quiet. Some don't even go there for the books. They will engage in listening to music, flipping through magazines, enjoy a cup of coffee, or simply get on the internet. Now some people argue that some of the books, music, and movies in libraries are inappropriate or offensive, but does that mean the libraries should have to get rid of them? These materials people find offensive have no reason to be banned. First of all, the libraries will lose customers. There is a large majority of people in the world who really like listening to rap or (@CAPS1&@CAPS2). It's hard to find that kind of music without cuss words or sexual innuendo. Even I will listen to that type of stuff occasionally just so that I can have a cool beat stuck in my head for a while. Plus, when you are in a library and listening to music you will have headphones on, which isn't disruptive to others in or around the library. Secondly, customers who don't like the context of these materials don't have to get them. If there is a book that has a sex scene or talks about drugs then don't read it. You have a choice to what book you would like to read and if that isn't your style then there are plenty of other aisles and children's books you can look through. Those who are interested in those topics still deserve to be able to choose those books. I have been to my public library many times and all the times I have been there I have not once even seen a book, music, or a movie that looks displeasing to the eyes. So if you're a person who wants an offensive book, then it takes a good amount (@CAPS3) of looking, not just a quick little scan. Finally, freedom. Isn't that what (@CAPS4) is all about? The freedom of speech, and religion, and even what type of movies you want to watch. I know this might come as a shocker, but there are labels on the back of movies that tell whether it is (@CAPS5), (@LOCATION1), (@LOCATION1@NUM1), or (@CAPS1). It also includes the not - so - nice content that will be present in the movie. So you have total freedom to purchase (check out) any of those rated movies. Like I explained clearly earlier, you aren't forced to watch any of the naughtier movies, so just pick what you want and be happy. As you can see, there is absolutely no reason to remove offensive books, music, or movies. There are many different types and styles of these categories and it isn't disturbing anyone. Libraries will lose customers, people don't have to choose the less appropriate things, and us (@CAPS7) have freedom to do what we please, especially with what we would like to read, listen to, or watch. So save yourself some time and just keep the few so - called 'offensive' materials in the library.

I did not know what to do; I was completely clueless and I had no book to write my report over. So he asked the librarian 'where are all the books covering Saudi Arabia, Iraq, and Syria?' I'm sure that he found this comment to be very offensive but there was nothing that he could do about it because the white people found Arabs to be offensive and unequal to the white race. These are only a few things that have already happened because of people finding certain books to be offensive, which is why I believe that the government should leave all the books on the shelves and let the people decide to pick up that book or pass it by. Sure, people have a freedom of speech but it should not affect what books belong on the shelf. Which is why I believe that censorship should not be allowed to affect libraries of the public. We should preserve the diversity of knowledge in libraries for the sake of education and personal growth.

Should certain books, movies, magazines, music, etc., be removed from shelves if they are found to be offensive? Books, movies, magazines, and music are forms of expression that are made to relay a message, express a point of view, or perhaps state an opinion. Since everyone has a different point of view, what one person finds offensive may not be offensive to another. No, books, movies, magazines, music, etc., should not be simply taken off of the shelves or out of stores. All of the previously listed things are already rated. Movies are rated from @CAPS1 through @CAPS2, books are rated from child - friendly to adult - oriented, and music, if explicit, has a parental advisory sticker. People just need to follow these ratings. For instance, if a four - year - old tried to buy two tickets to see a rated @CAPS2 movie, the theater would not sell him the tickets because he is not of the appropriate age. People often bring up the point that maybe a child could pick up an adult book or magazine in a store and start reading it. The solution to this problem is simple. Stores that sell these items can create a separate room and label it the adult section. Install cameras nearby so that if a youngster tries to enter the adult section, they will be caught. Another option is to put a desk in front of the adult section and require an ID for entrance. These are still books which are expressions of a person's dreams, hopes, desires, fantasies, and heart. They should not be denied the opportunity to be available just because a person deems the content unfit. And most importantly, if a piece of content offends someone, they should simply choose not to read it. In summary, people should simply follow the rating rules and take necessary precautions. If all of these rules are followed, then businesses and libraries should have no problems keeping everybody safe and happy, while still allowing for the free flow of diverse forms of expression.

If I could remove anything from the shelves of libraries, I wouldn't. After all, libraries are repositories of diverse knowledge and ideas. Would you rather your kids learn things from the objective facts in books or from the often unreliable chatter of friends? Censoring books, magazines, movies, etc., and deciding what goes onto the shelves is a complex matter. Most of the materials on library shelves are there either for enjoyment or to provide information. Granted, you wouldn't want a five - year - old reading a book made for adults, but as kids grow older, they have to learn various things. You can't always control what children read unless you plan on going with them everywhere, including college and into their adult life.   Books provide facts and more reliable information than what you can hear from people. For instance, if all the books on the shelves relating to drugs or alcohol were pulled off, how would someone write a comprehensive report on those things? The books were created to provide people, kids especially, with facts that no one else could share, and it could also help with expanding their vocabulary and knowledge. If someone were to find a book offensive, they don't have to look at it or even pick it up. Libraries can't always suit everyone's tastes, and something you find offensive isn't offensive to others. Taking a single book from the shelves would result in others taking books off the shelves, and then no books would be left for anyone to read or wish to take off the shelves.   If you controlled what everyone read, no one would be happy, and their brains wouldn't function correctly. You'd be taking one of their rights, one of the only things entitled to them without someone else telling them they can't. What kids read is shaping their minds for their future. If you removed their favorite series or genre from the shelves, they wouldn't read or listen to music or do anything enjoyable anymore. Kids get into reading when they can enjoy what they read or listen to.   So with that, I wouldn't take anything off the shelves because everything appeals to someone in one way or another. Controlling what one person reads doesn't lead you nor the other person anywhere. Someone could end up being offended if you take something you find offensive off the shelves, and you can't stop the knowledge that books can provide people if they read them. In one way or another, something provides information for people, and libraries should be a place where this free flow of information is maintained.

Censorship. It's a word that everyone has heard, but do people truly know what it means or how it affects them? In the past, books have been censored by rulers and leaders who thought that the material was harmful. How could they say that they knew what was best for their people? What gave them the right to decide what their people could or could not read? In today's society, we still have to deal with censorship issues. Books, magazines, movies, music, etc. should not be removed from the shelves just because certain people find them offensive. Everyone has different tastes, not only in food, but in every other part of their lives as well. No one person has the right to say that one genre is better than another. Some people like mysteries, while others like to read romantic books. If we allow people to censor what we read, then how can we say that there is a book for everyone to like? Censorship, or the removing of material deemed inappropriate or offensive, has been used as a means of controlling people's thoughts and feelings for many centuries. The British used it in the American colonies during the American Revolution to keep the colonists loyal to the crown, aiming to suppress any anti - monarchy ideas. The Nazis used censorship not just during the Second World War as a brand of propaganda, but also during the pre - war years under Hitler's guidance, shaping public opinion to fit their ideology. Censorship is still in use in the United States today, as a way to 'protect the children'. The Federal Communications Commission tells the American public what we can and cannot watch on television and what we can and cannot listen to on the radio. Other organizations tell us what books we can and cannot read, what video games we can and cannot play, and what items we can and cannot buy. Such organizations, I believe, are pushing the United States and other freedom - loving nations to the edge of totalitarianism.  As Katherine Paterson stated, 'If I have the right to remove that book from the shelf--that work I abhor--then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else.' If one person has the right to control what we buy, what we listen to, and what we see, then how come we don't have that right to control the same things for them? Where do we draw the line? Eventually, all books, movies, magazines, music, and video games would be deemed offensive and inappropriate. Culture would slowly wither and die, and our lives would become drab and essentially useless, for lack of a better term.  I recently read a book titled 'The River Between', by Ngg wa Thiong'o, about two periods in a boy's life: his childhood with his family in tribal Kenya, and the life he had after his mother's death in the colonial capital of Nairobi. Ngg wa Thiong'o's work includes some passages that are less than angelic, and, had strict censorship been in place, these passages would have caused the book to go unpublished. Ngg wa Thiong'o's work gave not only myself but a multitude of others insight into the life that Kenyans face in the changing landscape of their country, and it certainly made me realize once again that I have a life rich in family, friends, and comfort.  All in all, censorship is a horrid disease that slowly infects and consumes every part of our lives. If you get to censor something you find offensive, then why don't I do the same thing? Some censorship is good, and a fact of life. But we have to ask ourselves, where do we draw the line? Where's the boundary between safety and and outright police state? Censorship is just a fancy term for blatant disregard of the First Amendment, as freedom of speech is guaranteed for all American citizens. As a famous colonial revolutionary once said, 'Give me liberty, or give me death!' If censorship continues to grow and our libraries grow emptier and emptier, then I shall take death over liberty, for liberty with censorship is no liberty at all.

If we don't remove anything from the library, we would have a lot of people coming. On the other hand, if we removed a certain type of books, people would get mad and not come to the library. The books, movies, music, etc. need to be in a certain section of the library to where the little kids can not go or reach. A library is a family place not a fun zone for adults.  On a stormy day, I went to the library with my brother to pick out a book for him. He is only six about to be seven. He had told me he wanted to get a book about dinosaurs, but I told him to get one on space and aliens. He was very into reading. He read to our mom every night before he would go to bed. We were walking down the street when a bolt of lightning struck through the trees. 'Ekkkk!' said my brother as he ran around me. We walk into the library and the old lady at the front desk says, 'there is a huge storm coming.' We sorta ignore her and go on about our business picking our books for my brother. My brother and I walk up stairs to the children's section. My brother is looking around and he says 'hey kayla, what is this' and he picks up a naughty magazine. I rush over to snatch it out of his hands and he gets scared. He asks 'but sissy what is that?' I do not respond. I tell him to pick a book and come on. He grabs one and we are on our way to get it checked out and the lights go off. It was completely dark. 'Stay calm.' a man says. The back - up lights come on and we all go to the lobby area. We sit there for twenty minutes and the lights are back on. Everything is normal again and we go to check out. We get up to the front and I turn in the bad magazine that my brother had found. The lady asks why I was bringing it to her and I had to tell her the bad news, that it was up in the children's section. She said 'oh my!' We then check out the book, and as we leave the library, I hope that the staff will take better care to ensure inappropriate items are kept away from the children's area.

Should public libraries have to censor some of the books, movies, and music they have on display? In my opinion, they shouldn't have to. We as people have the right to learn, read, and expand our minds in whatever way we see right for us. There are three main reasons as to why I feel 'offensive' pieces of writing, movies, and music should be allowed in public libraries. One reason as to why they should not is that people have been writing and expressing themselves throughout history; therefore, there are far too many pieces that we would have to get rid of in order to eliminate them all. The second reason is that people have different opinions as to what is 'offensive' and what is not. The third reason that will be elaborated on is that people will be exposed to whatever it is you try to hide, if not through the art of music, movies, or books, then through the real world we live in.  Throughout history, mankind has been writing things down to document experiences, events, and ideas that have happened throughout history. With those experiences come profanity, sexuality, death, and abundant amounts of situations that the public eye might consider 'offensive'. If you were to try and delete these pieces, one, you would be destroying a big part of history, and two, there are far too many books, movies, and music pieces that you would have to get rid of. In almost every form of art there is some remark to something negative. If you were to take them out, you would be left with very few, if any books.  The second reason is that people have different opinions on what is bad, and what is not. For example, I was going on a band trip with all the other band students, and on the way there we put on a movie. We ended up having to turn off the movie, because one parent found it inappropriate. While that parent didn't like it, other parents were upset we turned it off, because they saw nothing wrong with it. The same rules apply with books and music. It all depends on personal views as to it being 'offensive' or not.  The third reason is that people will experience all of the things you are trying to hide. If you take it out of the library, one will hear about it on the news, on the radio, in a restaurant, in schools, just about anywhere they are. Taking out the pieces in the library will be useless in the long run. For example, people want to take out a book called, 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn' because it uses the word 'nigger' in the story quite a few times. There are a lot of people that feel it is not appropriate enough to be taught in school. On top of that, they want to get rid of all the books that say 'nigger' and replace them with books that say 'slave' instead. In my opinion, that would be a stupid thing to do, because it takes away the authenticity and effectiveness out of the book. In the book when they use the word it is very powerful and makes you think. If you replace it with 'slave' that statement or passage loses its power on its readers.  In conclusion, I strongly feel that libraries should not have to take out the 'offensive' books, music, or movies. If it does happen, we would be deleting part of our history and knowledge. With that, if we do it, how will we know what books to take out, if everyone has a different opinion on what is 'offensive' and what is not. Finally, should we do this, it will not solve anything. People in today's society will still be mean, still do sexual things, people will still use harsh language, and people will still experience 'offensive' actions. That is the society we live in and people will have to accept that fact. That is why we need to keep all of the 'offensive' pieces we have, as it allows us to have a more complete understanding of the world and prepares us for real - life experiences.

Recently, the growing issue of censorship in libraries has truly caught my attention. This is extremely unfortunate. People inherently have a right to unmolested knowledge, and censoring libraries is a direct and blatant violation of that right. Libraries are fundamentally meant to be a place of learning, and they should undoubtedly be kept that way.  History is filled with moments that are both glorious and inglorious. We aren't always proud of what we do or what happens, but those events remain, regardless of whether or not we choose to acknowledge them. To think that turning a blind eye to the less - than - clean aspects will make them go away is not only unrealistic but also completely ignorant of facts.  I realize that there are some things children should not see or hear, and I'm not suggesting we expose them to these things. I'm merely saying that trying to hide them from what we deem to be unclean is neither right nor a good idea in general. We can't shelter our children forever, and sooner or later they will learn things we wish they didn't. This is an inevitable part of life. Life doesn't seek to hide its darker side from us at all, and to hide it from our children will serve little more than to handicap them. Do children need to be protected from some things? Yes, for a time, they do, but it is the role of the individual parent to protect their child. Protect the children, but don't do so at the expense of everyone else.  Why should the views of some hinder all others? Those who would presume to know what people should see and what they should not are out of touch. Those prudish enough to believe that people need to be protected from nature, from history, or from their own desires have no more right, and perhaps even less than everyone else, to interfere with individual decision - making. People have a right to make their own choices about what they believe, but no right to force those opinions on others.  This essay may make no difference, but it has said what needed to be said and thus served its purpose. With that task completed, I can finish with a good conscience, knowing that I've stood up for the principle of free access to knowledge in libraries.

Should certain materials such as books, magazines, movies, etc., be taken off the shelf in a library if those items may be offensive towards others?
