Many people base their actions on their own views. What, in their minds, appear to be justified due to their beliefs, might cause an uproar from others. One instance of this is media censorship. It happens daily, everywhere. Someone can take it upon themselves to, in their mind, 'make the piece better for general viewing'. In reality, though, they are really ruining the experience of the media for everyone else and even impeding on the rights granted to us by the constitution: Freedom of the Press. First up, books in the library. Every time I go to the library and pick up some books, there is always one book with the 'bad parts' marked out. Someone had found these words offensive and decided that no one should have to see or read them. To me, it was irritating. I don't always like those words either, but having them marked out is distracting from the page and, for me, ruins the author's voice and style of writing, hence impairing what I draw from the book. Some marked - out words aren't always offensive to others, either. Simply put, if you find the book offensive, don't read it. Others may enjoy it, whether they share your views or not. People also take the liberty of simply removing whole pieces of media from shelves just because they find it offensive. If everyone removed anything they didn't like, or found offensive, there would be nothing left in the world for anyone to enjoy. We, as American citizens, have the right to make our own choices, and our choices should not be limited by the views of certain individuals. That means that if I want to read or view something, it should be available to me, so I may learn and expand my views, even if it makes someone else uncomfortable. With nearly every disputable form of media that comes out, people harangue the producers and say the piece should have never been made. Wrong. Producers and authors can publish whatever they would like. It's called Freedom of the Press, and it is a right guaranteed to us, as American citizens, under the Constitution. And clearly, if pieces like that are being produced, people read it. Plain and simple. You might not, but maybe a neighbor, or even a relative, may not be offended by it and might read it. Supply and demand. If everyone found it offensive, no one would buy or read it, and because of that, it would no longer be produced. You would get your way. But, no. Some people do read it and it is produced. Again, if you don't like it, don't read it. People should not take it upon themselves to censor what others can and can't do, see, or read. If someone wants to read a story that has 'bad words' in it, so be it. Others should not ruin the experience by marking the words out. Not only is it rude and ruining the experience for the reader, but it is also destroying someone else's property. If someone wants to view something that is against a certain religion, so be it. They have the right and no one can take that right away from them. In my opinion, censorship in libraries, whether by government, or other civilians, should not be allowed. We citizens are allowed the right to make our own choices and in public libraries, the public should be allowed to read or watch whatever they want. Choice is one of the principles of the constitution, and it should be protected, not limited.

Many libraries contain books, movies, music, and magazines that can be considered offensive. All of these libraries, however, have certain reasons to have these books. Whether those reasons are for education or for recreation, the libraries have reasons for them. So, the libraries that do have 'offensive' books, should be allowed to keep them because they are not offensive to everyone, and they could be beneficial to the reader. These books that are considered offensive to some people may not be offensive to others. For example, Sarah, who is from the South, comes into a library and finds a book that is all about the Civil War, and she reads that the South is full of a bunch of people who mistreated their slaves. Sarah gets a bit offended by this. Then, on the other hand, Tom, who is an African - American historian, picks up the same book and reads all about the South and how they treated their slaves. Tom thinks that the same book that Sarah hated is a great book. As shown in the example, America's people are very diverse, but what comes with that diversity is a lot of opposing views in its citizens. A library doesn't want to only appeal to one race, it wants to appeal to all of them, the only way to have that happen is to accidentally offend some people in the process. The citizens of the United States need to be more understanding that their race isn't the only one here. If a book offends a person, that person simply should not read it. However, these books, which many may find offensive, could also be beneficial to its readers. Some of these books could be helpful to the people who choose to read it. Going back to the Civil War reference, Sarah was reading her high - school American history text book, and she read about the horrible deeds the South had done regarding their slaves and the fact that they lost the Civil War to the Union, and she got offended because her side lost. Then, Tom, who is in the same class as Sarah, was reading his history text book and was becoming more and more elated as he read on. He found out that kids all over the country were learning about what had happened to his ancestors and that the Union defeated the South. Tom was as happy as he could be with this book, whereas Sarah couldn't be any more displeased. If this book was pitched out of the library, how would students all over the nation learn of the Civil War? They wouldn't. Libraries cannot just throw out books because they offend someone. As Katherine Paterson said, if we all picked a pile of books that offend us and got rid of them, then there wouldn't be any books left for any of us to read because other nations would be offended by the books that appealed to one, and so on and so forth. So, libraries need to keep the books that they have and get even more books. This nation needs as many books as it can get because they are all extremely helpful to those that they appeal to. We just need to remember that not all of the books appeal to us and not to get offended by those that don't.

Censorship in libraries, in my opinion, is over - rated. Everywhere you hear of books, music, magazines, and movies being offensive or degrading, but does that mean that they should be taken off the shelves of our public libraries, or out of book stores? I say no because future generations need to know of the material, it may not always be offensive, and the public libraries have no right to tell us what we can, and cannot read. Some say that our future generations will be greatly shorted of knowledge, or become naive because of this lack of knowledge. I say this is because of the censorship in libraries. Katherine Paterson once said 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' So if they're taking books off the shelves because they find them offensive, then there will be so many books gone, that the kids will not have a broader view as so many people are lucky to have today. Everyone has a different opinion about everything, including what's offensive and what's not. If one person sees a book as being offensive, that doesn't necessarily mean that someone else will also. I've heard of teachers not letting the students see pictures of The Holocaust, because they think it's offensive. Not everyone agrees with that. The Holocaust is a big part in history and it being categorized as offensive is wrong, it's not the only thing in history that is bad. If they start taking out big parts of history, it will be long lost and forgotten. Lastly, I believe that the libraries should not be able to tell us what we can and cannot read. We have the right to choose what we want to read, if we think that it's bad and shouldn't be reading it, then we won't read it. But that doesn't mean they should take out the book because one person finds it offensive. Someone else might want to read it. I think that people are mature enough to pick what they read, and as for children, their parents are the ones that could pick for them. With so many different opinions, it's hard to decide what to do about censorship. I believe that if it's offensive, maybe they should have a special section for explicit media and reading. Maybe then people wouldn't be offended by it. Just because one person doesn't like it doesn't mean another wouldn't either. In conclusion, we should balance the need for access to information with the concerns of those who find certain materials offensive, but not at the cost of hiding important parts of history and culture.

Do we really want our children looking at half - nude people or the murder of innocent people just because of their skin color? In today's libraries, there are many books and movies that represent racism. Take for instance the movie 'To Kill a Mockingbird.' In the movie, the white children get yelled at because they are playing with the African - American children. This is a wonderful example of why censorship is necessary. Just think, if your child were to watch this and then go and say something rude to one of their friends, who is African - American, it would be very offensive to them. Although this movie is about historical events, it still needs to be taken off the shelves, in my opinion. In today's society, nudity is becoming a big issue in movies and also in books. You may think that it is okay to let your child watch a movie rated R, but little did you know, there is nudity in it. Depending on how old your child is, and if you let them on the computer or not, they might think it is okay to go and look up nude pictures on the internet. Also, in books this is becoming an issue. It was just the other day I sat down to read a book about a musical that I wish to see, and there were nude pictures in it. Once I found this out, I asked my mother to please take it back. These are the sort of things that need to be taken off the shelves of our libraries. Language usage in music is also a big deal. Many rap artists think it is okay to use offensive and explicit language in their music. I do not think they take into consideration that young children will be listening to their music. This genre of music needs to be taken off the shelves. You may think it is okay for your young child to listen to it now, but just wait until those words make it into their vocabulary. I think that library censorship is a big deal that needs to be taken into deep consideration. It may be different at first, especially when you go in to get your favorite rap tape, or your favorite R movie, but trust me in the long run, you will thank the library for taking it off the shelves. Especially when you get older and have children. You will not want them listening, reading, or watching the things you watched as a child. In conclusion, implementing library censorship is a step towards protecting the young and impressionable minds from potentially harmful and offensive content, and it is a responsibility that libraries should take seriously.

Cooling the relevant topic: Key aspects and considerations. From Book by a certain author. Censorship in public libraries would be a blatant insult to the institution. A library, which serves as a citadel of knowledge, should not be restricted by society regarding what knowledge it can convey. One crucial role of a library, which is a destination for researchers, is to offer information that people need to seek. For those who can't find information at home without fear, or those who can't ask questions without facing retribution, the library stands as a pillar of safety. Books are impartial; they are incapable of judgment. To censor the books held in a library is to undermine human progress. The freedom of thought and the freedom of press, which are present in our nation and are becoming more prominent around the world, rule out the idea of this censorship. If any book is subject to criticism or opposition, then aren't all books worthy of the same scrutiny? To devalue one opinion or perspective over another is to degrade the entire culture from which libraries have emerged. Libraries are a communal institution, open to all views and writings. The purpose of bringing books together under one roof is to give them equal standing as literature or scholarly works. From personal experience, censorship in the library has cost me precious time and has deprived me of parts of my life. Growing up in a small town where ideas of gender and sexuality were rather rigid, any search for dissenting opinion was often in vain. When I visited my school's library as a child searching for answers about my sexuality, I found little help. Around the library, there were countless stories of a man and woman falling in love, but I never found a fairy - tale of two princes. It was only after I left the school that I discovered such books did exist in my old school library, but they were kept removed, off the shelves, and restricted. More insulting than finding books on certain issues completely unrepresented was to find that they were treated so differently. Here lies the core problem. Some people believe that if minority opinions or values are unrepresented, they will disappear. This is the essence of censorship: ignoring an issue or a life - choice until it fades away. But books can't force their values on readers. They can't push information on us. Books must be actively read; we must consent to receive their knowledge. Unlike an advertisement that might surprise us, we have to pick up a book and open it to gain its guidance. If my library had fulfilled its duty and given me the guidance I sought, I would have grown much more easily. I would have learned not only how to express and accept myself but might have also learned to accept others more readily. In the past few years, with the far - reaching effects of certain global events reaching the newest generation, a particular place has been searching for ways to pay homage to the victims of the violence of specific tragedies. However, the country finds that it can't effectively memorialize these tragedies. When trying to construct a monument, the government and culture realize they have little to base it on. The results of murder and book - burning have created an emptiness, a void. As such, architects have created what could be called 'anti - monuments', commemorating a void for future generations to remember what was lost. One of the most powerful examples, at least to me, is in the form of a negative bookshelf: a solid wall with gaping holes in the shape of book spines, stretching across the rows. This represents the knowledge lost from book - burning. We can't even describe what's lost because the knowledge has vanished. We must ask ourselves, what are we missing? What views, what prose, what beauty has been taken from us while we continue living, never having the chance to glimpse it? This is the detrimental effect of library censorship. To remove a book from its rightful place on a shelf is to metaphorically set its words on fire. Once it's gone, it will be forgotten. To protect our future generations and enlighten our descendants, we must work hard to preserve all books, regardless of whether they seem offensive, disgusting, brave, or new. Let the reader decide a book's value. Let the person in search of answers pick it up or leave it behind. Give the book a chance, as it might have an unrealized power. Leave the libraries as they are, as monuments to the preservation and progression of knowledge and wisdom.

Censorship is a topic that is strongly opinionated. If one person does not like the content of a text, that person might find themselves saying that they have the right to prevent others from being able to view that text in a library, public location, or online source. But what about the other people? Shouldn't they have a say too? Let's say that 'person one' does not agree with the language in a text, but 'person two' perhaps does. Which person has the benefit in this situation? Freedom of speech and expression are two factors that are very valued, and perhaps sometimes even overlooked in our society. In this case, both 'person one' and 'person two' are allowed to have a right to say and think what they feel about the text. Should 'person one' still have the right to say that this text does not belong in a public location? Well, if every person had the right to remove something that they disagreed with from the public, there would be nothing left. In such a large and diverse society, there is bound to be at least one person who does not agree with the content of a certain material of each and every lyric, magazine, book, and text that there is available. Some might say that this is unfair to that one group who does not agree with the content of a material. But how is that fair to the other group who actually do agree with that material? Freedom of speech and expression are still not being excluded from that group who does not agree with such material. That group is still allowed to speak their opinions and takes on that particular material, as well as the people who do agree with the material. Take iTunes for example. If there is a song that has language and/or content that could be considered disrespectful to a person, there is a red tag by the song that says: 'explicit.' This is an indicator that a person who could find foul language offensive should not buy that song. There is also the compromise. Quite often, if a song is tagged as 'explicit', there is usually an alternative of the same song. That same song is then tagged with a gray tag that states: 'clean.' A song being 'clean' simply means that the song is still the same, but the content considered to be disrespectful is removed, or removed and replaced with different words that are not considered to be disrespectful. Both parties are now satisfied with the so - called: happy - median. Take movies as another example. Movies are rated based on their content. The higher the rating, the more explicit such movie is. Along with the rating, there is an explanation as to why that movie is rated the way that it is. If you are a person who is careful about viewing things that are against your own opinions and beliefs, then by seeing the rating and explanation, you know that this material is not for you. Again, the happy - median. For every given case of a group of people who do not agree with the terms of a certain content, the alternate group must be considered as well. Both parties in this case are still able to say and express their own opinions. So, should this context be removed from the eye of the public because a certain group of people do not agree with the content in it? No. However, one must keep in mind the views and opinions that each person has on such material, and that person should still be respected for their take on that material. In conclusion, a balanced approach with proper labeling and alternatives is the best way to handle potentially offensive content in public media.

Censorship, that's a word that causes a lot of arguments in today's society. People have extremely different views on censorship throughout the world. In some countries, dictators do not allow their citizens to have internet access, watch the news, or in some more extreme cases, not even watch television at all. The majority of the time they do this because they do not want the citizens of their country to know what is happening around the world. This sets up a 'fish bowl' environment, meaning that people from other countries see all of the issues in that country, but the people actually in the country have no idea what's going on around them.  Although we don't always see censorship in that extreme of a sense, it still plays a large part in today's society. Everything from music on the radio to military files is censored. Think about it, how often can you listen to a song on the radio where all of the original words are still intact? Arguments over censorships have gone back and forth for years without really making much progress at all. Each side of the argument, whether it's for or against censorship, is almost entirely opinionative. No one can say for sure that censorship is completely needed or not. It's just too hard to determine whose opinion is really more convincing.  In my opinion, I don't think anything should be censored. If the writer of a TV show throws in a vulgar word, most likely it's for the effect that it has on people to show emotion. The same thing goes for songs. When an artist writes the lyrics to a song, they are trying to convey a message, and they use certain words that get their point across more effectively or more dramatically. Parents argue that their children are seeing too much violence on TV and that it is causing behavior problems along with other things, and that shows need to be more suitable for children. There is an alternative to censoring all of these things. Rather than 'ruining' everyone's fun, just don't let your kids watch that show.  In the United States today, we have something called freedom. We exercise this right every day with what we wear and what we say. I think that we should take that freedom and apply it to censorship. Instead of complaining about violence in movies and sex on TV, you can make a decision simply not to watch that kind of show. Everyone has the option to say NO. If you don't want to hear or see something, simply choose something else to watch, or even just do something entirely different. You do not have to do anything that you don't want to do. It's an easy solution. All you have to do is exercise a right that you have had since the day you were born and just say no, I don't want to do that. It's very simple and could potentially stop all debates on whether or not things need to be censored.

I think books, movies, music, and magazines that are offensive should not be pulled from the shelves. If you find something offensive then don't pick it up, it's that simple. You might find something offensive but it might not be to someone else. It is all according to your own personal opinion.   Sure, there are some things that are very offensive to certain people, and those people will try to put a stop to it. But I think that is wrong. Because it might be offensive to you but what if there is someone studying that topic but can't find the information on it because you thought it was offensive and got it pulled off of the shelf. Then it disrupts that person's study.   I am not promoting violent books and movies or other offensive material, all I'm saying is if you find something offensive then turn the other cheek. It might be offensive to you but other people might not think the same way.   There are many books and movies out there that are offensive to many people. And if we were to take all of those movies and books off of the shelf then there would be very few subjects and titles to read and watch.   In my conclusion, I support the fact that offensive material should stay on the shelves. It could be helpful to many people and at the same time it can be offensive to a lot of people. But if you are one of those people that find something offensive then don't pay any attention to it and find another subject or topic. For someone to take another person's right to read a book or watch a movie is wrong, everyone has their own opinions and rights. By respecting these individual rights, we can maintain a diverse and inclusive cultural environment.

There are some books that should not be removed from libraries due to censorship. From past experience with censorship, I found out it can tone down a book. In the book @CAPS1 @NUM1, for example, the books are being burnt and it is causing society to fall apart. Censorship often comes from people with a more ethnic background who don't want the kids to grow up and see inappropriate language.   The most recent book that I have heard of getting censored is @CAPS2 @CAPS3. The main word they are removing from this book is "nigger" because some people find this word very offensive to their race. The committees are trying to remove the books from school shelves.   I think we should not have censorship just because parents do not want their kids to hear the words in school or read them when eventually the kids will learn the words on their own or hear the words somewhere else. The kids can even learn the word from their own parent or from TV. I personally think that committees should stop trying to censor everything because they won't be able to censor how adults talk when they are around children and younger adults. In conclusion, censorship in libraries is an over - reaching measure that fails to address the real issue of language exposure and limits access to important literary works.

Katherine Paterson, a well - known author, presents an idea with which I strongly agree. She states, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf--that work I abhor--then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf left for any of us.' If everyone has the right to remove certain books that they find inappropriate, there might not be anything left for people to read.   Although it is a good thing for parents to have a voice and stand up for what they believe, books should not be banned. Many people have different views on what is right and wrong. Some might suggest that a certain book is obscene, while others might be offended by a different book. If every parent had the right to get a book banned, there might come a time when no books meet the approval of the parent.   Some of these books present great learning opportunities to students. Books often allow students to think in different, new ways. They can learn from a new point of view. Often times, a student can look at his or her own morals and values, which is a good thing. If a teacher finds a book which they think is appropriate, parents should respect the decision of this teacher. They might suggest another reading, or offer other ideas, but to go as far as getting the book completely removed is not right.   While removing books for reading might be going too far, things such as movies could go the other direction. Personally, my parents would be horrified to see grotesque, inappropriate movies set out in broad daylight where everyone can look at them. I think that this difference between books and movies is a simple thing: Books do not normally have an inappropriate cover, while bad movies often do. Because of this, even the people who do not wish to view the movie are often forced to see images which they find disturbing. If one was to walk past a book they did not intend to read, they do not have to be appalled at the cover as they pass.   Although parents care about the things their children read, books should not be banned. Although other things might have affects on youth, books are a different story. They allow one's self to dive deep into thought, to make observations, and to form opinions. They are a key to growing, learning, and discovering. In conclusion, the value of books in education and personal growth should be preserved, and the practice of banning them should be avoided.

First off, I do like censorship laws to a certain extent. They can play a role in maintaining a basic level of decency in public spaces. However, the government cannot ban everything that they deem inappropriate. What one person or the government considers inappropriate might not be the same for others. I think it depends more on what the family deems inappropriate. A family has a better understanding of their children's values and maturity levels. I do not think they should have any completely inaccessible areas in libraries for children of younger ages. Instead, proper guidance can be provided. I believe that the viewer should have a family member's consent to view said content. This way, parents or guardians can decide if the material is suitable for their children. I also believe that if the content is not relative to the viewers' interests, then they should just not look at it. They are not required to look at it, so if they do not like it, then they do not look at it. However, if the library does not consent to holding the books, music, movies, magazines, etc., then they do not have to and the viewer can go somewhere else. And if they do have the books, music, etc., then they can put limits and ratings on them. But I do not think that an adult could go in and complain about inappropriate material. As I said before, if they do not like it, then they are not required to look at it. I actually think that the government should not tolerate parents whining and complaining about the content of different materials. One parent should not have the ability to take away others' privileges to books, because they deem it inappropriate. Just because they do not like the content, does not exclude all others from enjoying it. Also, if a library does have an age restriction on certain materials, then appropriate acts of discipline should be taken for the viewer of said materials. However, if the viewer has an adult family member with them and has their consent, then I think they should be able to view the material, regardless of ratings. In conclusion, a balanced approach that respects individual choices and family values is the most appropriate way to handle the issue of potentially inappropriate content in libraries.

There are so many books and magazines, music, and movies to be discovered in this vast world. Some are funny, capable of making us burst into laughter; some are sad, bringing a tinge of melancholy; some are weird, sparking our curiosity; and some are scary, sending shivers down our spines. And then there are some that are questionable to others on whether it was even necessary to even put the material on the shelf of a library in the first place. I for one am not one of those people who would question a book, magazine, movie or music. I believe that everyone's voice needs to be heard somehow and if we all take a voice away that we do not like, then we will lose a lot of voices. We are all entitled to our own opinion. When it comes to some things some are more opinionated than others, but in the end we all have something that we feel strongly about. There are some people who want to express their feelings with the whole world with people that understand and agree with what they feel. If we take that away from people, then how will we all connect? Some things, at times, come across as offensive to others, but who has the right to say that something should not be shared with the rest of the world. I have observed that when people have the same interests in things like music, books, or movies then it gives people a way to come together and talk about something. I have witnessed at concerts everybody seems to connect because we are all there for the same reason, to see the band or person that we all like to listen to. Everybody's different and likes to have their own personal preference on something. Like Katherine Paterson once said, 'But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' I think she was trying to say that if we all take a book off the shelf that we do not think should be on there, then there is going to be nothing left for anybody to read. Then what will we do? There's such a variety of materials that are needed to be discovered whether it is a book, music, or movie everyone has their own special type that they enjoy. I do not think that censorship is a good idea for any sort of material on a shelf. These materials are what keep people connected with each other. I think it is very important to not censor anything because it does not just give the writer a voice, it gives a voice for the people that agree with the material of the book, movie, or music. In conclusion, embracing the diversity of creative works in libraries is essential for fostering connection and free expression.

There are many books, movies, and music in the libraries. These things can come in so many varieties, catering to different tastes and interests. Have you ever been to a library and not found something you liked? Well, most people find a lot of things that interest them in many ways. Many people come to a library each day to check out something they will enjoy and have a good time listening, reading, or watching. So many people are different and each person likes something different from one another. So the question is, 'Should we remove some books, music, and movies off the shelves because they're offensive?' From experience, yes there are things at a library that children or younger teenagers should not read, hear, or see. Though most libraries split a lot of their sections up by ages. Depending on your age you should go to the sections that mostly provide the thing you want. Do not go to a place that provides something that is not your age group, instead go to the place that looks like you belong. I personally have seen younger teens or children get a book or magazine that was not their age group, but that children wanted to look up on that thing. You have to understand that most younger teens and children are curious about many things before they even get to that age. As a parent or legal guardian, most children look up to you. If you read, listen, or watch something that is not to their age level, but the child wants to be just like you. Children look up to their parents or legal guardian. They want to do the same thing you do, so they copy you. They will find something that is similar to what you're doing. They might go find a book, movie, or CD that is not their age group. They will do this all because they want to be just like their parents or guardian. So as a parent or guardian you have to watch what you do also and try to set good examples to your children so they do not find offensive books or etc. There are so many reasons why people might think some things are offensive. Even though we are the reason why books and other things are brought into libraries today. Children today are growing up a lot faster than we want them to, but sometimes we cannot stop that. Just set good examples to children or any person not to get a book, movie, or music that is not their age group. Libraries can be a fun and learning environment for everyone. Just sometimes we all do not think alike or like the same stuff. There are just too many people in this world and I have read articles about libraries. I have read why libraries might not be a family place anymore all because of the varieties they carry. Have you ever thought though, 'It's us humans that makes the libraries carry these varieties?' I think so, because we are what makes up a library. We the people are the ones that want these books, movies, magazines, and music. So think about it next time you walk into a library and you see something that you do not think is right. Think about how someone really likes that. We all need to accept things if we like it or not at times. Just set good examples to help people not get those things that could be offensive. In conclusion, by setting good examples and respecting the diversity of library materials, we can ensure that libraries remain a valuable resource for all.

Libraries should have whatever they want in the library. Everyone has their own thoughts on things. If you don't like what they have on their shelves then don't go there anymore or pick up something you like. Everyone is different so you can't just take offensive stuff off the shelves, it might be offensive to one person, but not to someone else. Materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines you can't just start taking stuff off the shelves just because they're offensive to you. The only way I would say take books or magazines off the shelves is if the facts are not right. Libraries hold almost anything anybody needs - materials, books, music, movies, magazines and everything for facts. So don't start taking stuff off your shelves. Teenagers might have to write a paper about something that people think is offensive. If you don't have everything in the library then we won't have good facts. No one in this world agrees on anything, all you would be doing would be picking a fight if you're taking off offensive items. Libraries are open to anyone that wants to read about almost anything they want to read about. Music - everybody has their own type of music you can't just start taking music off because you think it's offensive. Most people have their own type of everything. Children are their own person. You can keep them from whatever you want to, the thing is you can't hold them back in life. They get older you won't be able to tell them what to do or what not to do. If you keep them from a book or etc. they might end up reading it in the long run. Keeping your kids safe is important, I understand. Your kids are going to experience things you don't want them to. Just by taking offensive stuff off the shelves doesn't mean your kids won't find them somewhere else. I could understand if the books or magazines were offensive to you because it was about your family. But most of the time, you're going to have offensive things come up in your life. That means you're going to have to not let it get under your skin or get over it. Things get under people's skin too easy. This is why the world doesn't get along. If you don't like something don't be around it. Find something else to read about. That's what I do if I don't like something. In conclusion, libraries should maintain a diverse collection, and individuals should respect different perspectives and make their own choices.

Libraries provide us with knowledge, entertainment, and peace. You can go there to learn and to do research if you have to write a paper. You can rent movies, music, and books at your pleasure as long as you take care of them. Also, if you're just having a hectic day and need some peace and quiet, libraries become a perfect get - away. But, here's the truth. Many people find certain things in libraries to be offensive and would rather them not be on the shelves. So, do we remove these things or let them stay? My opinion is to let them stay. I believe that books are too important to throw out just because they may contain a few vulgar words or images. It's the same with magazines and movies. Also, music is changing as the years go on and many people, especially elders, don't enjoy listening to this new style of music. Just because one person may find something offensive, doesn't mean everyone else will. People have many different views when it comes to these things. Take history for example. Many history books contain harsh, real - life facts about things that went on in the past. A song, book, or movie about slavery can cause some people to be offended. Whether it's because the person opposes slavery greatly or they believe that slavery was a good thing, people have different feelings towards it. Another good example is movies. Some people may find a movie offensive because of words said or if a certain person dies first, while others could care less. Additionally, many things that are found offensive to one person can make something more interesting to someone else. There are many movies nowadays that can be seen as very offensive. But honestly, the offensive things happening just make someone else want to know more about what's going on. It is practically the same with books. I myself have read plenty of things that would make some people cry or even get really mad or disgusted. Even though in the end, I find them to be exceptionally good books. It just depends on how you view it. So, should things that are found offensive to one person be removed from a library? The answer is no. There are just too many things that can be taken offensively. If you start taking away these things, libraries are only going to become vacant. Younger people will stop coming because materials will be less interesting. You will lose artifacts and stories about the history of the world. There will also only be so many books to read, if ever a non - offensive book could even be found. My advice to libraries, keep materials that can be found extremely offensive in their own area, away from younger people who may react strongly. Maybe even put a sticker on the book, if possible, letting people know just what they're dealing with. In conclusion, maintaining a diverse and uncensored library collection, while taking appropriate precautions, is crucial for the intellectual growth and freedom of all library users.

Katherine Paterson once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' I firmly believe that the books and other items should remain on the shelves of the library, as censorship in libraries is entirely unnecessary. As Katherine Paterson clearly stated, there will be no books left on the shelves if you take every book off that someone in the community finds offensive. What is offensive to one person may not be considered offensive from another person's point of view. Children, teens, and adults all have their own right to choose whatever book they want to read, movie they want to watch, or music they want to listen to. If it is a child or a young teen, then I believe that the parents should have a say in what their children read or watch. In my case, I am not allowed to listen to offensive music or watch rated R movies, but that shouldn't mean that it should be taken off the shelves of the library. Just because that is what my family believes to be right does not mean it is the only way to live. A person has their own rights to choose what they want to read, watch, or listen to. They can make the choice based on the way they have been raised or simply because that is what they think is right or wrong. If they think that a book is offensive, then they don't have to read it; they have the right to say no and put the book back on the shelf. If they think that the book is appropriate, then they can read it, and there is no law stating that they have to share the book with anyone else. If there is a book out there that is offensive in your view and you read it, there is no reason you have to agree with it. Every person is free to disagree with anything they want to disagree with. If you are a parent to a child and you are uncomfortable with them reading, listening, or watching something that is offensive, you should set the rules early in life with them. Parents should make sure that their children are not reading inappropriate things, listening to offensive music, or watching violent or rated R movies. Therefore, if you are comfortable with your children seeing and hearing offensive things, then you don't have to worry about what is out there in the community. The things that your children are watching, reading, listening to isn't a problem, and if it becomes a problem in the parents' eyes, then they have the right to stop the children from reading the offensive books, watching the bad movies, and listening to the music that they view as offensive. Every parent and family is different. As long as your child knows the rules and what you believe in, then there is no need for censorship in libraries. In my family, I am not allowed to listen to offensive music. Offensive music in my house is considered music with curse words in the lyrics. The words that my family considers offensive may be different from what other families consider offensive. I know that I don't want to and can't listen to those certain songs, but that does not mean that I can't be friends or be around people that listen to that kind of music. Just because that is what my family believes in does not mean that it should be taken off the shelves of the library or any other place. What my family believes in may not be the right thing in another family's view. Every person has their own right, and if they want to listen to that music, then they should be able to. My family also believes that at my age right now, I should not watch rated R movies. If you took all the rated R movies off the shelves, then half the movies would be gone, and that is not fair to the people who enjoy rated R movies. What my family believes may not be what other families believe in. I know what I stand for, and I will do what I think is right; I won't listen to offensive music or watch rated R movies. In no way though does that mean that other children, teens, adults shouldn't enjoy that kind of music and those movies. In conclusion, I believe that censorship should not be used in libraries. It is every person's own right, and they are capable of making decisions that they think are the right thing to do. Parents also have a say in what they want their children to watch, read, or listen to. They can monitor what their children are reading, watching, or listening to, and if they find it offensive, they can stop their children. It is not necessary to take the items off the shelf. In my family, my parents find some types of music and movies offensive, and I know when I go to the library or any other place that I won't get those items. I will get the music and movies I enjoy and find age - appropriate. Just as in Katherine Paterson's quote, everyone has the same rights, and if we all take the items we think are offensive off the shelves, then there will be nothing left on the shelves. Everyone has a different point of view, and no one person has the correct or wrong point of view that the community has to follow.

Offensive media is everywhere. From books filled with explicit content to music lyrics laced with profanity, our culture bombards us with it. Children that see inappropriate media can easily pick up bad behavior. This can then lead to a child having a hard time associating with his peers, as they may use language or display actions that are not socially acceptable. Adults are also affected by inappropriate media if they see their favorite celebrity or any other role model use inappropriate behavior. This could make an adult emotionally unhealthy, and they may become violent or depressed, as they start to question their values and the world around them. Finally, our world could be better if offensive media were abolished altogether. People's lives could be enriched with good, clean entertainment instead of being corrupted with inappropriate media. One can clearly see that offensive media must be pulled from our country's libraries immediately. Inappropriate media is surrounding us daily, including children. What children see they imitate, even in the first couple years of their lives. So if they hear a swear word on TV or see someone doing drugs, they may imitate it. Clearly this is inappropriate behavior for a child. If the child is exposed to inappropriate media for a long period of time, they may think that it is ok to use it in everyday life. Their social skills and mind are being corrupted because of offensive media. Libraries should pull inappropriate media off of their shelves because it can corrupt a child's mind. Another reason why libraries should pull off offensive media is because adults can pick up different offensive habits as well. Just as children can pick up the offensive habit of swearing, so can adults if they are exposed to it for a long period of time. Besides swearing, adults can also think that killing someone is ok because they saw it in a movie. They could then pick up a violent weapon and try to kill someone if they are angry. This is not a healthy way to express your feelings towards someone if they are making you angry. Our country's libraries should pull off inappropriate media from their shelves because it can turn adults into being emotionally unhealthy. Finally, inappropriate media should be pulled off library shelves because our world could be a better place without it. Media is one of the root causes of why people act the way they do. If they see their favorite celebrity getting arrested for a DUI in a magazine, they may think that it is ok to drink and drive. Another example is if people read about someone doing drugs in a book, they may want to try and experiment with drugs themselves. This can lead to people doing crazy things that can be harmful to other lives around them. Offensive media is almost anywhere. When children see inappropriate media, they may think that it is ok to imitate it. Adults, when exposed to enough offensive media, can pick up nasty habits like swearing, killing, or doing drugs which, in turn, can lead to being emotionally unhealthy. Without inappropriate media on our library shelves, our world would be a better place. We would have less conflict, less deaths, and better lives that are enriched, not corrupted, with quality media. Millions of lives could be made better if libraries pulled off inappropriate media from their shelves.

All of us have rights, and all of us have the same chance to express what we feel, think, or believe. Freedom is the most beautiful and important thing we have, and nobody can take that away from us: it's just something that belongs to ourselves, and that everybody does have. As humans, it is not easy to understand other people's thoughts, and it could turn kind of hard to accept the opinions that strangers from us can bring. A library is a place where we can find all kinds of material that can easily answer many of our questions. Sometimes, some material can be offensive and make a target group of people feel uncomfortable, while there is also material that can be really helpful through our searching. If I had the right to remove any magazine, book, or movie off the shelf, I would at least think about it before removing it and consider how helpful and worth it it could be for someone that really needs it. And if everybody else had the same right as me, then we wouldn't have any material at all in the library. Music is a big topic to talk about. We all know there are people that are really used to listening to a type of music that other people can call 'rude music', and it could be pretty offensive for kids. I truly believe it won't be fair for any of us to label people because of the music they like, the books they read, or the movies they watch. We need to understand that nobody is better than nobody else, and we also need to respect other people's feelings. It's something that we have to work on continuously, as it is an essential part of a harmonious society.

Should books, magazines, or movies that are found offensive be removed from the shelves? I think that the book, magazine, or movie should stay on the shelf even if it is found offensive. If it is offensive to one person, it doesn't mean that it is to every person. Everyone has their own view on the subject of offensive or not. Different people have different life experiences, values, and beliefs, which shape their perspectives on what is offensive. I don't think the person that wrote the book or magazine meant for it to be offensive. They were just writing what they thought went along with the story, and some people took offense from the book or magazine. But, they shouldn't argue over it because, like I said before, the author probably didn't mean for it to be offensive. Maybe the author was trying to explore a complex topic or tell a unique story, and the interpretation of offensiveness came from the readers' preconceived notions. In conclusion, the books should stay on the shelves. Everyone has a different point of view. The author probably didn't mean for the book or magazine to be offensive, and removing it would limit the diversity of ideas and stories available to the public.

Censorship in the world is getting worse everyday. Many people believe that some material is unsuitable. I believe that if it is unsuitable for others does not make it unsuitable for some. I believe people have the right to read, watch, or listen to what they want as long as it is not breaking any laws. I am torn on this topic because I am against censorship, but I am also for it when laws are being broken. I believe that people should have the right to read whatever they want. Granted, some people read very incriminating books that could get them in a lot of trouble, but not everyone should be punished for another person's mistake. Sometimes you hear about terrorist groups and other illegal groups, but usually they do not market to everyday people. I think that when it becomes a threat to the nation, they should remove material. For example, if a book promotes violence against the state or provides instructions for illegal activities, it should be dealt with accordingly. Another simple fact is that the constitution of the nation states that we have the freedom of speech, which basically means we may print and read whatever we want. Many people depend on the constitution to make their lives seem safer, and sometimes there is a book, article, movie, or a song that goes beyond our limits. I believe that some people use materials wrongly sometimes to get ahead and to make a name for themselves. I just think that people should write for the pure joy of it, not to persuade people to do something bad, or give bad thoughts or ideas. The government has the right to control what we partake in, but does that seem fair? I understand their logic behind this matter, but just because it has offensive matter does not mean they should remove it from society. I believe that if people want to experience it, they should be able to without wondering if it will be gone the next day. If people do not agree with this 'offensive' matter, then they should not take part in it. This is a true - enough statement that it just makes you wonder about their logic. So, does the government have the right to say what we can and cannot read? I don't believe so, but that is my opinion. I believe that people should read whatever they so choose to and should not think they are breaking laws for some 'offensive' material. Freedom of speech is what people have to look up to for the government, but how are people supposed to feel secure when they are reading a book, watching a movie, or listening to music that may be assumed 'offensive'? It is a complex issue that requires a balance between protecting the rights of individuals and maintaining the safety and well - being of the nation.

Have you ever come across books, movies, music, and magazines that deal with drugs, sexuality, and violence? I firmly believe that books, movies, music, and magazines should be removed from the library shelves if they are related to drugs, sexuality, and violence. There are several reasons for this stance. One reason is that little kids might get hold of books, certain types of music, movies, and magazines that contain drugs, sexuality, and violence, and then they could learn how to engage in such behaviors. A second reason is that I feel a library is not the place for parents and their kids to read about, watch, or listen to materials that involve drugs, sexuality, and violence. The third reason is that these kinds of materials belong in another building, a building far from children where only certain people can enter and access the books, magazines, watch the movies, and listen to the music that contain such content. The last reason is based on my experience. Once, I found a book about drugs. When I looked at it, I realized it was highly inappropriate for little kids. It had pictures of what drugs look like and what certain drugs can do to the body. In conclusion, I hope that whoever is reading this will recognize the negative impact these books, movies, music, and magazines can have on those who read, watch, and listen to them.

There are numerous books in the library that some people might find offensive to young readers today. I firmly believe that these materials should not be removed from the shelves. People have the right to read whatever they choose. There are multiple reasons for my view. First of all, there are so many books that could be considered 'offensive.' If you were to remove all of these offending books, you would essentially be removing half of the books in the library. Most young - adult books involve teens, drugs, violence, and other elements that might seem offensive. These are the very books that teenagers often read. Just because they read them doesn't mean their actions will be influenced. These types of books are mainly for entertainment and are not intended to harm or offend anyone. Secondly, I think people have the right to choose what they read, listen to, and watch. Books, music, movies, and magazines are sold for this very purpose. Everyone has different opinions and tastes regarding what they like or dislike. Finally, I believe that censoring what is on the shelves would be a mistake. There are many great books or movies that could be found offensive, and taking them off the shelf would make them less well - known. Children would be unaware of them and might miss out on some wonderful stories. Everyone has an opinion, and it's understandable for parents to watch out for their children. However, censoring what is available at the library would make it more difficult for others to find books. Libraries are meant to offer a variety of materials because everyone has different tastes.

I don't think these materials should be removed from the shelves. Everyone has the right to read such materials at some point, but with a restriction that no little kids can rent the book. If people are complaining about a book being vulgar or sexual, you shouldn't simply take it away. Instead, you could try creating an adult section. One person might love a book that has some violence in it, while on the other hand, you might have a very religious person who can't stand to see it. There are numerous viewpoints on this topic. There are parents who don't want their kids to be exposed to this type of lifestyle. Some people don't think it's as bad as others do. If you don't like a book on the shelf and don't want it in plain sight, should you really be the one to decide whether it's taken down? Some parents don't know what their kids like to read. If they have the final say on what gets removed, it could affect the kids' reading habits. What if your kid wants to read a horror book and you choose to remove those kinds of books from the shelf? Then they might not want to read the remaining books. I'd rather read a book that interests me than one I dislike. My point of view on this topic is straightforward. I don't think parents should control what we read as long as it's appropriate. I believe the decision should be left to the government to determine which books should and shouldn't be taken away.

When it comes to censorship, I firmly believe that very few things should be removed. Just because some people find a material offensive doesn't mean it's offensive to everyone. A material should only be removed if it offends an overwhelming majority of people. If you find it offensive, simply ignore it; you don't have to buy it. Maybe someone else finds it interesting and it contains the information they've been seeking. When it comes to books, music, movies, or magazines, I believe almost anything should be allowed, except for material that depicts nudity or drugs and alcohol. A little cursing here and there and some violence is perfectly acceptable, but if it's too extreme, it should probably be kept away from small children. Usually, if a child is exposed to such material, they may grow up believing that whatever they saw as a child is completely acceptable. Sometimes it's violence, sometimes it's other things like drugs or alcohol, whatever the case may be. Many parents believe that certain material should be banned because it exposes their children to bad morals. But in my opinion, if you're a good parent, you shouldn't have to worry about this. If you really don't want your child to be exposed to it, take action. For example, if you don't want your child watching a certain television show, block it. Don't just assume they won't watch it and then get mad at the show's creators when they do. It's not their fault; perhaps you as a parent should have ensured in the first place that your child didn't see that material. There are some people who believe that if any material depicts anything bad, it should be removed. But what I believe is that this is a free country and people can read and write whatever they want. If you have something to say about it, that's fine. People should be able to exercise their freedom of speech and be creative without being ridiculed.

Yes, children should not be reading materials that are of this nature. Children should be reading books that have good information, information that they can learn while in class. If books, music, and other reading and viewing materials have bad content, they should be removed from the shelf because children should not be exposed to such things. Some music contains bad language, and children should not be listening to such music. Also, movies that have inappropriate scenes should not be watched by children as it's not good for them to see all that. Parents should take action if their children are watching movies with inappropriate scenes. Magazines with inappropriate pictures are also not suitable for children as they are too young to see that. In conclusion, it is crucial to protect children from such inappropriate materials to ensure their healthy development.

My thoughts on censorship in libraries is yes, some books, music, movies, magazines, and other media should be taken off of the shelves if they are offensive. If they are left on the shelves, some very young children or teens could come up and reach for a book and find that it has inappropriate content meant for adults. The child will ask the caregiver that they are with 'What does this picture mean?', and they will most likely not know what to say at that moment. Parents and caregivers are not always ready to explain or want to explain such things right away. Everyone goes through life learning different things at different rates. Some things should be taught when we are young, like how to brush our teeth, but some things should be left until we are older, like having babies or drinking alcohol. When parents are going through the explanation of something like making babies, you do not want it to be when the child is only five years old. With books in a library that have pictures of men and women in compromising situations, questions like that do get asked too young. Libraries are public places and should be safe for any age, whether they are young babies or adults. Public schools have libraries in them also, and I would not want a child reading a vulgar or explicit book with bad or offensive things in it. It does not just have to be a book with bad things in it; it could also be something related to religions. Everyone has their thoughts and comments on at least one religion. If you have grown up a Christian your whole life, and a kid picks up a book dealing with Jews, they will ask someone about it. Young kids and teens can always find things that they shouldn't at certain ages, but why not make it less likely by having proper library censorship? When you were younger, your parent did not want to take you to the library and be asked an offensive question because of a book, music, movie, or magazine. It has worked well for so many years, so we should not have to change it now.

I don't believe that it should matter what books are in a library. If you think a book would be offensive to you, simply don't read it. If you were to read a book with opinions about a certain race or religion, just keep your opinion to yourself. Most people make a big deal about certain things to get attention. If a library was split up into sections about topics and such, it would be very helpful, and it would be a quicker way to get your books and get out to make room for others. I honestly have not seen a controversial book in a school library, but it's probably because I did not spend much time looking for it. And if there isn't one, it's probably because someone complained about it. If you are religious, you should have the right to be able to read what you want. There are all kinds of weird books in the library, and a lot of people just look at them for the fun of it. I don't know why some people have so many problems with certain things. Like I said before, if you don't like it, don't read it. In conclusion, libraries should offer a wide range of books without unnecessary censorship.

I don't believe any of those materials are offensive if found in a library. But if children look elsewhere to find those things, then they will find them at any time. The offensive materials are out there and can be picked up by some people, including children. The books aren't offensive when found in the adult area. If so found there, children wouldn't read them because they are too long for them and the books don't have any pictures. Music can be offensive, but as I said, it's only found in the adult area. Kids aren't interested in that kind of music at that age, so they wouldn't bother to look at it. Movies and magazines can have offensive things in them and can be found anywhere, but finding them in a library is going to be rare. The only thing you will likely find in a library that is offensive is a magazine. They make a bunch of different types of them, and they can be found anywhere. To explain the offensive and the non - offensive books that are out there, I'm going to talk about 'The Offensive Book'. This book has a lot of bad words, sexual scenes, drugs, gang violence, and racism. This book is so offensive that the children's parents wouldn't let them read it, but this book is based on a true story. Everything that happened in that book was real, and people need to know what happened and why the people in that story were doing those things. Some books may be offensive, but you can learn from others' mistakes by reading that book. Everything may be offensive to you in one way, but looking from the other point of view, it's a learning experience. People who made those mistakes could tell the children that those things aren't worth it. Everything has its purpose. The books can tell you the story of people's lives, and the movies are based on the stories, so instead you can watch them. Music can tell you the life of people through poetry. Magazines really don't have much of a point; they're just there to gossip. In the end, offensive materials in libraries can serve as valuable learning tools.

Is the censorship in libraries really necessary? In my opinion, it is but only to a certain extent. I believe that most people who frequently go to the library know what types of books, movies, magazines, etc. are for the adult group and what is for the teenage/children group. I think the censoring is helping to keep our youth from taking the words and actions they see in these materials and using them in their daily lives. If we don't want them to read or even hear certain things, I think the censorship is a great thing in many ways. I believe if the censorship was to go away in some forms, I would use a different method of censorship that was a bit more favorable for adults. The censorship would still be present at the library in a certain form. There would be something just a bit different or new about whatever that person is checking out. If we could, when people are checking out these books, movies, magazines, etc., we could use a rating system just like movies do. When a child who is 10 years old comes to the library to check out an item and they find one they are interested in, they could bring it to the librarian. The librarian would check the rating and the age of the child with their library card and see if that item is appropriate for that child. There could be many ratings, like PG, PG - 13, R, and NC - 17. I think ages 5 - 10 are for the PG - PG - 13, the ages 11 - 15 are for the R and ages 16 and up for rated NC - 17. I see many times when children are learning words, phrases, and actions from movies, books, etc. that make them think it is okay to do or say these things. I think not. In my opinion, this idea could help our youth and their parents make better choices in the content they are exposed to. So if you feel like this is a good idea, contact your local library and tell them you are in favor of the new system, 'The Library Rating System'. Don't wait until you have forgotten, call now. In this way, we can have a more balanced approach to library content.

Books, movies, music, and even magazines are all important in our life and environment. They all have a learning process. When you read, you learn; when you watch a movie, you learn; even when you listen to music, you can learn. Whether it's about the past, present, or future, everyone has the right to learn as it's part of being a citizen. Speaking of all this, I believe just because one book, or one movie makes someone uncomfortable, you shouldn't take it away. That's not only taking away from your kid or yourself; it's taking away from everyone else. Just like the book 'Huckleberry Finn', it's a wonderful book. I love it because it's about the old days when they still believed in slavery, and there were still some good - hearted people around. This book to some would be very offensive because of the fact it has the word 'nigger' in it one - hundred and twenty - seven times. In fact, last year at my school, a mother tried to get it taken out. Her son was actually a mixed boy, but thankfully the committee saved it, and it's still here. That's our history, and everyone needs to learn some of it, whether it's offensive or not. As well as movies that can and mostly likely are offensive to people, they still should not have that stuff taken off either. Like I said earlier, that's taking away from everyone else. If you don't want to see it, then don't buy it, or if something that you find inappropriate comes on, just change the channel. History is important, and I don't think people should keep you from your right as a citizen and deprive you from learning what you want to learn or need to learn for the future. Now, the music part I can understand. Some music may be a little inappropriate for younger listeners, so like I said before, change the station or don't buy that album. Don't deprive people of what they want to learn, watch, or listen to. People that feel offended or embarrassed should be ashamed of themselves because that is very selfish and rude. No one should be ashamed of who they are or any movie that describes the old days in the way it actually happened. If they put it in a nice way, then it would all just be a lie. That's why I don't believe in censorship. It should not happen. Any book, movie, magazine, album should be available to those who want it. In conclusion, we should embrace the diversity of information in various media and not let censorship limit our learning.

People often view libraries as excellent sources of knowledge, simply an information - filled place. Many individuals have a fondness for libraries, while some actually dread just hearing the word, 'Library'. To be honest, in my life these days, I only know a few people who use libraries as an information source. But can some information from libraries be offensive to others? To be quite honest, the answer depends on your own opinion. However, yes, I think some information that can be obtained from your local library can be rather disturbing, 'per say'. There are books and information that you wish you'd never picked up in your entire life, but then again, that's the case everywhere.   Now, music, movies, etc. follow a similar pattern. Some people may not agree with what he/she picks out and what they might be interested in. Can it be offensive to people? Of course it can, but people have different views. You may not agree on something, but your friend might think entirely differently from you. Everyone is entitled to their opinion on anything, well, normally. Now, if there are graphic movies or explicit music on the shelf where your little son or daughter can easily grab them, I can see that as a major issue.   Some parents do not want their children listening to that kind of music at such a young age. Even though in America, your child will likely hear or see those things as it's part of life. If a five - year - old can pull a graphic movie or a CD that a parent doesn't want them to see or hear, then I don't necessarily think it should be banned from the library. I believe it should be handled in a well - mannered way and moved to a place not so easily accessible to a five - year - old. These are common arguments people have about many places and similar disagreements.   Yes, I agree some things found in a library can be offensive to some, but my answer remains, 'No', it shouldn't be removed unless it really is extremely offensive. If there is something that offensive in the library and multiple people in the community find it offensive, I would take it up with the people in charge of the local library.

I think that if you feel like certain books, magazines, music, or movies are saying bad things, you should simply refrain from reading the books or magazines, stop listening to the music, and avoid watching the movies. If you find something offensive, just don't look at it because another person might not find it offensive at all. It's a part of life to encounter something offensive, so why let it bother you now?   I think that if people start removing offensive content, they might just take some TV shows off the air because there are a lot of shows out there that are offensive, and some people don't like them, but they don't take those shows off the air. So, why take books, music, movies, and magazines off the shelves? I don't believe that they should do that at all. If I don't like something, I don't look at it, so I don't get mad at what somebody says about my beliefs.   A person might not like the same music you like. I might not like the same music he or she likes, but I don't want to take it off the shelves. People should just stop paying attention to all the things that others say about their beliefs. In conclusion, we should respect different preferences and not try to remove content just because it might be offensive to some.

Libraries should not be able to remove books, movies, and magazines off the shelves just because some kids might be offended. If the town libraries and school libraries took out the cool movies, magazines, and books that most kids love to read and watch, then the kids who like those books, movies, and magazines would not return to the library any more.   For example, I like to listen to hard rock, heavy metal, and rap. But, the people that go to church just like to listen to church music. If you're with your friend one night because he invited you to come to church with him and you pull into the parking lot listening to your rap music, some people may not like it. This doesn't mean that they should take the things people don't like off the shelves in order to satisfy them.   Libraries should have a policy stating that if a child wants to check out a book or magazine or rent a movie, they should have the child's parents sign and return a permission slip stating that their child has their permission to rent this book, magazine, or movie. Libraries should also have an age limit to check out books and magazines. If kids want to rent a movie, then they would have to have a permission slip signed by their parents and returned. This permission slip can be used for all movies.   Libraries should not remove their books, magazines, or movies. They should make a policy to allow older kids to check them out. So, access to library material should be a choice based on proper authorization. In this way, libraries can maintain a diverse collection while also respecting the concerns of parents.

Some people may think that certain books, movies, magazines, or music should be removed from libraries because they may be found offensive. I believe that libraries should not rid their shelves of 'offensive' material.   What really makes something offensive? If someone were to tell me that it looked as if I've lost weight, I would find that offensive. The person wouldn't have meant it that way, though. Although I would have found it slightly rude, another person may have found it to be a nice compliment. With this logic, can one really conclude that anything is truly offensive? By saying something is offensive, you're stating your own opinion. Even if they aren't the same as everyone else's, everyone is entitled to their own opinions; equality is something most people find very important. Because of this, one person's definition of offensive shouldn't be held higher than another's. If we rid libraries of 'offensive' material, that is exactly what you would be doing; you'd be making one person's definition of offensive superior to another person's.   I also believe libraries should not get rid of 'offensive' material because by doing so, they would probably be getting rid of a lot of interesting material. Let's use my religious beliefs for an example. I am a [specific religious group]. Basically, I do not believe in [a certain religious concept]. If someone were to write a book about my religion, I would find it interesting. Some other religious people may find it to be offensive, though. So if a library got rid of that book because someone found it offensive, I wouldn't want to go there as often. When I go to a library, I want to find a book that I'd enjoy reading. If all the material that is found offensive was taken out of the library, would there really be anything left? If so, I doubt many people would find it interesting.   I also believe this because by taking a book off the shelf because you find it offensive, wouldn't you be offending the author? As I said before, everyone is entitled to their own opinions. Because of this, libraries should allow authors to speak their minds. By taking their books off the shelves, you'd be offending them. They took their time and effort to think about and write that book, and for you to offend them by taking it off the shelf, you'd be contradicting the entire purpose of removing it from the shelf.   In conclusion, I believe that nothing can truly be defined as offensive. Also, people should be able to speak their minds.
