Therefore, libraries should not attempt to rid their shelves of 'offensive' material, as it goes against the principles of equality and the free - flow of ideas.

Dear [Recipient's Title]:  Have you ever seen an offensive book on a shelf in a library? Would you want your children influenced by such materials? These are the questions you need to ask yourself about certain materials that appear in libraries.   As a concerned citizen, I am writing to you to reflect my opinion on censorship in libraries. In my own personal experiences, I have come across magazines, books, and music that are offensive. I believe that these materials should not be found in libraries. There are many people who still would want these materials, so my suggestion is that there should be a separate room for the offensive materials. If there was a separate room, we can keep these materials away from young kids.   When I get older and have children, I believe that the library should be a kid - friendly place. In order to make that happen, we need to find a place for these materials or not have them at all. Libraries need to be somewhere where anyone can go: a college kid trying to prepare for a test, a young child wanting to discover new things, or an old man wanting to enjoy the peace and quiet. The distraction of offensive materials is not needed in a library.   Libraries are places to learn and explore the different sources that are inside. For young children, it is the fairytale land where anything is possible and the unimaginable can become true. If there are materials that adults do not want their children to see, they may not be comfortable having their child there. Libraries need to be kid - friendly places so that all ages can enjoy what it has to offer.   As you can see, offensive materials should not be in libraries. All ages should be able to enjoy what a library has to offer, and with some materials, that is not possible. Please consider setting up a separate area for such materials or removing them altogether to ensure the library remains a welcoming place for everyone.  Kind regards,  [Your Name].

They need to remove the bookstores because all students want the library to have a wide variety of books, such as Spanish books or those related to different cultures. With these books, students can learn different languages and engage in various activities. For example, they can read extensively and even rewrite the same book using different words. Also, the music and movies in the library need to be removed as some DVDs contain inappropriate content. Take libraries around the world for instance; people often want to borrow books for free, and they expect libraries to be free - access places. Moreover, libraries should expand their reach globally. Many people think this is a great idea, but some oppose it, arguing that libraries may face difficulties in lending out books, DVDs, magazines, etc. That's why libraries need to make people aware of their lending policies. I believe libraries should interact with the public, showcase their collections, and lend out books and DVDs as people desire. Sometimes, libraries can rent out interesting DVDs that are hard to find elsewhere, like new movies. If the library doesn't have a particular DVD, people can inform the bookstore about it. Reading more is indeed a great idea, and libraries should enhance their appeal to excite people to pick up books and read. In conclusion, libraries need to balance the needs of the public and their management policies to better serve the community.

Censorship is important, especially when it comes to the books, magazines, movies, and music that the vast majority of people are reading, watching, and listening to. Some of the media, such as books and magazines in libraries everywhere, can be highly offensive to certain individuals or convey the wrong message to children and teens. So, should we remove them from the shelves? I personally think no. Most media items on library shelves can be offensive to some people, but a lot of this perception depends on personal opinions. It's the readers who claim that the books and other media in libraries are offensive. The authors, directors, and singers simply create their works, and the judgment and opinions come from the people, fans, and critics. We shouldn't remove everything from library shelves just because it offends some individuals. This ties back to the quote from Katherine Paterson: 'And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' We can't remove everything because everyone's opinions differ. If we censor everything, there will be nothing left. Currently, efforts are being made in censorship, such as rating video - games and movies. Rated R movies are known to be for adult viewers, and the same goes for video games. The music played on the radio is censored to remove foul language. This gives people the choice to watch, listen, or read what they want, and they should be aware beforehand that it might offend them. Although some people feel that the current level of censorship is insufficient, this is about all that can be done to avoid offending others. Removing all media due to people's opinions could potentially upset others or deprive them of the content they want to read or watch. Censorship can be beneficial without removing all media from the shelves and the world. In conclusion, a balanced approach to censorship is necessary to ensure that everyone's interests are considered.

Censorship in Libraries I know, just like everyone else, that you can find almost any reading - related material in the library. There is a wide range of items, from children's books to love stories, people's magazines, newspapers, movies, and music. Everyone is welcome in the library, but the question is, is everyone allowed to access whatever they want? I personally think it's a good idea to have all this material in the library, even though some of it may not be very appropriate. For those who don't have easy access to a library at home, the library might be the first place they think of when they want to learn about something specific. We can't really control what people might find in the library, but I believe it's beneficial to keep such diverse materials in a public place. You can search for information on the internet, but what if the internet doesn't have what you're looking for? I, for one, prefer books to the internet. Anyone can post information on the computer, but in a book, the information is more likely to be true because it has to go through the publication process and be reviewed by someone who wouldn't allow false information to reach the public. If librarians are worried about under - aged kids accessing inappropriate books, they can take measures like placing adult books in a separate adult section and restricting children from entering. They can also put these books on high shelves so that kids won't even notice them. In all the libraries I've visited, there were separate sections for adults and kids. If parents are concerned about what their kids might find, they can keep them at home and create their own home libraries, where they can choose which books and magazines to include. In conclusion, libraries should manage their collections in a way that balances the access for all users while also considering the concerns of different groups.

Should certain materials be removed from our library shelves just because they contain uncensored content? My opinion is a definite no! Now, don't misunderstand me. I'm not someone who always likes reading such materials, but every once in a while, there's a really good book or magazine with uncensored content that I'd like to read. The problem is that I'm often told I can't because it contains something that teenagers supposedly shouldn't see. One of my main questions is why statues from early Roman times are allowed in our history books, even though they are often of naked people, while other materials from our own time are restricted. We live in an era where people are more open - minded, and it doesn't bother most of us to see such things. Yes, some materials may not be suitable for teenagers my age, but I hear offensive things every day when I walk through the halls of my high school. Someone might have an opinion that the material is offensive, but if it's so offensive, why do they even bother complaining or thinking about it? Everyone has the right to their own opinion, but that doesn't mean their opinion is always correct. Different people have different opinions, and we can't say whose opinion is right. Another point I want to make is that we teenagers are learning to make our own decisions. In the near future, we'll be adults and will have to make choices on our own. So, we should be allowed to decide whether we want to read materials with uncensored content. It's our choice, and we should be able to make it without others dictating to us. I still don't understand why it's such a big deal to read uncensored material. Libraries should allow these materials, and we should be trusted to make our own decisions as we are learning to be more adult - like. In conclusion, teenagers should be given the freedom to access a variety of materials in libraries and make their own choices.

The censorship of certain media is a highly controversial topic. Whether a particular piece of material is considered offensive and should be censored is often a matter of opinion rather than a logical decision. It's difficult for most people to step into others' shoes, be open to different viewpoints, or escape the pressure of public opinion. There are many reasons for censorship. Sometimes, media is so intentionally offensive that the creator might even welcome the controversy, or a new and radical view is considered offensive simply because it's different. So, when does someone have the right to take a song off the air or permanently remove a book from a shelf? The first thing to consider is whether something is offensive. There are extreme cases in media where one might wonder, 'What were they thinking when they made that?' For example, a movie that is extremely graphic or violent. However, what one person might consider unnecessary gore in a film could be exactly what another person is excited to see at the cinema - it's all a matter of opinion. Another interesting aspect is that someone might come up with a revolutionary scientific theory and present it in a book or documentary, but certain groups might claim it's offensive. Yet, when we investigate the theory ourselves, we may not be offended at all. This is understandable because people grow up in an environment with its own set of ethics and principles, which they tend to hold onto throughout their lives. If a piece of media goes against someone's deeply - held beliefs, they will naturally be offended. But does that mean it should be censored just because it offends a few groups? The decision of whether to remove something from public access depends on the opinions of the general public. Public opinion is shaped by the current time, trends, ethics, and ongoing problems. When something goes against too many of these factors, people get upset. If most people are upset, the media is likely to disappear. It's bad for business, and libraries are already losing customers as fewer people have the urge to read with all the other entertainment options available. If a library has too many controversial items that put a bad taste in people's mouths, they may stop visiting. So, when it comes to censorship in libraries or anywhere else, it's all about opinions. If the general public doesn't like something, it will stop being available. Some books and media seek controversy, while others accidentally go against certain groups. In conclusion, censorship is a complex issue based on a multitude of opinions, and a balanced approach is needed to ensure that both the public's sensibilities and the freedom of expression are respected.

Isn't it truly shocking that some books, music, movies, and magazines you come across on your library shelf today aren't appropriate for the little ones? I firmly believe that if you have to question whether a child should be listening to or viewing this item, then it shouldn't be in or around a children's section at all. Some content could be offensive not just to children but also to teenagers and adults. Some music may contain words that children shouldn't be exposed to. Music such as hip - hop and rap often contain degrading comments about men and/or women. I wouldn't want my child listening to this type of music or reading any book that talks about it. Music can also be offensive to cultures, religions, sexual orientations, and races. Books or music with such comments should have notes written on them stating what they contain. I was reading a book called 'Adventures of Tom' that I had picked up in the child section. After the first chapter, I wondered who would call this a children's book. The character was using profanity and talking about sex throughout. My child shouldn't be looking for a book on pie and then find out it's not about pie. I once was watching a movie with my two - year - old that we got from the library. The movie was full of inappropriate words, so I had to shut it off. Movies like that should not be on the shelf at the library for my child to view. I now have to worry about what we check out. I also have had a few bad reading experiences. Magazines are a big issue. Some magazines might contain content such as inappropriate pictures and words. Magazines should stay at the grocery store rather than a library that I take my child to. Books, music, movies, and magazines should stay out of the children's section if they are only meant for adult viewing; keep them in the adult section. Any parent would tell you that they don't agree with some of the stuff on your local library shelf today. Offensive content shouldn't be found in the library at all. I know now to keep a better eye on what my child is reading and ensure their exposure to appropriate materials.

All kids have their own style of books. Some people like scary, funny, or romance books, but can we really take that to an offense? We should think about how taking certain books off the shelf would affect more than one person. Some people may be mature enough to read the more 'grown - up' books or magazines. Libraries have all types of styles for different people; you just might have to look a little harder to find the right book for you. I do not agree that certain books and or magazines can be taken as offensive. All libraries have different types of books. For example, an elementary school library will not have grown - up or teenager books, and a middle school will not have little kid books. We also have to think about whether peer pressure affects what books or magazines kids read. For instance, when I was in middle school, my friends were all reading romance books, and I was still reading 'Encyclopedia Brown', and I had to change my reading style to fit in, so that's exactly what I did. Books that have offensive content shouldn't be taken off the shelf. I believe that if there are 'offensive' books in your library, just ignore them; you don't have to get that book. We can't just take the more grown - up books out because some kids don't know what they're supposed to be reading. Libraries have all different styles of books to fit everyone's taste, so just look for that right book that suits you, and don't take all the books that have an offensive style off the shelf. Don't judge a book by its cover, as everyone has different preferences and maturity levels when it comes to reading.

'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right, and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' - @PERSON1 If one thinks about it, books are such a magical escape from everyday life. They can take one anywhere they want to go at any time. Imagine a world where books are a luxury or where they are simply not present at all. I feel as if this would become an all - too - real reality if we censor books. Where would the line be drawn saying a book is unfit to be read or placed into circulation? This would hold the world back since we could not express ourselves through our writing. So much would be left unsaid. I believe the quote stated above is quite true. If we place censorship on one book, everyone has a right to ban other books as well. Just because certain books, movies, and magazines are deemed offensive to some, does not mean they should be banned for all. No one should be withheld from a book due to age, race, gender, or any other factor. If one has ever been prohibited from doing something due to age or size, the feeling is not pleasant. No one necessarily said anything mean or hurtful; it just feels as if restrictions and boundaries were set for no particular reason. I have felt this way multiple times. I remember one time in particular. I went to an amusement park with a group of my cousins and their friends. Since I was the youngest, I was also the shortest. I could not ride many of the rides there due to my size. I knew why those height requirements were set, for my personal safety. This makes sense, but why should one be required to be a certain age to watch a movie or watch a TV show? Honestly, some people are more mature than others and grow up faster. Everyone is different. Everyone has a different personality and different perspective. There is no need to ban a book for everyone when we are all different. One should not be ineligible to read a book or magazine or watch a movie. Not wanting to is totally different from not getting to. The popular book 'To Kill A Mockingbird' was banned at one time in the United States simply for using the 'n - word'. This angers many, especially when one ponders how much slavery as well as the civil rights movement affected and shaped us into who we are today. America is a great nation because of its history. Do we need to have a filter to read? Why should we restrict ourselves and limit our own personal freedoms? If anything is to be banned, I believe it is censorship, as it restricts the free flow of ideas and knowledge.

When one person is given a right to do something, then everyone else should have the right to do the same thing. But every so often, you have someone that abuses their rights to something. I believe that all books, music, movies, magazines, and everything else has a right on a library shelf. And they shouldn't be removed if they are found offensive because in almost every book someone reads, there will be some kind of offense in it. I also believe that all books, music, movies, magazines, and everything else has a purpose to it. And if the purpose is good enough for it to be published, then it should have a good message worth delivering to people, even if it is a little offensive. I've read a few books, watched a few movies, and heard a few songs that were offensive even to me in some way. But, considering that there was more of a purpose to it, and the purpose being a good message, I liked the few movies and songs that most people would say are 'junk'. I don't have a lot of experiences because there isn't a lot that I can say is offensive, but the few songs and movies that are offensive to even me, I believe that there was some kind of good message there. I personally think that no one should have a right to take a book, a piece of music, a magazine, or anything else off a library shelf. Because everything has some kind of purpose to it and has some kind of message in it for each and every person to discover. We should respect the diversity of content in libraries and allow individuals to make their own choices about what to engage with.

Yes, I think they should be removed from the shelves. Some books, music, movies, magazines, etc. are overrated, and young children go to visit the library. They should have a shelf for kids, teenagers, and grown - ups. Everybody should have their own section for their age group. Young kids are already doing things that they shouldn't be doing, like hanging out in the street and hanging with older kids. They watch inappropriate movies when they should be watching something educational. The music they have out these days, children shouldn't listen to it. It has too much cursing and is very violent. More parents need to spend more time with their kids and talk to them about these things. There are certain things teenagers should watch and read too. I don't think they should read about killing or sex. I'd rather their parents talk to them about that and stop hiding things from them. Parents will eventually find out what you're doing behind closed doors; they've been through everything you're doing or trying to do now. So just talk to them and be real about things. I think there should be certain restrictions on magazines in the library. Young children beat themselves up because they don't look like the young actors and actresses in the magazines. They try to rush their life and be somebody they're not meant to be. Young ladies want to have big boobs and butt, and young men want to have big muscles and be buff. In conclusion, I don't think books, music, movies, magazines, etc. should be completely removed from the shelves. There should be a shelf for young kids, teenagers, and adults. The music that is played on the radio these days shouldn't be on there without proper warnings. Magazines shouldn't be out on shelves for children to reach easily. There are certain things teenagers should watch and read, and libraries should be more proactive in providing age - appropriate materials to ensure the healthy development of young readers and viewers.

I honestly think that anything should be allowed in libraries. If you think about it, there is a well - known law called freedom of speech. This fundamental law should be all the reason for someone not to ban something just for what it says. Also, in my opinion, if you find it offensive, you simply don't have to look at it, read it, or listen to it.   I remember walking through the library in town and seeing a large quantity of books neatly arranged on the shelves. None of these books really seemed offensive at first glance. Then again, this library had an upstairs area where the more 'colorful' books were placed. For example, some adult books with explicit content etc. These books were indeed offensive to some, but they should not be banned. Instead, they should only be moved to a more appropriate location.   On a different occasion, I remember walking through the library trying to find a book to help me with an assignment at school and I saw several young kids curiously looking at some adult books and magazines. I believe that these were put here for advertisements, however, they should be advertised in different areas out of the sight of kids and teenagers.   Although it would be nice to see some books and magazines banned, it would be quite difficult to accomplish. I don't think that anything should ever be banned for what it says, shows, or sounds like. Instead, it should be moved from one area to a different area. For example, instead of placing certain materials at low levels where younger people can easily get their hands on them, they should be placed at a higher level or behind the desk. In conclusion, libraries should maintain an open - access policy while also taking steps to protect the sensibilities of different patrons.

Have you ever found a book offensive? Many people can say they have. They might not agree on the central point of the book or certain controversial viewpoints in the text. When this happens, people often stop reading the book and other books in the same category. Certain materials should not be removed from shelves if they are found offending to certain people. Everyone has their own opinions, and if we start removing books based on individual sensitivities, what would be left in the library?   At my public library, citizens of my city can request certain books, movies, music, or magazines to be put on the shelves. We are very fortunate to have this service available because if someone cannot afford certain books, they can always rely on the library. Many people have been very thankful for this democratic system.   If certain people at the library do not want to order certain books requested by citizens because they find them offensive, what would happen? More people would stop going to the library because there would be no materials sparking their interest. Everyone is entitled to their own opinions. Just because one person does not approve of a book does not mean that book should not be offered at the library. There are thousands and thousands of books on display at the public library, and that does not mean you have to read all of them. There are also many different genres of novels, movies, music, and magazines. Everyone has interests in different types. If people all liked the same things, life would surely be boring.   In conclusion, certain materials should not be removed from the shelves of libraries if they are found offending to certain people. Everyone is entitled to their own opinions. If a specific book is requested and one person finds it offending, the book should stay in the library. There are many different genres of books, music, movies, and magazines. Imagine if the library did not have a certain type of novel you enjoyed, you would likely stop going. So, libraries should respect the diverse interests of all patrons.

I think libraries shouldn't remove material from the shelves even though it's offensive. The libraries shouldn't remove offensive material because even though it might be offensive to some people, other people still might want to learn about that topic. For example, the @CAPS1 didn't like the @CAPS2. In some books, there is some offensive stuff about @CAPS2 that was stated by @CAPS4. Some @CAPS2 might take that as offensive, but other people from different races or religions might want to learn about what was said. Just because people read about it doesn't mean all of them are going to agree with it. People might have their own point of view, and no one has the right to tell one person what they can or can't like.   If censorship starts to occur in libraries or other community places, I think people are going to get mad and might have a bigger problem than some people being offended by the material. They might think that they are being told what they can or can't read, listen to, or believe in. That will cause a bigger conflict and get a lot of people furious. I think it will be simpler if libraries keep the materials on the shelves and people who are getting offended by what's there should ignore it. After all, why would they read or listen to something if it only gets them furious? They might be offended by what one person says, but who cares? Not everyone is going to think or agree with what is being said. It's just a person's point of view. Let them be themselves and just stick with what you think of yourself and in your beliefs. Not everyone is right and perfect, so just be yourself. In the end, libraries should uphold the principle of free access to information while allowing individuals to make their own choices.

Materials should not be removed from libraries. It should be left up to a person to decide what they see or view. Books, music, movies, etc., are valuable materials used by everyone, and for some, a library provides a haven where they can get their hands on such things and nowhere else. So, we shouldn't try to take away any of these things from anybody.   One reason why certain materials should not be removed from library shelves is that there will always be some subjects and materials that a great many people will argue shouldn't be seen, and there will always be other people who feel differently. And if we allow them to be taken away, you will only be taking away a person's own choice, which is something we all should strive not to do. Also, just who would be left to decide what material should be removed and what material shouldn't? Is there really one person who could make such a choice for everyone? Also, there is no way everyone could agree on what material should be removed, so by trying, you would just be providing something more for everyone to argue about. I believe that if not everyone can be satisfied, then why bother.   Another reason why in libraries certain materials shouldn't be removed is that by removing certain materials, you would be interfering with education. Books, movies, and other such things are used for learning, even whether people realize it or not, and the more opportunities a person has to learn, the better. And who are we to decide what a person decides to educate themselves about? There has, in fact, been times in history when people in charge have wrongly decided that the public should not be educated or know about certain things, and it was wrong then and it would be even more wrong now in our modern society. A society that is based on learning and knowledge, a society that in this situation should not hinder a person's ability to learn.   Also, I realize some people @MONTH1 argue that for young children, some materials are better left unviewed, but that is where parents come in. It's their responsibility to decide what their children read or see and not anyone else's. And so there is no reason why anyone should interfere with a parent's choice as long as it is in agreement with the law.   These are the reasons why I think libraries shouldn't be allowed to decide what materials and subjects are put on their shelves. For some decisions, no one can make them to satisfy everyone and to be in the right. Therefore, it is better that such things are left up to the person themselves. In conclusion, libraries should remain a place of free - access and open - minded learning.

I do not believe that certain materials such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed, unless if it has nudity or a large amount of cussing in the books. Because some books and movies are inappropriate to show little kids. But I think we should have anything that teaches you something in the library. Plus, people have to do reports and homework on some books, and if it's about something with a little cussing and is somewhat graphic, it should be okay. I think if the library has these kinds of books, movies, music, and magazines, they should have a policy where you can access them if you are a certain age or have a note from a teacher stating that you need that book, or some kind of rule that lets you choose any kind of book but with permission.   The library's would have more people going if they had more books and better - quality ones. Because most of the things that people like are in the books or movies that the library won't have. So it just depends on the situation. There is a lot of offensive things out there, but it doesn't mean you can keep it away from people. They will find out anyways sooner or later. I think it's unnecessary for the libraries to be overly restrictive. I always hate when I try to get something and then find out you have to be @NUM1 or older or have an adult with you. Plus, some people don't have computers or internet access, so they can't look up things easily. They have to drive down to the library to look something up, and if you are lucky, they might have the thing you are looking for at the library, but if they don't, that's disappointing. So, in my view, libraries should balance the need to protect younger patrons while still providing a wide range of educational and interesting materials. In conclusion, libraries should adopt a reasonable approach to handling potentially offensive materials to serve all patrons effectively.

People believe that censorship is important in libraries. They firmly believe that things should not be released if they have a bad subject matter. They strongly feel that it is sending a very bad message to children and teaching them horrible things to do and say. I disagree with them on this, and these are the reasons why. I feel that books, music, movies, and magazines shouldn't be taken off the shelf if they have cuss words inside. I genuinely feel that they should continue to be sold even if they have bad words inside. I feel this way because there are a lot of truly horrible things in this world. Children have to learn that, and I feel like cussing or anything of that subject matter isn't that big of a deal. There is so much more to worry about than a couple of bad words children read and listen to. I listen to music that has cuss words on the inside, and I also read books with bad words, and it doesn't influence me in any kind of way. So, we shouldn't always try to control everyone. We should just let these items be on the shelves and let them or their parents decide if it's inappropriate or not. In conclusion, I feel again that they should be on the shelves, and people should be allowed to listen/read whatever they want to. If it doesn't harm anyone or themselves, then let it go on and happen. Let them do what they want to.

No, I do not believe certain materials should be removed from the shelves in libraries if they are found offensive. You have the clear right to either read what you see or keep moving and read what you want to. Certain books, movies, magazines, etc., shouldn't be removed just because someone else doesn't like it. If someone of a certain belief sees something offensive to them or their religion, then they have a simple option to not read or look at it. Something that someone might find offensive might be really interesting to someone else or they might have to do a report or project on it. There's absolutely no need to discriminate against a book or movie just because a certain religion group or someone as an individual doesn't approve of it. It's a public library that has materials on display for the public! Any and everybody can come and read any and everything they please. A library is open to the public, which means people of different races, beliefs, religions, etc., are going to come through, and it's a real possibility that they're going to see something offensive or that they don't like. They have the option of either picking it up and reading it or the option of not paying it any attention and ignoring it. I do not think that books should be taken off shelves just because it's offensive or because others don't like it. If everyone took the books, music, and movies off the shelves that they didn't like, then all that would be left would be completely empty bookshelves. There are people in the world who might be offended by various types of literature, movies, music, or etcetera. I truly understand this, but I don't think they should be banned just because someone else doesn't agree with it. Some people don't like some media because it goes against their beliefs. If this is the case, then just simply ignore it. If you don't like a certain type of music, don't listen to it. Maybe it is a movie you're not particularly fond of, then don't watch it. In conclusion, people should learn to give some things a chance. They should also not get rid of something just because they themselves aren't fond of it or find it offensive. That said, I don't believe that certain media should be banned. We should respect the diversity of tastes and opinions and allow a wide range of media to be available for people to choose from.

For many students, it is extremely hard to compose essays in a public school's library. Acquiring the necessary information in such a setting is comparable to painstakingly finding a needle in a haystack. This predicament is not due to the lack of funding or even the quality of teachers and staff. No, neither of these problems is the cause behind many students' inability to compose thought - provoking essays and in - depth analysis over a myriad of topics. This is primarily due to the extreme levels of censorship that are being imposed on libraries and schools in general. Many of the relevant topics and materials needed to truly understand our constantly changing world are being removed from the reach of those who will go on to lead this new world. Some prime examples of this tyranny on knowledge are the removal of books such as @PERSON1, @PERSON2, the @CAPS1, and many other classical works. Each of these, according to many parents, has good reason to be removed from our libraries. @PERSON1 promotes discrimination and racial supremacy, along with being written by what @CAPS3 has pegged as one of the humanity's most vile of creatures. @PERSON2 uses racial slurs that are not appropriate to be in the hands of our young children. The @CAPS1 violates the separation of church and state. Many other classical works reference racism, drugs, murder, sex, and use rampant profanity. All of these are valid reasons as to why a parent might advocate for there to be censorship of our libraries. Many of the books that have been recommended to be removed show us an unfiltered view of a time period from a point of view that did not belong to the 'victor' of the social battle. As we know, 'history is written by the victors.' Although it is good that the @CAPS5 won the @CAPS6 @CAPS7 and helped abolish slavery, it is still important to realize that we still cannot remove the viewpoint from our centers of knowledge. To forget is to remember at another time. That time is when we repeat the same mistakes again. To censor our libraries is to cripple our children from the knowledge they need to fully understand our shadowed and fragmented world. Just because we try and close our eyes to the realities of the world does not mean that they don't exist. It is far better to see and understand than to enter the world blind and dumb.

Should offensive material be removed from the library? I firmly think no, and there are numerous reasons as to why I disagree with this idea. Many books, movies, and magazines are not meant to offend people; rather, they are just a means for the author to let the reader know how they feel. I believe that the books, movies, magazines, etc., should stay on the shelf because if they are removed, what are we left with? It seems like all that would remain would be the dictionary. I think that when Katherine Paterson said, 'Children or any other children have taken off the shelf' that she was making a big mistake. So, what seems to be offensive to people? Topics such as gossip and politics are a gold mine for authors in the @DATE1. Yet, people find these topics to be offensive, probably due to that person's background. If someone finds a read to be offensive, then they should simply stop reading, and that should be it. Instead, people decide to go on a rampage against that magazine or whatever they read and have it banned for life from others to read. Readers have the choice to read whatever they want, and if they disagree with that subject, they should just move on with their lives. At the library I attend, many people of different shapes and sizes walk through the door every day. Many of them like a different subject than the others, so it's common to find everybody reading about a different topic. Sure, someone here and there does not agree with an author, but they never decide to go crazy about it. Instead, they just go pick a different read to enjoy for themselves. People read what they want to so they can enjoy it, not to bash the author for his writing. In my own reads, I have found at times stuff I disagree with. Instead of going off the deep end and getting all excited about it, I choose to think about where the author is coming from and try to understand his side. On the other hand, some movies are meant to be for one type of audience when instead another audience sees the material. This still should not get movies or whatever the material is banned from the library. When on the box it says rated for teenagers and up, that means it is not for a four - year - old to watch, and their parents should not get mad at them for it. If people followed what the box says and listened to the guidelines, then there would be no problem. I disagree with @PERSON2 when she said that some books, magazines, movies, etc., should be removed from the library. People have the right to read anything and to see anything they want, and if they disagree, well, they should just deal with it. In my own experience, I have not found there to be a problem in my community library with people wanting content removed. Once people start following guidelines and reading the boxes and still disagree, then maybe we will have something to worry about. But until then, we should keep our nation's libraries the way they are today.

There are big debates today over whether or not certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves of libraries if they are found offensive. Plenty of arguments are made from maybe somebody's own experience, careful observations, and/or in - depth reading. I have read plenty of people's concerns regarding this issue, and there are some valid points to be made from both sides of the story. No matter what your opinion on this issue is, there will always be someone who opposes it. You see censorship of offensive language on television, but here is my take on whether or not censorship should take an effect on books, music, movies, magazines, etc. The first point that I would like to make about censorship is that people all across the world will inevitably come in contact with something that they might have thought to be offensive. When kids are old enough to understand what other people are talking about, they will come in contact with things that they take offense at some point in life. I know from my own personal experience that you will see things that people think should be censored. Although I come from a religious family who does not like to offend anyone, I am old enough to realize that not everything in life is going to work out your way all the time. When you honestly think about it, you cannot censor out things that you hear in person, so why censor things in certain materials? The second point I would like to make about censorship is that no matter how much you try to censor certain materials, people will still find a way to take things offensive. There are certain things in life that you cannot control, and being insulted or offended is one of them. Even the most popular man or woman on the planet has been offended at least once or twice. It isn't about trying to censor every little thing that might be offensive to some people. Maybe it is about the people learning to deal with a little criticism. 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf---that work I abhor---then you also have exactly the same right, and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This is a quote from Katherine Paterson that makes a big statement. Almost every well - written book that you will find on the shelf has something that should be censored. What would those books be without those statements? To conclude this debate on censorship, plenty of arguments have been made about the views of censorship. Many observations, personal experiences, and/or readings have been done by many different people. Truth is, there will always be people who disagree on this subject, but that is just the way things are. We might never know who is actually right or wrong about this topic. We do know though, that judging from the previous points above, it is very unlikely that certain materials will be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive.

Well, if items are banned from being seen or read, then there will be no creativity in the world. Everyone will be forced to think the same thoughts if they can't learn about other thoughts that are portrayed to be offensive. No one can read about a topic that they are interested in if it is banned. This will cease creative thinking by not allowing people to think differently. In the process of deciding what books are offensive and which are not offensive, all books will eventually be eliminated. Certain topics aren't liked by everyone, and, as Katherine Paterson says, '...if I have the right to remove that book... so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Paterson is exactly right too; if one person has the right to remove a book, so does everyone, and this will cause everyone to take off that book that they dislike so much. Also, everyone likes different kinds of books and different topics, and this will cause less self - expression because if someone doesn't like books about @CAPS1 @CAPS2 @CAPS3 because they think it is offensive to @CAPS4, then there will be no books about @CAPS1 @CAPS2 @CAPS3 on the shelves for anyone to learn about it. Everyone will turn out to be the same if they can't express themselves or their opinions. If a certain topic is banned for being discovered as an offensive topic, then this will result in the thought being banned. If you can't read or watch a topic, you shouldn't be able to think or talk of the topic either because you will offend someone. Also, if people can pick what books can be in a library, that will eventually be transferred over into other areas, such as clothing, food, thoughts, etc. Eventually, everyone will be wearing the same clothes, eating the same food, and thinking the same thoughts. Yes, I do agree that some novels are not age - appropriate for young children, but that doesn't mean that they should be removed. I think that if people are so worried about their children reading these books, they should either go into the library with their child, closely guiding them, or simply give the child a certain area that they are allowed to pick a book from.  Another way of avoiding these writings getting into the wrong hands is to section off the more aggressive and adulterated books to a specific spot in the library and allow only age - appropriate people inside. An age restriction of thirteen years and up would be a responsible decision. An age younger could be inappropriate for them, but any older and it could keep them from learning and expanding their mind to its full potential.  The point of this writing is to show that removing these books and novels from the libraries is not going to help anything. If anything, it could hurt us by not allowing our minds to reach newer and higher limits by learning and understanding the complexity of these novels. Sectioning off these novels in an age - appropriate area or having parental discretion will help to keep the age correct for the books that they get. In conclusion, a balanced approach that respects both the value of diverse literature and the need for age - appropriate access is the best way to handle this issue in libraries.

In our libraries, there are a large number of books that are extremely helpful. There are also a wide variety of magazines, music, and movies. A lot of the movies are adult movies, but most libraries do have a dedicated kid section. Most of the books, magazines, and movies are easily reachable by little children. I have been to the library as a child and vividly remember seeing all the books there.  When I went to the library as a kid, I usually went with my parents. We would go there and mainly head straight to the kids section. I can also clearly remember going with my grandparents. I would either read books or put a puzzle together or engage in some other activity. I cannot recall a single time when I went to the library and saw something that was offensive.  I've never been to the library and seen anything that seems offensive to me. I'm sure that there is a book or a movie somewhere in every library that is offensive, but to give you an example of a personal experience is something that I cannot do. If the libraries do have books that are offensive, they do a really good job of hiding them from me and other kids. I haven't heard anything about people finding these kinds of offensive books in other books or magazines that I read.  I tend to not read very many books about the world. I have a strong preference for reading biographies about sports players and similar types of books. Whenever I read magazines, usually they are about sports or cars, so I don't read much about offensive things that might be going on, if they are.  If the libraries have offensive books, but no kids or people who shouldn't be reading them come across them, then the library doesn't need to remove them from the shelves. Some adults come into the library looking for one of these books, so then they can ask and find them. So, in my opinion, I think that the libraries shouldn't have to remove these books from the shelves. In conclusion, as long as proper measures are in place to prevent inappropriate access, there's no need to remove potentially offensive materials from libraries.

We see them. We read them. We gossip about them. Books that are found with inappropriate language, pages with the word 'sex' on them, disturbing thoughts and ideas, cuss words, it's all there, but yet they are still in our libraries. My views on censorship is that, yes, our libraries should be more modest and not have books on the shelves with these things in them. The books in libraries across the country that have profane ideas in them are one of the direct faults in our teenagers today.  In my personal experience with this, I have come across books that have had inappropriate language in them. I have also read books assigned to me at school that have had descriptions of sex and bad language in them as a third - grader. As a young boy, I would go home to my parents and show them the content of the book and how despicable it was. I know that there are so many things that could offend people. Racism, sex, cussing, rules, religion, but you need to eliminate the main things. It is impossible to please everyone. These ideas in magazines, books, in movies, and even in music have changed the world upside down. Even when I was young, we were taught no cussing aloud, and yet you see this all the time in books.  In America, of course, we have the freedom to do what we want. Authors have the right to put profane language in their books, and even dirty ideas. However, libraries are not forced to keep this content in their libraries across the globe. I believe that we should keep the future of America in the back of our minds, that if we teach them this material, they are going to grow up in the world with no morals at all, and the world will become worse than it already is.  In the quote by Katherine Paterson, I believe that she has made a strong point. I believe that if we take these certain books, magazines, movies, songs, and internet sites off the computers, and out of libraries and schools, teenagers wouldn't be traveling down the road they are.  In conclusion, while we need to balance the freedom of expression with the need to protect the younger generation, it's clear that a more cautious approach to the content in libraries is necessary. We should strive to create an environment that nurtures good morals and values in our youth, and carefully curating library materials is an important step in that direction.

Offensive literature, sexual content, disagreeable topics. Books all have those things to someone somewhere. It would be impossible to get rid of all of the books that offended everyone and still have books left. There are many reasons why censorship is pointless and wrong. Censorship only causes curiosity. Censoring books could take away from learning. The real world is not censored so books should not be either.  Censorship only causes curiosity. Young kids every day are constantly being told what to do and what not to do. Many people know that children are most likely to want to do exactly the opposite of what they are told to do. Being censored from things makes people want to rebel and learn the truth. No one likes to be told what they can and cannot do. The same goes for being told what you can and cannot read. No one wants the truth cut out of their reading materials.  Censoring books could take away from learning. In school, children are required to read many different books in their English classes. Some books, depending on the teacher, have what some would consider offensive language and topics. What some people do not understand is that reading those things are a part of life. Reading foul language would not be any more offensive than if someone was to use the same foul language in front of you in real life. In fact, the real - life situation would seem to be more offensive. If we are censored from these things, how will we learn that they exist.  The real world is not censored so books should not be either. You can't go walking down the street and expect a loud beep to randomly play over someone's foul banter every time they curse. When someone says something offensive in the real world, you have to learn to deal with it appropriately and maturely. We can't cut out people's offensive banter in real life, so why should we do it in our reading material. Has no one ever heard of freedom of speech? That amendment was created for a reason, to let Americans speak their beliefs.  Everywhere we look today, things are being censored and 'cleaned up' to make others happy who might be offended by whatever it is they are censoring. Sometimes it is appropriate for offensive language or topics to be written about. People need to be able to speak their minds and beliefs. But people also need to be able to have constructive criticism and be mature about offensive writing. Everyone will be offended in one way or another some time in their life by something they will read or already have read. It is just life. In conclusion, we should embrace the diversity of literature and the real - world experiences it can reflect, rather than resorting to unnecessary censorship.

Books are important in the life of human beings whether they are for studies, entertainment, or any other use. On the other hand, there are some books that are offensive to readers. If certain books are offensive, should you stay away from that type of book or get rid of the book altogether? With this being said, should certain material be removed from shelves if they are offensive? Some reasons against this are you are taught to stay away from bad things, some people have different views of 'bad', and even if they are offensive they do not need to be removed.  Some materials are offensive to some people but not to others. This is the case in anything, for example, movies, books, and daily life. Some people might think the type of words used in a book make it bad, but to others, that is what makes the book interesting. For example, to show the full amount of hatred for a character, you have to use some offensive words. Another example is describing how horrible a person was killed; it is not enough to say he got stabbed and beaten, you have to describe just how brutal it was to satisfy some readers.  Another reason why books should not be removed is that people are taught when to tell that something is offensive. If a reader discovers a book is offensive, they should know to stop reading instead of finishing the book then complaining about offensive material. Also, if a person rents a movie and they know they aren't allowed to get an adult - rated movie, then they should get another movie. People should know not to get a book, read about the offensive stuff without stopping, and then go complain. If a person was concerned about a certain material, they could ask people or go online to see if it is offensive or not.  Even if a certain material is offensive, it should not be removed. That is only the opinion of somebody. If the book was needed by somebody, they would not be able to get it because it was removed. If material were removed because someone said it was offensive, then there would never be any more books. For the reason that anyone can be offended, so they might just say it was worse than it actually was because they are mad.  For those reasons, materials should not be removed. What if everybody started saying things were offensive? There would not be any more books. People should not have the complete say in the removal of books. Otherwise, people would complain just out of spite towards certain people's material. So, do you believe that certain materials should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? In conclusion, a consensus - based and rational approach is needed to handle potentially offensive library materials, rather than hasty removal based on individual opinions.

Every parent has their own distinct opinion upon controversial topics like this. They often deliberate on what is best for their children's well - being. But even if you were to painstakingly censor out books, movies, music, etc., your child would still manage to find that book or movie on the vast expanse of the internet, completely uncensored. Yes, parents firmly believe that having things censored will safeguard their children from inappropriate content. However, children today have much more advanced technology at their fingertips and much easier access to uncensored music. As each day goes by, the minds of children become more and more curious as to what the world has to offer. The more parents try to keep their children away from certain aspects of life, the higher the chance is that their child might sneak out or turn out to be different from the person the parents had envisioned. Every person is an individual with their own thoughts and desires. I personally would say to just leave the books, music, movies, etc. on the shelves of libraries. Children will find out about these things anyways, whether it is from their friends or through the media. It's not to say that your child will become corrupt if listening to such music, but I believe that at a certain age, parents should have in - depth talks with their children about the things happening in the world. After all, children are not going to be children forever, and you will not be able to control them indefinitely. Everybody was a child at one point in time, and I am pretty sure that most parents very much disliked it when their own parents would keep them away from things they wanted to do or see. But life is not always fair, and these are just one person's opinions. Either way, if you decide to take all the music and censor it out or do the same to all the books and movies, etc., there will still be unhappy adults and unhappy parents. No matter what happens, odds are that children will find their way around these restrictions. It never fails. There will always be some way your child can get around you, always going to be some way your kids will get past your rules. Just think about it, if they disobey you once, they will most likely do it again. It is in a child's nature. So like I said before, every parent and every person has their own opinion upon topics like such. Me personally, I say just leave it and let the parents of these children handle it the way they would like to, because you can not please everybody.

Should books, music and movies be removed from shelves if they are found offensive? Books, music and movies have a specific view set aside for the reader or viewer at hand. They are created with a certain intention and message. If someone has a different view of the text, then they should not even be reading or viewing them. But to have great books be taken off of the shelves because they represent different views to someone else is truly unreasonable. People should give these things a fair chance because sometimes the non - original things just don't work. To have movies banned from the public because they are offensive is merely a way to control what we see and what we hear. Books, music and movies should not be taken from shelves for the fact that they teach us a valuable lesson about life without it really happening to someone. Books are a remarkable way that people can express themselves without actually going out and causing harm to someone or something. Poetry, for example, gives the reader a profound feeling of what the writer was experiencing when it was produced. Books that have political or social views on something should not be discriminated against because someone does not like the side that they chose or the way that the author presents it to the people. In novels, just because someone uses profanity does not mean that their message is any less clear. Their message might be that profanity is used too often or that the next generation below them might take a turn for the worst, but it is not used to harm. Music is a powerful way that people can express their emotions without taking it out on the people that have hurt them or the people that they have hurt themselves. When someone uses profanity in a song, it is not specifically aimed at one person; it is used to convey how bad they feel about what has happened to them, that they need something strong to really show how they feel. Many people who hear these lyrics might believe that the person is telling them that that really is how they feel when it's just a verse. Music should not be taken away because it is just words, and they should not hurt someone, especially when it is only a way to express. In movies, you see someone get shot, brutally murdered or attacked, and it's already a horrible thing because someone died or because someone did not have a fair life. This violence shown on the screens in homes, movie theaters and schools is shown to teach people what real - world dangers are out there; they are not shown to teach people other ways to severely injure another person, although that is how some people perceive them. Movies are about taking an idea and showing the world your vision; to show the world that this is what you are thinking and that this is how you feel about something. To have this all taken away shows that the generations before us are scared of what it is that we can do when we are united or what we can be if we stand alone and say that we don't like something. Books, music and movies that are all based on something real should not be banned just because they show individuality; just because they have the decency to show us the truth amidst all the lies told to us by a higher authority. These people most likely believe that there is a thing as a perfect life when there is not one. So when people show the way things are, they get scared that their ideas of a perfect thing are ruined by those who know the truth. The censorship of only things that are truly vile should be censored, not the things that have nothing to do with the way that the communities are today.

I do not believe that certain materials such as books, music, magazines, etc. should be removed from the shelves, whether in libraries or any other place. I believe that if someone wants to know more information about something, the library or other relevant institutions should be able to provide it for them. Imagine if the libraries and other similar places started putting these materials away. Many people wouldn't bother to go there. In my eyes, the library is a place that shows us where we have been, what we have been through, and the things we have accomplished. Could you imagine walking around a library and seeing nothing about your past? No, I couldn't. Even though things might seem offensive in one person's eyes, it could be the history of another. Many people these days rely on the usage of magazines, books, and music to get information. I believe that everyone has a right to know what has happened in their past to understand how they got to their future. So taking away information that might seem offensive to someone else isn't fair. I believe that we should keep all information in libraries, museums, art shows because everything has its own history behind it. And if we just cover it up, we will never know. I myself would rather want to know than not to ever have known. After all, knowledge, no matter how uncomfortable it might be, is an essential part of our growth and understanding of the world.

I believe that certain materials such as books, movies, magazines, etc. should be removed from public libraries. Consider this: what if a young, innocent child were to stumble across an inappropriate magazine? They would have the disturbing images stuck in their heads, and it could potentially lead to unlawful decisions in the future. There are many books and movies that aren't appropriate for most young - aged children. I think that they should either be placed more appropriately or removed completely. Some people will take certain materials to be more offensive than others, but if read or watched, the person might get angry or start to have bad thoughts. Personally, I think that most fictional books are mainly for entertainment. They do not, for the most part, display actual happenings or thoughts. If someone reads them as offensive, they might just be taking it the wrong way. Most libraries have areas sectioned off for adults only, but these areas aren't adequately monitored. So how would anyone know if a child was in this restricted area where they shouldn't be viewing this material? They wouldn't have the slightest clue. I think that in today's society, most children already know about sexual graphics and such, so why limit them to what they already know about? There are a lot of television shows and movies in the world that are much more graphic than books and magazines. Shouldn't they be banned too? The world is exposed to offensive material every day. We just get used to all of it and do not take it the wrong way. But young children don't know better, so there is no guarantee that they won't take ideas from inappropriate viewings and use them. So maybe things do need to be taken off shelves to protect the innocent minds of children.

Offensive materials in libraries. When entering a library, you know you are going to find something interesting to read, listen to, or even watch. Most people use libraries to find information on a certain topic, and some of these topics are not always appropriate for certain age groups. I do believe that materials on any subject should reflect how people see the world now. Most kids go to the library and look to find books that interest them. Sometimes, they come across books about stuff they shouldn't know about yet. Libraries should be allowed to have anything on their shelves that they please, but it should be restricted to certain age groups. Suppose you were a little kid and you wanted to look up information on racing. You might have passed by many books about racism. As a little kid, you might not know what that is, but all you have to do is pick up and read. That kid just went from reading about NASCAR to reading about racism and different races. I believe that books should be kept in order of age. When a teenager goes into the library to look up a book, they should be able to go to a section for teens and get a book on their topic. In most libraries, there are topics such as sex, killing, and violent matters. Kids should not be allowed to view that detail until they are ready for it. If I am at the library, I will always look for a book that interests me. My skills on choosing books for myself have changed since I was 8 or 9. Now that I'm older and like to read, I read more books about action and mystery. I was at our hometown library and saw a 10 - year - old kid looking at books about pregnancy and was shocked to see what he was reading after he put the book down. That same day, I came across a younger kid approaching his father with a book about sex and one about killing. When I saw this, I was surprised to see what was happening. I do believe that libraries should be able to showcase what they have, but in certain age sections. Kids visit the library all the time and are looking for books to strike their interest. They will always find something different that they should not be exposed to. Libraries would have trouble containing what kids read, so they should expose all the different topics in an age - appropriate way. When you're little and reading about these topics, you will then be more informed when you're just a little older. Next time when you visit the library, check and see what kids in your local town are talking and reading about. You will be surprised when a child approaches his parents with a book about sex. I think that all libraries should expose what they want as long as they want to ensure knowledge to everyone in an appropriate and safe manner.

I don't think nothing should be taking off the shelves at the libraries. If a book, magazine, or other educational material can offer valuable knowledge and lessons to your child in a certain way, it should stay. Children can learn a great deal from the diverse collection of books at the libraries. These books cover a wide range of topics, from history and science to literature and art. If you need help or answers about certain things, you can always find what you are looking for in a library. They house an extensive repository of information, and they have all the answers you might seek. You can not get everything off the internet; some in - depth and reliable information you have to look up by opening a book. As I was growing up, I was able to get what I needed done for my school projects and studies at the library. It was a place of discovery and learning. There are so many things at the libraries that are educational. You just have to know what you are looking for and take the time to explore. For some of these adults, if you were having a hard time looking for what you needed at the library, it doesn't mean the same for your child. Sometimes your children have a better time understanding and grasping concepts than you did at their age. Parents, please don't take away the good things out of the libraries that could really help your child at times. If it was not helpful, they would have never put it in the library from the start. There are things that you would be better off finding in a book because not everything is on the internet. So many scientists found their information in a book because it's easier to trust and reference. You learn so many good things from a library. The books and materials in a library help you with so much research. Taking materials out of a library, I would have to disagree. Libraries are a valuable resource for everyone, and we should preserve their collections.

Certain materials, such as books, music, movies, or magazines, do not need to be removed from the shelves in libraries if they are found offensive. There are multiple compelling reasons to back up this statement, including an accurate and thought - provoking quote from author Katherine Paterson. People build their character through their reactions to how others treat them. For example, in life, somebody might offend another person, but that does not mean the offender is going to disappear after doing so. How does this relate to libraries, you might ask? Books and movies do not need to be taken off of shelves in libraries if they are found offensive because there are a lot of things in the real world that are offensive. It is your choice in what you want to read, listen to, or watch. Just because you may have the option of checking out something you do not think is appropriate or is offensive, does not mean you have to check it out. Some people actually enjoy reading or watching things that are offensive as it challenges their perspectives. You may be wanting to argue, 'But I don't want my children being exposed to such offensive materials.' That is why most public libraries are split into children and adult sections. If you happen to come across an offensive book in the children's section, then do not let your child check that out. It is as simple as that. Trying to take the book off the shelf or complaining about it would only take up more time and energy. The quote, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everybody else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us', by Katherine Paterson, is a perfect example to conclude the reasons why books should not be taken off the shelf. She is saying that if one person is allowed to remove a book, then anybody else would be able to have that ability as well. Therefore, a book that may not offend you at all could be taken off the shelf because somebody else does not approve of it. Eventually, there would be no books left. In conclusion, if there are books, music, movies, or magazines that offend you, simply do not check them out. You do not need to get rid of them because somebody else may want to check them out. We should respect the diversity of opinions and the freedom of choice in libraries.

No, I do not think that books and other materials should be taken off the shelves of a library if someone thinks it's offensive. Everyone has a different opinion on what books they like to read. Tastes in literature vary widely, from adventure and romance to mystery and science - fiction. I think that if you don't like the book and think it's offensive, that you shouldn't get the book and just leave it there because someone else might like that book and want to read it. Not everyone likes the same books, but every book in a library is there for a reason. The library screens all of the books that they get in and wouldn't buy something if no one asked for it or if it wasn't a good book to have. They consider the interests and needs of their patrons. I think that everyone has a right to read what they like to read and that no one should have the right to take books off of shelves in a library because what if someone is looking for that book and the library is the only place that has it. Then where would people spend their time reading and enjoying the books that they have an interest in? If everyone could just pull a book off a shelf when they thought it was offensive, there wouldn't be any books left on the shelves and no one would have books to read. I also think that if you don't like the selection of books on the shelf, that you shouldn't be looking in that section. Go to another part of the library and look at the types of books that you like to read. There's something for everyone in a library, whether it's classic literature, modern best - sellers, or specialized research materials. This is why I think it's not a good idea to be able to take books off of shelves. No one would have any books that they like to read if everyone did that when they saw something 'offensive'. Libraries are meant to be a place of open access and diverse reading options.

I think that there are some books out there that really do need to be taken off the library shelves and just be put in book stores for one's own usage. These might be books with extremely explicit content that is not suitable for a general library environment. Then there are other books that people just need to be more mature about, like history books talking about wars, slavery, and books with curse words in them. These books are important for understanding the past and different aspects of society. School libraries, such as the elementary and high school libraries, should have books according to their age groups. If the librarian knows the book is not something a young kid should read, then they shouldn't let them check it out. The music, magazines, and movies should also be age - appropriate for the age groups. Little children do not need to hear cuss words every five seconds in a song. It can have a negative impact on their language development and values. Movies should be age - appropriate too. That's why libraries have sections for babies, toddlers, pre - teens, teens, and adults. So if you're really concerned that your child or even just yourself are going to find an offensive book or one that's not good for the age group, then stay in your own section. Let's say you're a teen and there's a book that is not right for you to read and is for more older people. Then you should be able to tell a librarian that is there and maybe she can just move it out of that section. Every person feels differently about what's offensive and not offensive though. So libraries shouldn't have to take out every book that offends one person because it's not fair to the rest of the people. Besides, no one's making you check out that book. We should respect the library's role in providing a balanced and diverse collection for all patrons.

They can go ahead and complain that they don't want it there. But if the library has it, the library should be able to keep it there whether or not people don't want it there. So if a person does not want a certain thing on the shelves, they should not be able to by themselves take it from the shelves because what if another person wants to see the movie but they can't because a parent took it from the shelf because they did not want their kid being exposed to it. This way, the library can maintain its role as a public and inclusive resource.
