Do people have the right to limit freedom? Do people have the right to limit imagination? Do people have the right to limit self - expression? Many individuals in today's world seem to think so. Book censorship is a significant and widespread concern in the world today. Whether books deemed 'offensive' should be removed from libraries or not is a pressing and serious issue. Censoring books not only restricts self - expression but also curtails knowledge and violates our constitutional right of free speech. I firmly believe people should not be able to censor books. Censoring a book is akin to putting a strict limit on human imagination. Throughout our lives, we are constantly urged to think outside of the box. As kids, we are taught that being unique and different is a virtue. We internalize these teachings, yet when writers express themselves in books, the very same people who encouraged out - of - the - box thinking want to censor their thoughts. By censoring books, we are essentially telling the world that imagination is a negative trait. Many people wish to censor books to shield their children from 'offensive' material. They assume that by removing books they consider 'offensive' from libraries, they can protect their children from the harsh realities of the world. This is a fallacy. People may attempt to censor books, but no one can censor life. Children will learn 'offensive' things with or without books. Book censorship limits knowledge. At the time it was written, The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn was a very scandalous book. Due to the language this book used, many people regarded it as trash and wanted it to be censored. Today, The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn is a famous and classic book. In fact, I was required to read it for school. Regardless of the language, it offers a glimpse into a part of American history. And to think, if people back then had removed it from the libraries, I most likely would never have read this book and gained the knowledge from it. It is our constitutional right to write and read the books we choose. America was founded on the principle of freedom. Under the constitution, we are guaranteed freedom of speech. By taking books out of libraries, we are undermining our freedom of speech. No one should be allowed to tell you that you can't read a book you desire to read. No one should be allowed to tell you that you can't write a book as you wish. If we start censoring books, writers will be compelled to censor their personal thoughts, which will severely limit their freedom of speech. If freedom of speech is restricted, what other freedoms will be compromised in the years to come? Book censorship and censorship in general are not beneficial; all they do is impose limitations. If we start censoring books, we are sending a message to our children that being different is bad. If freedom of speech is limited, we must ask ourselves how long it will be until our other rights are also restricted. Where will this downward spiral end? Before removing even the first book from the shelf, we need to seriously ask ourselves if we have the right to limit freedom.

In conclusion, we should respect the diversity of creative works and avoid unnecessary censorship.

What is censorship? Censorship can be described as limitations or restrictions, and it can also be misconstrued as common courtesy. The real question is what exactly are we limiting? Censorship is not something to support. Censoring a book is like having a chocolate cake without the chocolate; it takes away the value and enjoyment from education. Though many individuals disapprove, libraries shouldn't censor their books, movies, or music because of that. Some people find that 'To Kill a Mockingbird' or 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn' are offensive books because of their repeated use of the 'n - word'. However, there is an argument against this. There are several African - American scholars that I know who find the 'n - word' offensive in general, but not in the context of these books. They say that it adds more educational value to the book because in the time of Mark Twain, the 'n - word' was an accepted part of the language. That was simply the social norm back then. Back then and now, censorship is a way of hiding reality. People who write, sing, and direct things that are considered 'inappropriate' are the ones trying to expose the truth. The 'inappropriate' language or experiences are the ones that actually occur and are the words that are really spoken. By using censorship, we are creating a false sense of security and sheltering the world. Censorship is a tool we use to block ourselves from facing reality. Is this the right choice? Is it right to send sheltered teens out into the world, ill - equipped to fend for themselves? Or should we let them understand how the real world works? In conclusion, we should resist the urge to censor and embrace the realness in creative works.

Censorship 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This quote was from an author named Katherine Paterson. I firmly believe that certain materials such as books should not be removed from shelves under any circumstances. Everyone is entitled to their own opinion about certain materials. If books are removed from the shelves due to censorship, then what is the point of writing or even reading books? If people continue to remove books because they're found to be offensive, then there won't be any books left to read. I have come across many offensive books. Whether they involve religious beliefs or contain excessive sexual content, I'm certain they're offensive to someone somewhere. Books are written by authors who believe they have the right to express themselves through writing. If you were to take away or ban a certain book from the shelf, then what would the author who wrote the book think? The world is full of offensive and rather disturbing books. It can't be right to simply get rid of those things because they bother us. Everyone has the right to read any book they want to. Just because it offends one person, doesn't mean it offends everyone. I believe censorship is unnecessary. What gives anyone the right to remove or change something because it's inappropriate? I have personally read a few books that I wouldn't want little kids to read, but that doesn't mean I should remove it from the shelves. Perhaps, somebody else has been eagerly waiting to find that book. If I did remove it, then I'm restricting others from experiencing the joys of reading that book. Censorship in general is wrong. Everyone is entitled to their own beliefs and different ways of expressing themselves. I don't believe anyone has the right to take something that someone has worked hard on for so long to create and remove it because they find it offensive. There will always be something out there that you won't approve of. Just because you don't approve of it doesn't mean everybody doesn't approve. Authors write books for a reason, musicians write music for a reason, people make movies and magazines for a reason. What gives anyone the right to take something that somebody made and ban it from the rest of the world because it's offensive? Books are there to help us become more educated and more open - minded towards different thoughts and ideas. We shouldn't just ban them because they offend certain people. If you don't like a book because it offends you, then don't read it. It's as simple as that. If people continue to remove books because they're offensive, then there won't be any books left to read, and we'll lose the rich cultural and educational heritage that books provide.

If someone is actively looking for an offensive book, they will surely find it, regardless of whether it's gathering dust on a library shelf or is brand - new in a bookstore. The same situation applies to an offensive video game, magazine, or movie. Removing these offensive items from library shelves will simply prompt the people seeking them to search elsewhere. Different individuals hold varying opinions on what is offensive and what isn't. The Satanic Verses is an example of a controversial book that many people believed to be offensive to their religious beliefs. While numerous people found The Satanic Verses offensive, others thoroughly enjoyed the story. If the book had been removed from libraries because some people found it offensive, then those who really loved the book would have been deprived of the chance to read it. Another reason libraries should not remove offensive items from their shelves is that, in most cases, the entire book, magazine, movie, etc. is not offensive throughout. Even if a movie has one offensive scene, the rest of the movie could be an excellent story that many people would benefit from watching. It's the same concept with a book or magazine. There might be a few offensive chapters or one or two offensive articles, but it's very rare to find a book, movie, or magazine that is offensive from start to finish. Of course, there are still offensive items that would be inappropriate for younger kids to see, even with just one or two offensive scenes, chapters, or articles. There are easier solutions to this problem than completely removing the items from the shelves. One solution could be for libraries to set age limits on certain items, so that younger kids can't check out materials that are too inappropriate. But more importantly, it's the parents' responsibility to monitor what their kids are reading, watching, or listening to. Removing offensive books, magazines, music, and movies from library shelves would only lead to more problems and complaints. I firmly believe it's a good idea to leave the material on the library shelves and caution library users to 'read at their own risk'.

Censorship in Libraries. Censorship is a major conflict in many libraries. There are plenty of offensive books that shouldn't be placed on the shelves. Banning books can have both positive and very negative aspects for many reasons. First off, I like to consider the situation from the author or writer's perspective. How would you feel if you spent around five years writing a story or a movie for kids, and it got banned in the first couple of weeks it was on the shelves? I don't think many people would be happy about that. I also think that many people don't regard authors as being that important. When I think about it, it makes me realize all the things we wouldn't be able to read in our world, including newspapers, books, and magazines. Maybe we should also consider that it takes a great deal of effort to write the things that people want to hear or see. I feel that when books or movies get banned or removed, it makes the author feel worthless. The parents' point of view makes the situation even more complicated. Think of it like this: your child comes home from school with a book that he/she wants you to read with them. You sit down and start reading, and suddenly you come across a violent or inappropriate scene in the story. You stop reading immediately and look at your child, who is enjoying the violence and loving the story! What would you do? Many parents would call the school, explain what happened, and complain about banning this book and taking it away from children who could access it. But taking it away is pointless because just banning it from the school library doesn't mean that kids can't find it elsewhere. How do you think your child would feel if a story they loved suddenly disappeared? I know it would make me feel like I'd done something wrong. Taking things off shelves also has a positive side. When you take the book, movie, or magazine off the shelf, it's gone forever from that library. This can be a good thing because then kids won't have an obvious way to get the story. If you don't want your child or other children to see it, it's a reasonable idea. It makes the banned object harder to find and also less likely to catch kids' interest. If the book or movie isn't readily available, kids will be less likely to become interested in it. There are many different views on censorship, which can influence decisions about what happens in libraries. My view on this topic is negative, and I fully support it. If an author works hard on writing a story, they shouldn't be punished for expressing their feelings. Many people face this issue, and there are diverse views on the topic. Next Banned Book Week, I'll be standing up for the authors whose work has been banned. I hope you will too.

Censorship in public libraries, allowed? I firmly believe it should be, and here are a few different viewpoints. First of all, why should books be removed from shelves just because some people don't like the plot of a series? There are over a million of us people out there, and we all have different preferences. Moreover, reading is one area where we differ from each other. One person might prefer peaceful, warm - hearted stories, while others want something more intense to read. Since all of us are different around the world, humans have varying tastes in food, music, movies, and books. Everyone has different ways to satisfy their reading pleasures. To me, books are like religions; not all of us are the same in this regard, and at the same time, we all freely practice our religions without punishment. So why would you take away books that people love to read freely? In my eyes, it's simply not right. It's like taking candy away from an innocent baby because it might rot its teeth. What I mean is that, sure, some books might offend certain people, yet there might be others who find the books of those offended people offensive, and so on. But as long as a baby's teeth aren't actually rotting, why take the candy away? That is, if the books have individual shelves with clear labels about what they're all about, which they usually do, people wouldn't feel so offended when finding them in the wrong place. Looking at these viewpoints, do you understand where I'm coming from? We're all human beings, yet in books, we find different parts of ourselves. I know many book - readers with a wide range of tastes. No matter who they are and who their friends are, we're all unique. Many people other than myself would agree with this. So, tell me again why censorship shouldn't be in public libraries.

Books are a form of history, each one narrating a story from the past. In history, we don't block any offensive events that took place, so why should we remove any books that have offensive material in them? It would be unjust to deprive kids of any learning tools. Books are extremely important learning tools in today's schools, and there's always something new for a kid to learn in every book. So, even taking away one book could mean a kid learns one less thing. And doing this intentionally would go against everything that schools stand for. There are many different genres of books, but not everyone likes every genre. If a person only likes to read young - adult books because it relates to their culture, which most likely will have offensive language and events, and if you were to take these books away from a young adult in school, once again, this person would miss out on reading because they're not interested in the remaining books in the library. If you can even think of one instance where a student could be stripped of a learning opportunity, you shouldn't do it. The fact is, there are numerous reasons why you shouldn't remove any literature from library shelves.

Libraries shouldn't remove items just because some people find them offensive. People have diverse preferences when it comes to books. For instance, some love mystery novels, while others prefer romance or non - fiction. Removing certain books reduces the overall selection. A lower selection of books means less people have a compelling reason to visit the library, resulting in a less vibrant and useful community resource.

Can books, music, movies, and other materials be perfect for everyone? Everyone has their own unique opinions and deeply - held beliefs on what materials are good and what are not acceptable for the human mind. All over the world, young kids, young adults, and adults are actively engaged in reading books, flipping through magazines, listening to music, and watching movies. These are all hobbies that most people genuinely enjoy. Everyone reads different kinds of books, whether it's a thrilling mystery, a heart - warming romance, or a thought - provoking bible - based book. Removing books, magazines, and other materials off the shelves in a library leads to an unsuccessful, empty library. When people come and search for a book to read, they search for what they think they will enjoy. If they enjoy one thing, another person might not. They might find a book offensive, but does that mean everyone else is offended by the book as well? Taking that book out leaves the person who would enjoy that book stuck searching for another book. Everyone is different, everyone has their own story, just like these books do. Magazines are like books, they are meant to be enjoyed. I believe some magazines might not be appropriate for some people, but that doesn't mean they should take it off the shelf. It means that person should simply not read it. Magazines are made for all people to enjoy, that's why there are so many different kinds. They aim to fit each magazine personally to each individual. Music is the number one entertainment people enjoy. There is a reason why there are so many different genres. The music industry tries their best to sort the music to your taste. Just because one song has stuff in it you don't like doesn't mean you can delete that song from everyone. Music is used for many different ways. It relaxes you, pumps you up, it is used for parties, events, and so many other things. All songs are different so you can use them however you want. To ban music because someone doesn't like it, changes music forever. There would be no music to listen to. People should be able to watch what movies they want. That's why there are ratings on movies. What is acceptable for teenagers, might not be acceptable for young kids. That's why they should not watch it. If people banned all the movies they thought were inappropriate, there would be no rented movie stores, theaters, or success in the movie production industry. Everyone should know what kind of movies they like, and they should just watch what they like, and leave the other movies for the people who enjoy them. In conclusion, no, books, magazines, movies, and music can not be perfect for everyone. Materials bring all different kinds of subjects and stories for everyone. Each material brings enjoyment to different people. To ban all the materials you believe is inappropriate will leave the shelves empty. What kind of library or entertainment world would that be?

I, as a student, a child, and a citizen of the United States, firmly believe that every book should be allowed in any library. Books are a medium to express a wide range of feelings and emotions, just like movies and music. If we don't have them, how will we be able to learn anything in this world? Each book out there has a unique explanation, a captivating title, and a valid reason to be read. Today, millions of people read more and more because of the vast array of books available. I do believe, however, that the reason why every book should be in a library is because all of them are different. It doesn't matter what the book is about; some might seem offensive, but everyone has something that they dislike. There are many people out there who get defensive over various things, for example, certain people, animals, countries, different skin colors, cursing, and even sports. We all have our own opinions. If you do not like a certain book because it has content that you don't like, then it's simple  don't read it. Others might like it. Movies, books, music, magazines, etc., should be allowed anywhere. In conclusion, a diverse collection of these materials enriches our cultural and intellectual lives, and we should embrace this diversity rather than restricting access.

Dear newspaper, In my opinion, I don't think that censorship in libraries should be imposed on materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, and more materials. Censoring materials in the library could result in many problems. I don't agree with the censorship in libraries on materials for many reasons. In my upcoming paragraphs, I will explain why I disagree with libraries having censorship on a lot of their materials. Many libraries in the world currently have censoring on their materials. I believe that libraries have a lot of censoring on most of their materials due to the fact that they often have children under the age of eighteen constantly viewing a lot of explicit content. Libraries shouldn't censor their materials, but in my opinion, they also shouldn't let under - age children check out any kind of material that is only meant to be viewed by adults. Also, if computer access is offered to children, an adult supervisor should be nearby to make sure that no explicit content is being viewed. Censoring in libraries could result in many problems, such as customers not getting all the information they need for a certain material, children not reading up to their abilities or standards, and also children not learning enough or getting information that they need for school. If all of these things happen due to the fact that libraries have censors on their materials, then many libraries will not get as many customers. Yes, most people sometimes visit libraries for the wrong reasons, but to other people, those so - called "wrong reasons" might be the reason for them to gain more information. Materials in a library could also be found offensive to most people. But what's found offensive to most people could be found useful to other people. If something is found offensive to one person, I don't think it should be removed from the shelves. If books and or materials are removed from the shelves, that can hide so much useful information that people could gain. In conclusion, I don't think censorship should be put on materials in libraries due to the fact that much information could be lost. Censorship doesn't always mean that the material is bad; it can also mean that the material is just not appropriate to be viewed or read by that certain age group. If a library that I visit has censoring on most of their materials, I would convince the library staff to take the censoring off. Censoring is not always bad and it's not always good either, but it can hide a lot of information from us, which is not good at all. Libraries should strike a balance between protecting the young and providing access to all knowledge.

Censorship is indeed a significant aspect in many aspects of library operations. A library is a wonderful place where one can go to find a vast array of books, a rich collection of music, and other useful resources. The crucial question is, should everything that you can have access to be removed from the library shelves if it's found offensive? Libraries are a place to go to be used as resources or for pure fun. Everyone who goes to a library should have access to everything that meets their needs. In conclusion, by segregating offensive materials and having a permission - based access system, libraries can better serve all their patrons.

Is it really understandable to have some books restricted to people because of their age? No, it is not. The whole situation of whether or not libraries should have things such as movies, engaging books, and cool CDs restricted to certain people due to their age should not be a major issue. My reasoning for this is not because of how it might influence people in a bad way. On the contrary, it might influence them in a truly fantastic way. That's how people discover who they are, such as what they're interested in, what they like, and what they want to pursue in life. If it weren't for establishments such as libraries, most people would be just the same as others and not have a unique sense of character. People would be overly similar and have very few differences from one another. People should, of course, be aware of some of the content in books. But it should not be to the point where those areas become restricted to certain age groups. Movies and CDs are more understandable to have restrictions due to the actual graphic violence and explicit language that some musicians and actors might use. However, in a book, it's not just about what other people are doing and saying; it's about what you yourself are reading and how you yourself are interpreting it. It takes more than just the actions and words described to reflect on what you're reading and how you're engaging with it. That's why the whole situation should not be about restricting certain things such as movies, books, and CDs to a certain age group. Many books in libraries contain profanity, and it just depends on how you read and carefully analyze the profanity. To some people, the strong words are actually quite useful as they help the reader clearly grasp the point the writer is trying to convey in their head. To others, however, these words are simply offensive. I strongly disagree that most books are offensive to readers. I believe that they just assist the writers in getting their points across effectively. Many children do come across books with offensive language. But if they only read books that are within their appropriate age level, then they shouldn't encounter such problems. In adult books, there is typically more offensive language. But from an adult's perspective, it's a different story because they hear, and possibly even use, a lot of the words that they are seeing in these books on a regular basis. I believe that any offensive reading material should be identified and then moved to a specific area of the library. If you are an adult, you can then check these books out. This is an effective way to keep the children away from these books and their offensive words and to keep them 'innocent' for a longer time. Children don't really need to be reading books with offensive language anyway, but of course, this ultimately depends on their guardian's decision. It's not necessarily a bad thing to have strong language in books, as long as the reader who has the book is taking it in the way the writer intends, which is most likely to enhance the theme. Children should be kept away from these books, but they should not be completely removed from the shelves. They should just be placed in their own area for adults to read exclusively. In conclusion, a proper segregation of offensive materials in libraries can satisfy the needs of both adults and protect the innocence of children.

All libraries are well - equipped with books suitable for all readers, regardless of their age. If parents take prompt action, their child should understand that they are taking the wrong book from the bookshelf. Wouldn't children learn from this experience and understand that if their parent has to take the wrong book back, they should not do it again? I reiterate that some, but not all, reading materials such as books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed due to some of the graphical features in each reading material. The books on each bookshelf are or should be arranged in alphabetical order with the last name of the author first. All libraries have books for all readers no matter the age. In conclusion, proper arrangement and parental guidance can ensure that children access age - appropriate materials in libraries.

In many libraries, there are books, movies, magazines, and music that some people find offensive. The degree of offensiveness varies from person to person, with some finding them more offensive than others. These resources are in the library for a valid reason. If what is on the shelves is a distraction to people, they don't have to pay any attention to it. People can easily find what they like and stay away from what they do not like. For instance, there are books that talk about real - life events happening to real people, and some might not be able to handle the descriptive details provided; if it's too difficult to handle, they can simply put the book back and go read something else. College students, teachers, and students from all over the world rely on a library with these kinds of books, movies, music, and magazines. For example, those who read more than others are usually more involved in plays and have no problem speaking in front of people. This is due to their higher intelligent reading levels. So, as you can see, people have different likes and dislikes, and some will find these resources offensive. Also, books are essential for helping people and making them more intelligent. If books, movies, and music were removed, our intelligence levels would not be as good as they could be. Every human being will face problems in life, and that's just the nature of life. We have to learn to deal with these problems. In fact, when these issues of offensive resources come up, we should understand that we all have different outlooks on everything. Removing books from the shelves would not solve anything; instead, they can only benefit us.

I think that people who find offensive books, music, movies, and magazines just need to stay away from them. Some of these books contain information that people need to know. Take the concentration camps, for example. People need to learn about the atrocities that took place there so that we can prevent such a horrible event from happening again. I believe that by allowing people to read those types of books, it helps us understand and learn about what happened in the past. So, we need to keep the books on the shelf and let people learn. I do not believe books, music, and magazines should be removed from shelves. Wherever you go in the world, whether you like it or not, you're going to come in contact with things you don't find appropriate or you think are offensive. In today's world, the world is far from perfect. One reason I don't believe they should be removed is because it would be unconstitutional. The freedom of speech and the press was not meant to be tampered with. If a specific library thinks their articles are inappropriate, an easy solution would be to put these articles in a certain section of the library and clearly warn people about what they are. The main reason I don't believe books, music, and magazines should be removed from the shelves is because the world is a harsh place and books are the least of your concerns. Kids can't be sheltered their whole lives; they need to face reality, and books are a good source for that. Kids these days are resilient and can handle 'inappropriate' content. Parents need to accept the fact that their kids are going to be exposed to offensive things in today's imperfect world of ours. It's just a natural part of growing up. Another contributing factor is that it would be unconstitutional to remove books and other articles from the shelves of @LOCATION1's libraries. When the amendments regarding freedom of speech and press were written down, they were intended to be permanent. They are not guidelines that can be overlooked; they are rules set in stone for today's great country. People have fought for freedom over much bigger issues than books. Who are we to tell people what they can and can't write down? People's natural opinions can't and shouldn't be governed. I think it would be a crime against @LOCATION1 to censor things in libraries. My final reason for not censoring libraries is that it all boils down to the people running the library. If they think some of their articles are profound and inappropriate, they can simply isolate them to a certain section of the library and put a clear warning for people to see. If people don't want to be offended, they simply have to stay away from these sections. Take responsibility for what is in these libraries that is apparently so offensive and put them in their own area and stay away from them. Do not take them out completely because, who knows, someone might want that offensive book. These are all supporting opinions as to why I personally do not believe libraries should be censored. Today's world is far from perfect, and it's not going to become perfect by censoring libraries. Plus, such an act would be completely unconstitutional. Finally, all the libraries have to do is exile these articles to certain areas of the libraries and put a warning on them. If libraries were censored, there would be a lot of missing information in today's world because there are many things in today's world that are 'offensive' to at least someone.

I believe that in libraries, certain materials should not be removed from the shelves even if they are offensive. The reason is that if someone does not like a particular item, they can always go and choose another one. I have visited a library, and I found that nothing there was offensive to me or anyone else around. If people don't like the fact that the library displays what they consider 'OFFENSIVE' items, it's a personal choice not to go there. Everyone has the right to choose what they listen to or read. As long as a particular person likes a certain type of thing, that's their prerogative. That is what I firmly believe in. In a world where people have diverse tastes and opinions, it's important to respect the availability of different materials in libraries. Removing items just because a few find them offensive would limit the choices and learning opportunities for others. Libraries are meant to be a source of knowledge and exploration, and by keeping these materials on the shelves, we ensure that everyone has access to a wide range of information. So, in conclusion, we should not remove offensive materials from library shelves but rather let people make their own choices based on their preferences.

Everything is offensive to someone. There is simply no way to make sure that nobody is offended unless there is absolutely nothing to offend anybody at all. If there is something on the shelf, it's highly likely that someone can find something offensive in it. Here is a good scenario: there is a children's book. It is one of the greatest books ever written, but it was written before the civil war and contains a racist comment. Then, goodbye to that book. Some people would probably think 'Well, it's only a children's book. I'm sure we will survive.' But let's move on to a bigger idea. What happens when someone says the Bible is offensive? Then, that's gone. Now, its supporters are saying that the other people's entire religion is offensive. That means a few more books are removed. Now, let's consider violence. Moderate censorship is acceptable for the young, but there is a line, even though it can be hard to define sometimes. Obscene images that are illegal to view by a minor are justifiably censored, but those that are legal should be accessible without censorship. Censorship for those who are mature enough to understand is unacceptable, although select items should be viewed under supervision. To strip a person of their rights is not acceptable. The @LOCATION1 government has granted people certain freedoms. One of those freedoms is the freedom of speech. This essentially means that I can say whatever I want and support whatever I believe in. A book is a form of speech. Although some speech is frowned upon, it should not be censored. Censorship is basically saying 'you can not say this.' That then leads to 'you can not say' and finally 'you have no say.' In developing countries, such as the Congo, if you go to the government and say what they are doing wrong and that you are against them, you can guess what happens. They shoot you. A more appropriate word for that would be they censor you. If you write a book saying how Obama could be a better president, but someone finds it offensive, what happens? They censor you. Now you have no say in the matter because the supporters of Obama don't want you to. Do you see much difference? Supervision is a powerful tool. It can do a better job than censorship. With supervision, children can still learn about various topics but are not simply exposed to the obscene aspects of them. A person, including a child, has the right to learn without excessive influence from others, but censorship denies them of that right. Censorship should not be used in libraries. It takes away freedoms and opportunities for children. It can cause conflicts among people. It can damage culture and ignore religion. Although censorship is intended to protect people from things they find wrong, good intentions do not prevent the negative consequences. We should find a balance between allowing access to information and protecting the vulnerable, but complete censorship is not the answer.

With new things emerging these days, I, @PERSON1, firmly believe that all the materials in libraries should have a proper organization for certain subjects. I'm not advocating for the removal or destruction of books, magazines, or any other items in the libraries. Instead, I'm simply asking for a fair hearing of my opinion. I truly desire more organization for certain things. I'm well - aware that people have their own ideas about what should be in a book. These books found in a library can bring great enjoyment to many, but sometimes they can also offend others. So, I really wish there was a scale or an organizational system for books. That way, people who don't like certain subjects can easily avoid the books they dislike. If there is a scale factor for these books, music, magazines, or movies, we can use a number or a letter to symbolize the specific categories. Even though, personally, I think it's a bit less effective than a different organization method, it would at least alert people to these things. If a decision is made that either way would be better, then there would be fewer people complaining and demanding all books be destroyed. I firmly believe that organizing the books in a different way would be the better option. This would require a lot of work, but think about a mother with a child. She could easily keep her child away from books that she herself wouldn't even touch. I would never want any books removed from libraries. Everyone has their own opinion, as do I, and I firmly believe it should be allowed.   Censoring books allows libraries to withhold books, movies, magazines, music, and more from children who are not quite mature enough to handle the contents within the material. I believe that an age limit should be set for certain types of materials. Children that are under the age of 13 should not be watching movies that are rated PG - 13. There is a reason the rating is what it is. Just because your child is not allowed to rent/check out whatever the material might be, doesn't mean that you couldn't check it out, maybe go home and watch/listen/read/play it. If it doesn't seem too violent/graphic for your child, then allow them to watch the movie, read the book, or play the game. That is your choice, but a library doesn't want to be blamed for your 5 - year - old coming home cursing and fighting. My sister took my niece to the library once to rent a movie. But in one of the scenes, there was some arguing and fighting, and my niece began arguing with my sister and hitting her. My sister wasn't very pleased that they allowed that movie to be on the children's floor of the library.   Censorship is a wonderful thing to have in libraries. The maturity level for some children is just not quite high enough for them to see/watch/listen/play certain materials. Not only should censorship be allowed, it should be enforced. I believe all libraries should have to have censorship in their library. In conclusion, censorship in libraries is essential to protect young and impressionable minds from inappropriate content while still allowing adults to access a wider range of materials.

There are many books, magazines, and movies out there that contain content not necessarily appropriate for young children. Part of a parent's job is to ensure their children are safe and looking at materials appropriate for their age level. However, this does not mean taking materials off of library shelves for everyone. Censorship in libraries rids people of their freedom to choose. Also, content that is inappropriate for children might be fine for adults to read. Libraries offer a wide variety of materials, and this allows people to choose what they want based on their interests. Censoring the content on the shelves of libraries might seem like a good idea for children; however, adults have the right to choose what they want to take from the shelf. Furthermore, censoring what is on the shelves of libraries limits the range of materials that are available to patrons. There is content out there that children should not see; however, adults have the right to choose what they want to read and come in contact with. Although certain materials are not meant for children to see, adults might find it enjoyable and interesting. Libraries offer a large range of materials, and this allows people to express themselves and find entertainment. There are many different types of books and music out there, and censoring these would greatly limit the variety.   In addition, parents have the responsibility to watch over their children. They choose what their child wears, where they live, and where they attend school. It is no different when it comes to books, movies, and music. Each parent has a different style of parenting, and they choose what works best for their child. If one parent finds something to be offensive or inappropriate, they shelter their children from it. However, another parent might not have a problem with it. The content children choose from library shelves should be at the discretion of the parent. After all, you cannot shelter children from everything.   Censorship in libraries results in more problems than solutions. It rids patrons of their right to choose and their freedom. Censoring materials also greatly limits the variety of content available for people to choose from. It is not the responsibility of the law to choose what children can and cannot read, but rather the parent's job to watch over what they take off the shelf. As citizens of the @LOCATION1, we have rights and freedom allowing us to act as individuals. Censoring the materials on library shelves results in very little materials left. As Katherine Paterson said, 'And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' We must strike a balance between protecting the young and preserving the rights and freedoms of all library patrons.

The concept is quite simple; if the reader or viewer does not think they would agree with the work, then they should not spend their time to read or view the pieces at hand. Just because they might not completely think what the content entails is necessarily appropriate, someone else might enjoy it. Censorship is wrong for this very reason. The creators of their work are most likely proud of what they have accomplished and would like their audience to enjoy it too. In Katherine Paterson's writing, she clearly conveys that she doesn't want her child to casually pick up a book off the shelf that could potentially be offensive. However, I firmly believe that libraries should have sections that are hidden from the public eye yet still accessible to specific individuals. For instance, if my child were to pick up a book that isn't suitable for their age group, I wouldn't get angry. I understand that some book categorizations are close to one another, and all books are on display, which might be offensive to some. In such a situation, I'd gently tell my son or daughter that the book isn't for them, and then we'd go together to pick out a new, appropriate book to read. There are indeed some movies, books, music, and other forms of media that can be found offensive to certain people. I firmly feel that if you're of the appropriate age for a particular type of literature, you should have the right to access and observe it. If you read a book and find it offensive, then perhaps you shouldn't have chosen to read it in the first place. Books, music, and movies are primarily created to entertain. However, if you're not entertained by what you're reading or watching, it simply means that it's not the right fit for you. I once had an experience where I was deeply offended by a movie I watched. The movie degraded women by showing them being beaten and treated as slaves. As I watched it, I couldn't help but think that these women were someone's daughter and mother. I would never agree to my own mother being treated that way, and I certainly wouldn't want any other woman to endure such treatment either. Everyone has their own way of thinking and absorbing information. What might be offensive to one reader could be well - received and admired by someone else. I believe that censorship is a highly debatable subject for many. But I think I have a well - considered outlook and a clear view on this matter. Censorship involves the question of whether books, music, movies, magazines, etc. should be removed from the shelves. I believe in a free society where everyone has the right to read what they want and what they don't. If an adult wants to read something vulgar, it's their choice. However, when it comes to children, I think they should not have unrestricted access to such content. To keep children away from vulgar things, libraries and other media outlets should have separate sections for kids and adults. If parents think it's okay for their children to read, watch, or listen to certain things, they should obtain it for them until the children reach adulthood. I don't advocate for children to be shielded from the real world, but I do believe there should be a reasonable limit to what they are exposed to. Clearly, I think censorship is a good thing. I'm not saying that having an urban style is bad, but when it leads to criminal behavior and drug use, it becomes a problem. I believe that only children should be subject to censorship, not adults. Once a person reaches adulthood, they have a better understanding of what they should and shouldn't do. What's yours?

To whom it may concern; As a student, I find myself reading quite frequently. Whether at home, at school, in the library, or even in the car, I'm always on the lookout for a good novel. However, not all the novels I read are ones I've chosen for my personal growth. I must admit that I'm not an enthusiastic reader on my own. I'm the kind of student who only enjoys reading books that truly interest me. Many of the books I choose are closely related to real - life situations, which often include content that could be considered explicit. I firmly believe that books, magazines, movies, music, etc. should not be removed from the shelves. As @CAPS1 citizens, we are granted the right to free speech. This fundamental right allows us to express our thoughts and opinions freely without any restrictions on our personalities. It also gives authors and producers the freedom to base their work on their own ideas. Media that might be considered explicit appeals to a wide range of people, while others find it disturbing. With the freedom we have as @CAPS2, we have the power to choose whether to watch certain movies or read specific books, and we also have the option to avoid them. When producers create movies with sexual content, strong language, or violence, they know that not every citizen will want to watch them. There's no law forcing us to watch movies we don't like. We have the ability to make our own choices. Explicit material is everywhere. When walking in @LOCATION2 and @LOCATION3, we see books, music, and magazines lining the walls, most of which contain explicit content. But it's important to note that although many novels have explicit material, there are still plenty that don't. People often complain about explicit content in novels, but in reality, there are numerous novels without such content. As humans, we tend to focus on the negative aspects of situations and lead pessimistic lives. We need to learn to look for the good in things. There's a vast amount of media that contains no explicit or sexual material, and we're given clear warnings about what does and doesn't have such content. These warnings are mandatory! Labels like @CAPS3 or @CAPS4 indicate whether a piece of media is suitable for general audiences, with or without parental supervision. Parents have the responsibility to monitor what their children are exposed to. They can set rules for their children, such as only allowing them to watch @CAPS3 - rated movies or requiring parental consent to read a magazine or novel. Parents are guardians for a reason; they need to take an active role in monitoring and caring for their children. If they don't like the music, novels, or movies their children are interested in, they have the right and the power to change it. Instead of trying to remove all explicit material from the market, parents should set their own limits for their families and have open discussions with their children about it. Katherine Paterson is absolutely right when she says, 'If I have the right to remove that book from the shelf... then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' If we were given the power to remove any books, movies, magazines, etc. that we don't think should be on the market, we'd likely end up with no media at all. With billions of citizens in @LOCATION1 alone, each person is likely to find something wrong with a particular book. If we removed every book with a perceived flaw, we'd have no variety of material to choose from. People who are strongly in favor of eliminating explicit material would act quickly, while those against it might not be as vocal. This could lead to a chaotic and divided society. We, as humans, value our freedoms and the ability to make choices. Taking away our freedom to choose what we read or watch would undermine our individuality and self - expression. Books, movies, and magazines are meant to be enjoyed based on personal opinion, and this should remain the case.

Libraries hold a vast array of books and movies, including fiction, nonfiction, historical, fantasy, and adventure. One book that comes to my mind that can be seen as offensive is 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'. This movie has a boy from a slum being tortured because he knows the answers to the questions on the game show 'Who Wants to be a Millionaire?'. Many Indians, who believe they are smarter, could be offended by this because it implies that if you grow up in a slum, you can't be smart. Do I think offensive reading materials should be taken off the shelves in libraries? No, books should not be removed from libraries. According to Katherine Paterson, who wrote an article about censorship in the library, the question arises: Should we be able to have the right to take a book, magazine, movie, etc. off the shelf freely, whether we're offended by it or not? One problem it could cause is regarding people's thoughts towards a book, movie, CD, and so forth. If one person looks at a particular item and says, 'I don't like this and that about it,' and then just pulls it off the shelf, then that's one less thing for somebody who does like it. I do not believe that censorship should be an option for people who find a book, magazine, or movie offensive. Since nothing is censored on the internet, if you're all about censorship, you should avoid going onto the internet. Adults do not need censorship. There should be well - defined sections for children, teens, and adults. There are ratings on movies, and books are written with a certain age limit in mind, so everything should be placed accordingly. Censorship is needed, but your parents or guardian are the ones who will most likely tell you whether or not you're going to be able to read a book or watch a movie. Some people find things more offensive than others. So, censorship is really in the eye of the beholder. Personally, I believe in censorship, but to others, it's a waste of time. I wouldn't want my child watching a movie where someone gets brutally murdered and there's cussing every other word. Music can come in both uncensored and censored versions, it just depends on what you want to hear. In conclusion, censorship is a complex issue that is either loved or hated, and it all boils down to personal opinion. We should respect different views while also ensuring that appropriate content is available for different age groups.

Each book in a library bears its own unique relation to each person that enters that library. Whether the books relate well or poorly to each person is not something that a large group of people should decide. Every person has a distinct outlook on what makes a story interesting. There will never be a book that every human being agrees is both appropriate and engaging. Since people are designed with distinctly different minds, they want to read distinctly different books, written by distinctly different authors. People should maintain the right to choose which books they want to read. Never will one book bind the world. The minds of human beings are too complexly separated. For example, reading 'To Kill a Mockingbird' by Harper Lee in my English class last year was more than appropriate, though rather boring for the majority of the class. Books dealing with racism, religion, and sexual content can either intrigue a person's mind or disgust them. Finding satisfactory books for everyone in a community to agree on simply won't ever be possible. There will always be that one person who refuses to agree. It is a choice. It is a choice for each person to read what he or she wants to read. If you force something upon a society of readers, then what will they have left for their own minds' freedom? Face it, forcing an atheist to read an emotionally comprehensive novel of the Christian faith will not be tolerated by the reader. Cursing, to some people, brings a book to a realistic point. To others, however, it makes them lose interest in the story. A choice should remain a person's right; especially when it comes to reading a book written to be read. Censorship is a growing problem in today's world of literature. Censoring does not always allow the author to thoroughly convey his or her ideas as they were originally intended to. Katherine Paterson says that if we were all allowed to eliminate things that we thought were wrong, then there would be nothing left to be right about. Censoring leads to an ignorant, opinionless, and clueless society. In the novel 'Fahrenheit 451', censorship is one of the main themes of the story. Bradbury portrays the burning of books as the way of ending all controversial opinions. Guy Montag finds that the burning of books has led the society that he lives in to be ignorant of what is going on around them. The government has tried to rule out all causes of controversial opinions in the hope that it would make for a happier society. When in reality, members of the world are not happy and are consistently showing the reader that they do not know how to be happy. Guy Montag decides that he wants to learn, but he does not know how. The brain is a muscle, if it is not exercised correctly, it becomes weak and useless. So when he tries to memorize a part of the Bible, he cannot retain what he has been reading. Such as trying to fill a sieve full of sand, he does not know how to learn. The members of this novel's society are basically opinionless on what is happening in their world. What they are told on the television is thought of to be factual, and that is what they do all day. In school, kids are being fed fact after fact and are expected to agree with what they are being told with no questioning involved. In a normal society, learning leads to questioning. But for them there is no learning, just accepting. And acceptance leads to contentness, which in the end leads to unhappiness. The society in 'Fahrenheit 451' proves to be oblivious to everything that is going on in many different ways. To them, death is not a big deal. Clarisse McClellan was killed by a speeding car, and Mildred, Montag's wife, was not even shocked to hear it. Another example is when Guy Montag was running from the police, and a car full of rambunctious teenagers attempted to run him over just because they wanted to. At the end of the novel, Guy Montag is walking along the railroad tracks with his new friends and the entire city is blown to dust by bombs dropped by fighter planes. The city had no idea that this was going to happen, they were clueless to the war that was going on around them every day! A clueless society is a useless society, and in the end they were destroyed. Censorship lies within the hands of the viewer. Censorship has become such a big problem in the world when there are so many other things people should worry about. Reading about somebody doing drugs will not make a child want to do drugs, it crosses every teenager's mind at least once. But instead of not allowing them to even realize that it is out there, parents should do what they signed up to do, teach your kids right from wrong and hope that you did it well. In conclusion, censorship has far - reaching negative impacts on society, and we should approach it with more rationality.

Reading it is a pleasure for some and a chore for others. When considering whether objects in the library with offensive details should be cleaned up or removed from the shelves, it's clear that there are some materials that could undergo censorship, while others would lose their value if censored. Indeed, I firmly believe that there are items in the library that could benefit from censorship. I'm going to explain the reasons for censorship and what types of content should be censored.   There are certain types of library items that should not be subject to cleanup. For instance, historical documentaries or historical books have no other way to convey the necessary information to the reader or viewer. However, there are other library items that could be censored. Some magazines and movies display uncensored scenes or pages that aren't necessary to convey a message, even if there is one to be conveyed. I think a movie, book, or magazine should only remain uncensored if it's trying to make a valid point. If uncensored items aren't getting a point across, they have no place in the library.   As we can see, there are circumstances where an uncensored book, movie, or magazine is extremely useful for obtaining information. But there are more situations where a library item doesn't need uncensored details because they're simply offensive. If you ask me whether censorship is important in libraries, I'd have to say it's a yes - and - no answer. I've just provided some reasons for this stance. The next time you're in the library looking for a book, ask yourself one question: Is it too offensive to be valuable? By carefully considering these factors, we can strike a balance between access to information and a suitable library environment.

Have you ever imagined going to the library and picking up a magazine from the shelf only to find it offensive, and being unable to do anything about it? Well, now you can voice your concerns. Katherine Paterson and I visited a library together. We selected a magazine from the shelf, and it contained a lot of offensive content that we didn't like. We approached the lady at the front desk, and she was completely unaware that such magazines were there. She got really angry and went back to the shelf, only to discover that there were many magazines with offensive writing, pictures, and even comments. We gathered all of those magazines and threw them away.   In my opinion, offensive things like movies, music, and magazines should be removed. They should be removed because they're a bad influence on the youth. They plant ideas in the young minds, and later, the youth might act on them, say inappropriate things in public, or even do them at home. These offensive materials are getting a lot of people into trouble, making them imitate what they see. This is particularly affecting kids, making them more violent towards their schoolmates, friends, and even their moms.   We need to remove all these offensive materials because they're everywhere and easy to find. In movies, for example, it's reached the point where you see naked girls in almost every film. Parents also have a role to play. They're the ones buying these materials and leaving them around the house, making it easy for children to access them.   We have to be more careful about what we buy or read. You might find something offensive, and if your kids read it, they'll form the wrong ideas. So, the next time you buy something or go somewhere and find something offensive, talk to the manager or supervisor about removing it. That's why I firmly believe these offensive materials should be removed to protect the well - being of our youth and create a more appropriate environment.

Parents should inform their kids about what they're allowed to read at certain ages. This is where my opinion begins, and I'll explain why I hold this view. I'll discuss why I disagree with the idea that parents should have absolute control over what books are available in libraries, and provide reasons for my stance.   I truly believe that anyone should be able to read the kind of books they like. The library is the source for these books. Just because a parent doesn't want their child to read a certain book doesn't mean the book shouldn't be in the library. Parents need to explain to their children the reasons why they don't want them to read a particular book.   If parents take the time to explain, kids will understand why the book isn't suitable for them. Those types of books are often favored by older people and are quite interesting. I think if people understand the content of a book and it doesn't bother them, then they're old enough to read it. Also, young kids who shouldn't be reading these books should be accompanied by an adult or guardian. This way, the adult can prevent the child from reading inappropriate content.   Another issue that concerns many people is not being able to access a book just because some parents don't like it. This is taking away our right, and we shouldn't have to buy a book just to read it once. If these books are so terrible, why are people still writing them? If they haven't caused significant problems so far, there's no reason for people to suddenly object to them. People should be able to do what they enjoy without having that right taken away.   This is my opinion on the matter. Many people may not agree, but I've tried to make them see my perspective. By understanding different viewpoints, we can work together to ensure that people's rights to access books are protected, and that the community can continue to enjoy the benefits of a diverse library collection.

Television, news, drama, life, and controversy. These are just a few of the themes that books are written about. Some subjects are regarded as vulgar and inappropriate for young audiences. Many people believe that their children have the right to learn about all the things books can offer, but is that really a good idea? Books have long been an important tool for students. However, not all books are suitable for all audiences. Stories about knights and princesses are great for young people, while other stories about the darker aspects of life are usually kept away from children.   Books are censored for various reasons. Some of these reasons are trivial and shouldn't prevent a book from reaching its full potential. The truth is, there's a line that shouldn't be crossed, and some books cross this line and get banned. That's appropriate. However, some books that don't 'cross the line' are banned anyway. Honestly, careful consideration must be given before deciding to ban a book or keep it on the shelves.   If a book written by a recognized author contains only minor obscenities and is banned, the author may not face serious pressure as the banning will be well - known, and consumers may still buy the book out of curiosity. However, if a relatively unknown author writes a well - crafted piece with a few somewhat vulgar references, and the book is banned, the author is in serious trouble. This author can no longer have their book in libraries, which means their work may never be recognized. Banning books is preventing authors from making a name for themselves.   Books that are extremely vulgar should definitely be banned. No child should be reading a book intended solely for adults. Children should be protected from such material, and book banning serves this purpose. If a child really wants to read a banned book, they can ask their parents to buy it, assuming the parents think it's okay for children to read such filthy books.   If a book can spark good discussion in a classroom and is mostly 'clean', it should be available to everyone. Just because a book has a few inappropriate references doesn't mean students shouldn't read it. If the learning material a book offers outweighs the potential negative effects on a student, the book should be accessible. However, since it's difficult to effectively compare knowledge and harmful effects, this is a complex decision.   In conclusion, while book banning can protect children from inappropriate material, it also has a negative impact on authors. We need to find a middle ground where we can ensure that children are protected while also allowing authors to share their work. By carefully evaluating each book, we can make more informed decisions about banning and availability.

I believe there should not be censorship in libraries. If someone needs to read a book about a particular topic and the library doesn't have it because the library staff doesn't believe in or like what the book has to say, the reader is deprived of the opportunity to learn the actual facts.   The first reason I believe there should be no censorship in libraries is that many students go to libraries to study for papers. If the library doesn't have the book a student is looking for, it fails in its main purpose of providing access to information.   The second reason is that just because the person in charge of the library doesn't like a book, it doesn't mean they have to prevent others from reading it. Books are meant for everyone to read.   The third reason is that a library is supposed to have a wide range of books so that people can access the information they need. If the owner removes a book and someone needs that specific book but can't get the information from it, the library is failing in its primary function.   The fourth reason is that many people read books to learn about different things. Just because an individual doesn't like what a book says doesn't give them the right to remove it from the library. Should materials in libraries be censored? No, I don't think that stuff in libraries should be censored or taken off the shelf. If something is offensive to someone, that person simply doesn't need to look at that material. People should have the right to get whatever they want from the library. If someone doesn't like the materials available, that's their problem. What if kids get inappropriate stuff off the shelf? If a kid were to pick something bad or inappropriate for themselves, the libraries won't let them check it out, so it's not an issue. Additionally, parents should be monitoring what their kids are getting. I visit the library frequently, and I've never seen anything inappropriate. I also don't know anyone who's ever told me they've found something offensive in a library. I think libraries are well - aware of what people want and don't want. It's not right to take something off the shelves just because a few people don't like it, as I'm sure other people enjoy it. However, if there's something extremely offensive that everyone agrees is bad, then it can be removed. But you can't remove material every time someone complains it's offensive, or there probably won't be anything left in the library. In conclusion, I don't think anything should be removed from shelves just because some people find it offensive. There are likely just as many people who don't find it offensive, and it would be unfair to take it away from them.

I believe that if there's a book in a library that a child isn't allowed to read, the book should be placed where the child can't access it. I think those types of books should be stored in the part of the library where a child doesn't have access. Also, the library should have a section where only a certain age group can read those books. In some libraries, there are many books not suitable for children, yet they're placed where children can easily access them, and this shouldn't be allowed. So, I firmly believe children shouldn't have access to those types of books. The same principle applies in a store. In some stores, there's a magazine section with inappropriate content that a child shouldn't see. In the grocery store I go to, there are inappropriate images and words that a child shouldn't read. There should be an area in the store where only a certain age group can access these magazines. One day, I was in the store and saw a little kid reading a magazine, saying the bad words in it and looking at the bad pictures. This is why magazines should be placed where children can't access them. In the same store, there's a music section, and children are often there. The music isn't all bad, but kids can take the CDs off the shelves and take them home to listen. This is partly the parents' fault if they buy the CDs for their children. I think the CDs for little children should be in one part of the store, and the CDs for older people should be in an area where they can access them. The same goes for movies. There are movies in stores rated from various levels, including those for specific age audiences only. Many movies rated for older audiences have content that children shouldn't see. For example, movies for adult audiences often show nudity and other inappropriate content that no one under a certain age should view, yet some of these movies are just sitting on the shelves. So, children shouldn't be able to access these types of movies. The main reason I've explained all this is to prevent children from getting hold of such inappropriate materials. If kids start listening to bad music, they might start using bad words and get in trouble at school or elsewhere. Similarly, if a child reads a book with bad content, they might imitate what they read. In movies, if a child sees inappropriate content, they might show it to their friends or get bad ideas. In conclusion, by restricting children's access to these inappropriate materials, we can protect them from negative influences.

Should we have the right to remove materials from shelves if they're found offensive? I believe we should not have this right. If we did, there would be no materials left for future children to read. When considering this right, we must remember that even though some materials may mention discrimination, use an offensive word, or we simply don't like a book, movie, or magazine, we should never have the right to remove them. I know several people who think a seemingly harmless children's book is discriminatory. There are books that discuss discrimination against certain races or inform us about a time when people were discriminated against. If we had the right to remove these materials, they would all eventually disappear. Future children wouldn't know that these events ever happened, or if they did, their information would likely be inaccurate as people might distort the story over time. If someone found a single offensive word in a book or movie, they could remove it from others' view. For instance, if someone found a curse word offensive and had the right to remove the material, thousands of good books and movies would disappear because of one person's dislike of a word. Some people might think certain materials are a waste of space and remove them if they don't like the book, movie, music, or magazine. However, there are others who enjoy these materials and find them good or entertaining. Judging a book by its size or the size of its words isn't a valid way to evaluate it. I firmly believe that nobody should have the right to remove a book, movie, music, or magazine from the shelf. We should keep these materials as a reference for future generations. In the past, people have destroyed materials they didn't like, and now we'll never know what they were about. There's no reason to remove a material based on one person's opinion. By preserving these materials, we can ensure that future generations have access to a wide range of knowledge and perspectives.

I believe that certain materials such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should not be removed from libraries for being too offensive.   First off, many people have different opinions about what is offensive and what is not. For example, people have diverse interests. Some people, like me, are fond of certain kinds of books and movies, while others prefer different genres. For instance, one of my favorite types of movies to watch is a comedy. On the other hand, there are many friends of mine that love to watch horror movies. This natural difference in preference is something you can not change. Everyone is going to have their own preference on what they want to read, listen to, or watch. Why would you take things away that people actually enjoy? There are other ways to solve this problem.  I believe that we can solve this problem by just separating certain materials from others in the library. For example, if something is thought to be offensive, then it can be placed with others like it. These materials do not have to be removed completely. Mothers are often worried about their children picking up things in the library that they think are offensive. If these materials are separated from others, there will not be a problem. Certain materials do not have to be removed completely from a library.  All in all, there is no need to remove materials from a library because many people have different interests. In conclusion, I firmly believe that materials should not be removed from libraries for being too offensive as it goes against the principle of catering to diverse interests.

There are numerous books, music, movies, and magazines that people find offensive. Some people even believe these things should be taken off the shelves. However, I do not believe that the books, music, movies, or magazines should be removed completely. Not everyone finds these things offensive, and they should not be taken off the shelves just because a few people do not agree with them. First, people have diverse views on what they find offensive. Not everyone will find the same things offensive or want the same books or songs to be removed. Due to people always having different views, it is extremely difficult to take books, music, movies, or magazines off the shelves to satisfy everyone. Just because one person does not agree with what is being said in a movie or book does not mean that every single person wants that movie or book to be removed. If one person found my favorite book offensive, I would not want it taken off the shelves completely. Equally important, if every book, song, movie, and magazine that someone finds offensive is taken off the shelves, there would not be many left. Author Katherine Paterson once said, 'But if I have the right to remove a book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' She is saying that if every single book that offends someone is taken off the shelves, there would be no books for anyone to read. People find different things offensive, and if everyone took these things off the shelves, there would be none left for anyone. Finally, if someone finds a book offensive, they do not have to read it. When someone finds a book, movie, song, or magazine offensive, they don't need to watch it or read it. Instead of taking it off the shelves, the person could simply avoid it. Not everyone finds the same books offensive, and taking them off the shelves could upset many people. When someone finds something offensive, they could just steer clear of it instead of getting it removed and upsetting other people. If someone was offended by one of my favorite books, I would prefer if they just avoid reading it instead of taking it off the shelves so that I can't read it. Some people find many books, songs, movies, and magazines offensive and would like them to be removed permanently. I, however, do not believe that these things should be removed. While taking these off the shelves might make some people happy, it could also upset even more. Not everyone finds the same things offensive, and they should not be taken off the shelves because a few people do not agree with them. In conclusion, a more inclusive approach should be adopted to deal with offensive materials in libraries and other media sources.

With this process, every book with a racial slur or questionable scene is not removed, while the ones that truly deserve it are removed. In conclusion, the existing system strikes a reasonable balance between freedom of access and protection from harmful or highly offensive materials.
