Censorship in libraries? That could be a good and a bad thing. Is it truly that significant for kids to encounter some inappropriate content in books? Will authors actually remove their books from libraries due to censorship? Censorship in Libraries is not as necessary as most people assume. Children nowadays are well - informed and quite intelligent about certain subjects. I understand that parents don't want their children to read books containing drugs, alcohol, sex, etc. However, they're going to have to learn about these things sometime in their lives. They might as well get an early start on it now. Young children most of the time aren't even interested in picking up those kinds of books anyway. If you censor all the books in the libraries, then some students would face difficulties in projects they need those kinds of books for. Say I needed a book on alcohol for a project I'm doing in my science class. If the books are censored, then I would have no sources to obtain information from.   On the other hand, I can see why adults would want the books censored. No parent wants their child coming home from school talking about sex and drugs they saw in a book at school. If I were a parent, I would be concerned myself. But if it's such a big deal to some adults, then what are they going to do when their children see the same stuff, only worse, on TV? Commercials about condoms and advertisements promoting drug - like substances. At least with books, the book is teaching you about the drug and how dangerous it is for you.   If one author takes their book off the shelf because they don't want children reading it, then that gives all authors the impetus to do the same. Which could mean that we would have no books on the shelves for anybody. Books are a key to learning! We need to keep ALL books in the libraries no matter how explicit they are. Parents should sit down and talk with their children about not picking up those kinds of books if they don't want their child reading them. Yes, I have seen people pick those books up and start making jokes about them, but that's what children do when they're immature. You have to expect that from kids nowadays. No matter how explicit they are, they're informational books and we need them to learn. In conclusion, while censorship may seem like a solution to protect children, it has far - reaching negative consequences and open communication between parents and children is a better approach.

Censorship seems like a great idea at first thought! It allows parents to have their children closely monitored without actually monitoring them. Consequently, censorship in libraries creates the possibility for every book ever written to be removed from shelves around the world. There are multiple things wrong with the idea of censorship. It creates objections due to differences in opinions and authors being completely and utterly offended. Censorship is a disgrace and should not be forced in libraries.   People have different criteria when it comes to deciding a level of offensiveness. For instance, if a fifty - year - old conservative female read a violent book with some curse words and sexual content, she might think that it was offensive. Likewise, if a twenty - one - year - old, carefree male read the exact same book, he would probably enjoy its content. This difference in opinion poses as a huge problem in allowing libraries to censor their selection. I feel that it would be unfair to remove books that some audiences would enjoy.   Instead of completely banning some texts, why not move them to another section of the library? Libraries could take some time to separate the books into categories, and the books that they feel are offensive could go into a separate section of the library. This section could be as simple as a separate shelf, or could go to the extreme of a separate room or area closed in by a curtain. Either way, completely getting rid of books because of their content is a terrible idea.   Authors could potentially lose money from the action of censorship. They put in numerous hours and a great deal of effort to write books and novels. Some spend years trying to perfect their masterpieces. Magazines and movies require the same amount of time, but they also incur an unimaginable amount of money. If these authors, directors, and producers have their specific product taken off of the shelves, it would be offensive to them. They could have a decrease in sales which would cause a decrease in money as well. The idea is simply unfair.   Librarians have the right to display the content of which they choose, but making them remove products that they feel are fine is ridiculous. I think that censorship is a terrible idea. If anything should be banned from a library, it should be censorship itself! In conclusion, censorship in libraries undermines the rights of both creators and consumers, and alternative solutions like sectioning should be considered to preserve the freedom of access to diverse materials.

Censorship  In our daily lives, we often come across things that we consider inappropriate and think should be removed. And is it beneficial for the future of children to keep them away from such materials in stores, libraries, and bookstores?  Most cartoons contain violence. In fact, almost all of them do. In every conflict within these cartoons, violence is often the solution. Children sit down to watch these cartoons without fully understanding that the violence they see is wrong. They may not realize that they shouldn't imitate the violent behavior shown on TV. Similarly, some shows and movies are not suitable for kids.  The same goes for books. Nowadays, kids are attracted to new book series based on movies, like the Twilight series. These books also have elements of violence. If parents were to censor what their children could read, many of these books would be removed from the shelves, especially for young readers.  Newspapers also report on violence. For the safety of children, if they see such reports, they might be curious and want to see if the events are still happening. Children's safety is of utmost importance as we care about their future and the kind of information they consume from books, TV, movies, and newspapers.  All these reasons justify giving parents some control over what their children read, hear, and view on a daily basis. Even though cartoons show violence, children can still watch and enjoy them, but they should not act out the violent scenes or repeat the inappropriate language.  In conclusion, censorship is necessary to protect children from the negative influence of violent and inappropriate materials in various media. By allowing parents to have some say in what their children are exposed to, we can help ensure a healthier and more positive development for the younger generation.

In the literary world of today, it is never hard to find a topic that will interest you. Science fiction, thriller, romance, how to build a car with household materials, and many more topics all await you at your nearest bookstore or library. With this vast array of topics, it isn't that surprising that you will find some authors that have decided to go against the norms of society and write a book that is controversial in the ideas that it presents. These books will often get put on a 'burn list' or censorship list and will be taken off the shelves of the local libraries in order to protect the patrons of those institutions from those books' ideas. Many have argued that this is a way of keeping the society pure, but this censorship of literary works is probably one of the biggest mistakes a civilization can make.  Removing books from the shelves of a library is a form of censorship, which is a clear violation of the Constitution. In the United States, everyone has certain unalienable rights. These were written out in our Constitution as the first ten amendments to the Constitution. One of those rights is the freedom of speech, or the right to voice your opinion. By removing a book from the shelf of a library, you are silencing the author of that book and thus taking away that author's freedom of speech. This clearly violates the Constitution and thus is unconstitutional and illegal in the United States. By violating the Constitution openly, this opens the door for other areas to be violated in the Constitution. The president could act like a dictator, we could turn into a communist - like state, and many other actions are then allowed, leaving the Constitution as a scrap of paper with no meaning. Without the Constitution, the United States is just like any other country and has no direction. This leads to a downward spiral of our society.  The silencing of the voices of authors also stops new ideas from coming into a society. Every year, thousands of new books are introduced to the American public. Many of these have novel ideas that help shape our society for the future. If you take these books off the shelves and out of the public's hands, you effectively stop all change from new ideas in a society. Nothing would ever get better, and the society would stay at the same level that it was when the censorship began.  Censorship can also lead to the downfall of a society. In the novel 'Fahrenheit 451' by Ray Bradbury, the censorship of books has gone so far that all the great literary works of the world are banned. Anyone who is caught reading a book that'makes them think' is locked up or killed. The main character's job as a fireman is not to put out fires, but to set books on fire that encourage people to think. The censorship of that society had gone so far that no one did anything; they just sat at home and watched the television all day. Many people will argue that pornography is something that should be censored out of society, but the problem is once you start censoring, where do you stop? Censoring out pornography would lead to romance novels being censored, which would lead to magic books being censored, and so on until you are censoring out classic literature or the Bible. By censoring out the books and movies that make people think, you quickly lose all interest in higher learning. That is why censorship can quickly lead to the collapse of a society.  Although censorship may seem like a good idea, it is really one of the largest mistakes a society can make. It can lead to the silencing of all the voices of change in a society, causing society to grind to a halt and stay right where it is. Not only is it detrimental to a society, but it is also clearly unconstitutional if you look at the Constitution of the United States. So let us hope that although we may play with the idea of censorship, that we never go down that winding road to nowhere.

Another reason we should refrain from censoring offensive books is that in our society, we are granted the right to express ourselves freely. Subsequently, the fans of the @ORGANIZATION1 series might retaliate by trying to censor the books that the other person likes. If this cycle of censorship continues, we would be left with no books at all. Another crucial reason is that without offensive books, we would never learn from the terrible mistakes of the past. Suppose all books related to both World Wars were censored and made unreadable. Eventually, people would forget the atrocities that occurred, and history might repeat itself. Unless having books that seem offensive is a greater evil than the repetition of the events we dread, offensive books should not be censored. In conclusion, I firmly believe that books found offensive should not be censored because doing so would violate the right to free expression and allow the lessons of the past to be forgotten. In conclusion, we should uphold the freedom of reading and respect everyone's right to choose what they want to engage with.

Should we remove books and media because they are offensive? I do not believe so. In this essay, I will describe to you precisely why I hold this view. The word offensive is a controversial one. Is it the scenes of kissing that render books and media offensive, or is it the use of curse words or depictions of fighting? Different people perceive different things as offensive. Many of the books today's youth read are considered offensive by older generations. This is because today's standards have changed. Children now have more freedom to do and say as they please, causing the meaning of offensive to evolve. If a book, song, or video is offensive, then it is the parents' responsibility to address it with their children. What is offensive to some people may be perfectly acceptable to others. Just because such content exists doesn't mean we have to be exposed to it. So, in conclusion, I firmly believe that books and media should not be removed from the shelf for being offensive, as the concept of offensive is constantly changing and varies from person to person.

In my personal opinion, I am convinced that certain materials, whether in books, music, magazines, or movies, should be removed or edited more carefully. Most parents, including mine, expect their kids to behave with good manners, refrain from using foul language, and avoid making out with their boyfriend or girlfriend at inappropriate times. Yet, we seem to promote such behavior in various forms of media, and that is simply unacceptable. In bookstores or even libraries, there are some books on the shelves that can be deemed inappropriate. We encourage and even urge kids to read, but we can't simply tell them to pick any book they want. These books often contain foul language, gang - related violence, or even sexual gestures that I wouldn't even consider giving to a young niece or a baby cousin. There are numerous types of music in the real world. Everyone has their favorite and least - favorite music. In my view, it's impossible to make everyone happy, so we just have to ignore the music we don't like. There are different formats like CDs, cassette tapes, or even records that we can buy. Yes, I think what some people put in their music is inappropriate, but we can always change the radio station. We don't have to purchase that CD, and we can always drive without listening to music. Magazines can sometimes present rather unseemly content. Whether it's a well - known person on the front page with an odd appearance or certain reality - show - related content. Quite frankly, I don't mind seeing such things in magazines, but strict parents may not want their kids to be exposed to such actions. Magazines can cover a wide range of topics, from someone's drug use, alcohol consumption, to winning the lottery. We just have to choose what we and our kids look at wisely. People can act quite recklessly in their creative expressions. Whether it's in writing, singing, or pictures, there will always be someone doing something inappropriate. This is the reality, and there's not much we can do about it. If you don't want to hear it, don't listen. If you don't want to see it, don't buy it. It's as simple as that.

Censorship in libraries! Do you believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? No, I firmly believe they should not be removed. I believe that everyone is entitled to their own opinion. Just because something is offensive to one person, it may not be offensive to another. No two people think exactly the same or have identical opinions about everything. That's why there is a wide variety of books, music, movies, etc. available. If we were to remove the so - called offensive things, it would likely cause offense to someone else. People need to stop being selfish and understand that everyone is different and has different interests. In conclusion, we should respect the diversity of opinions and keep the variety of materials in libraries, rather than removing them based on individual sensitivities.

Many people, after reading a book, listening to a song, watching a movie, or reading a magazine, have found themselves upset or disturbed by that piece of media and feel that it should be removed from the shelf where they found it. I firmly believe that since everyone has their own unique definition of offensive and disturbing, libraries and media centers should separate such materials from other books, magazines, or media forms. My opinion is that not everyone will find the same things disturbing or offensive. It largely depends on that person's background, religious beliefs, and personal values. I do not think that books, magazines, or other media should have to be banned from library shelves just because a particular person finds that piece of material offensive. If they find it so disturbing, then they should simply stop reading that book or magazine, or listening to that song. One person should not be able to make the decision of keeping or removing a certain book or magazine from the shelf because, somewhere out there, I'm sure there is someone who does not find it offensive. The main purpose of writing a book or creating a song is to express one's opinion on a topic. If the reader or listener does not approve of that opinion, they should respect the director or author's thoughts and move on. If a library or media center has inappropriate books, magazines, or movies, they should create special areas or shelves to store such material. This area could be specifically designated for adult or mature readers, viewers, or listeners. I also think that books and other pieces of media of such inappropriateness should have a clear label regarding its offensive or explicit content. If someone finds a song, book, or magazine article offensive or disturbing, I do not think that a single person has the right to have it removed from the public. There are other ways to keep such material out of a reader or listener's hands, especially those who may not be aware of its possible offensiveness. If warning signs are clearly shown, then the reader or listener should realize that they are taking the risk of being offended or disturbed. If such measures are taken, I am confident that they will keep all readers, viewers, and listeners satisfied.

Every person is unique, and due to this uniqueness, people have a wide range of views as to what is or is not acceptable or offensive. Something that is highly offensive to one person may not be offensive to someone else at all; it is entirely a matter of personal values and beliefs. Libraries house a vast variety of books, music, movies, magazines, and other materials on diverse topics, some of which may not be suitable for everyone. I do not believe that a material should be removed from the shelves just because one person or a group of people find it offensive. The offended group is not being forced to read that book or magazine, listen to that music, or watch that movie. Materials are placed in a library for the public to enjoy, not just to satisfy the preferences of certain individuals. I do believe, however, that materials should be clearly sorted in a library. If they are well - organized, people are less likely to accidentally pick up something that offends them and can completely avoid books, movies, magazines, and music that they don't want to read, watch, or listen to. This can also help protect children from accessing unwanted material. To conclude, materials should not be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. What is offensive to one person, another person might enjoy watching, listening to, or reading. It is impossible to please everyone because every person has different views. However, we can avoid potential conflicts through careful organization. If everything that was found offensive to certain people was taken off the library shelves, there would be hardly anything left. By maintaining a diverse collection and organizing it properly, libraries can serve the needs of a wide range of patrons.

I do not believe that books that are considered offensive should be removed from public libraries. The eye - opening world presented in these books is truly amazing. The fact that I can read about other people's lives and their everyday struggles is astounding to me. If we all made a huge decision based on one person's opinion, then our world would be a mess. Therefore, if all of these 'offensive' books were to be removed, then there would be little left to read that can truly engage us. I want to read something that is going to grab my attention and make me want to keep reading. I do not think that I would have that type of experience if these books were removed. In conclusion, we should respect the diversity of content in public libraries and not hastily remove so - called offensive books.

I believe that censorship is rarely acceptable, and certainly not in libraries, whether at school or otherwise. Censorship prevents knowledge from being obtained, spreading ignorance and intolerance. Libraries and schools are meant to be places that encourage free thinking, discovery, and learning. Censorship stops these important things from occurring. If people are prevented from reading what they want, then many will simply stop reading. Not all children and teens are naturally drawn to reading. If there is a book that a reluctant reader shows interest in, then why would someone want to take it away? Is it because he or she finds it offensive? Or because he or she does not agree with the views expressed? Neither are legitimate reasons for censorship. Most justifications for censorship would not stand the test of time. A great number of books challenged in the past are today considered classics and/or important works, such as To Kill a Mockingbird, The Catcher in the Rye, The Grapes of Wrath, and Fahrenheit 451. To Kill a Mockingbird and its author were censored because of the racist language. This language helps to set the time period in the novels. Also, To Kill a Mockingbird is about a lawyer who defends a wrongly accused black man in the racially - charged South. The main antagonist is an ignorant, racist man. The book itself is not racist, only the villain of the story. Censorship for such reasons is different than not allowing a young child to watch something violent. Preventing a child from seeing a rated R movie or reading a letter to a certain organization is a separate issue from censorship. I define censorship as preventing someone from seeing or reading something due to personal views rather than for the good of the sheltered person. Keep children sheltered when they are young, if one must, but as they grow older and mature, it is essential that they are allowed to mature in their reading as well. If someone lives their life reading only the books others choose for him or her and seeing only the movies and shows chosen for him or her, then he or she will not be his or her own person. Living a sheltered life can catch up to people when they reach adulthood. They will not have their own views and will be largely ignorant of the world around them. John Milton said, 'He who destroys a good book, kills reason itself.' This is what happens to people who have grown up among censorship; they have very little reason. Censorship can mold people, not for the better. People who grow up free to read and watch generally what they wish can turn out differently. These people can have views and values of their own, formed by, among other factors, influential books they have read throughout their life. Many of these people better understand others, promoting tolerance. Censorship takes away all of those wonderful qualities from people. Anyone is capable of possessing them. Censorship cannot be seen as the norm. Libraries and schools should allow children and teenagers to learn and grow. That is the purpose of the institution of education. Therefore, censorship should not even be considered. Students' freedom to read what they desire should be the policy of all schools and libraries. In conclusion, upholding the freedom of reading in educational institutions is crucial for the development of well - rounded individuals.

Should we remove offensive items or materials from a public library? My firm belief is no. In today's society, many people themselves exhibit offensive behavior. In many libraries, there are books, movies, magazines, and a wide variety of other materials. Some of these items are considered inappropriate for certain age groups. However, I firmly believe that every customer in the library should have the freedom to choose what they want to read. It's up to parents or the individual to decide what information they want to absorb.   Let's start with books. There is an incredibly diverse range of books, from scientific works about human anatomy to fictional tales of dragons and vampires. How can one choose a book that is appropriate? The answer is straightforward. When you're young, your parents assist you in selecting suitable books. As you grow and mature, you start making these choices independently. It's entirely up to you whether you should read a particular book.   Movie guidelines follow a similar pattern. In your youth, your parents help you pick appropriate movies. As you grow up, you learn to read about the movie, check its rating. If it seems intimidating, inappropriate, or violent, you can decide whether to watch it.   Sometimes, you may encounter offensive material in movies or books. If you strongly disapprove of it, take the matter to the librarian. Explain why you think the movie or book is inappropriate and offer some suggestions on how to handle the situation. Some ideas could be to remove the item from the shelf, write an additional review for the book, or write to the author or movie director. The simplest solution, though, is to just ignore the offensive item. If it offends you, return it to the library and warn your friends not to check it out. Others might still enjoy the item even if you don't.   There are countless books, movies, magazines, etc. in the world. Some may be deemed inappropriate or offensive, but there are also many other acceptable choices. So, if you don't approve of a certain book, simply return it to the library and find one you do like. In conclusion, maintaining this freedom of choice in libraries is essential for a diverse and inclusive reading and viewing experience.

Should books, music, movies, and magazines be removed if found offensive? Well, I firmly believe that they should be put to a vote for everyone who uses that library to decide. The reason is that the staff might consider an item morally incorrect and offensive, but the people checking out the books may have a different opinion. After all, the staff doesn't read all the books; the customers do.   Some people may not find an item offensive as others do because everyone thinks differently. It's almost impossible for two people to have exactly the same thoughts. If the library removes books for the wrong reasons, it may lose its patrons. Every book has something to teach about life, whether we like it or not.   People have different beliefs. In one culture, a particular book may be widely accepted, and if the local library removes it, those from that culture will miss out on using the library. For example, if the library decides to take out the Bible and romance novels, it will lose a significant number of customers, and its business will suffer.   The library staff should not have the sole power to decide which books are allowed. After all, they may have financial incentives, like getting money from fines. So, my answer is a resounding no. We should put it to a vote, considering that some may not find an item offensive and that people have diverse beliefs. In the end, respecting this diversity of opinion is crucial for the success and relevance of the library.

That would be incredibly sad and you would earnestly want them to see the movie or book you did but they can't. Like what Katherine Paterson said 'All of us think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf.' The second reason is, what if you and your wife or husband had a favorite song, but they took it off the shelves? That would be absolutely devastating, it would just break your heart. Well I know it would break mine if it was our wedding song. The last reason and my favorite reason is, you just have your own opinion. Everyone has their own opinion, if you don't want to see them or look at them just don't do it. It's as easy as that, just try to ignore it. It's really not your problem to worry about. Those are just three reasons why you should not let people remove anything off of any shelves. Like what Katherine Paterson said 'But if i have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' If we let this happen everyone will take advantage of it. That is why I am firmly against letting people remove anything off of any shelves.

Should we censor books in libraries? Katherine Paterson, an esteemed author, once said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This provides a very valid point. If we start taking off books that we find offensive, there will be none left. Books are meant to provide in - depth information and valuable insight into someone's life. If we take away that book, it would be like saying that person's idea did not matter at all. The main reasons why we should not show censorship in libraries are a loss of insight, books, and personal creativity. Books provide unique insight into the author's life. Also, the things that are happening in history significantly affect the author's tone or style, like @ORGANIZATION1. During his lifetime, @CAPS2 was ruled by kings, so if he wanted to be successful, he had to carefully appease the @LOCATION1. It also helped appeasing the @LOCATION1 since he was sponsoring @ORGANIZATION1's plays. Another example of an author influenced by his time and upbringing would be @CAPS3. He was alive during the middle ages, and he constantly witnessed oppressive things like serfs. When he wrote his tales, he made the high - class people sort of mean while he made the lower - caste people on the humbler side. @CAPS3 was not afraid to displease the @LOCATION1. If we start taking off books from shelves in a library that we think are offensive then soon there would not be any as Katherine Paterson said. Where one might find information, another might find it highly offensive and vice versa. Every book would have someone say it was offensive. It might be the context or the tone or even the person who wrote it; it does not matter. Sometimes the books that are the most informative are the ones that are offensive. However sometimes it is good to have offensive things in books. It builds the tone and mood of the story or character. It might create a certain vivid image. It also teaches us not to do what these people are doing. The books sometimes show us a depressing ending of a person who lived a vulgar or criminal life. These stories teach us life lessons. Yes sometimes I read a book that I find offensive, but I have learned that if I do not like it does not mean someone else does not. It would not be fair then to take off a book that someone might have learned something from just because you do not like it. I am sorry, the world does not revolve solely around you and me. It revolves us as a whole, and if someone starts taking off books, who is to stop someone else from doing the same. It would not be fair. Finally, if we started taking off books, it would start influencing kids in thinking it was okay to throw away someone's creativity. It would also make them think that their ideas would not matter and no one would be able to appreciate them. I for one do not like doing things, if they might offend someone. I could not imagine what it would be like in that type of society. Books are important to have. They teach us about events or people who were before our time or problems some people experience. It is important to be aware of what is going on around you. I grew up ignorant of big problems that were occurring in society. My parents tried to shield me from the bad news and creeps in society. Reading books is what opened my eyes to what life is really like. So taking off books from shelves would have hindered the process of me growing up. I would still be that ignorant little child thinking that life ends in a happily ever after. Unfortunately most do not, but there are some that have a happy life. That is what books are for, to teach people about other people's experiences, the good and the bad. So @PERSON2 was wise in her observation. Who is to stop someone from taking off books once this process has started?

When you are taking your little kid to the library because they're eager to get a book, you might think 'hmmm, there isn't anything bad at the library; it's all educational books.' @CAPS1, how would you feel if your child wanted to check out a movie there? A little girl could be with her mom in the adult section of the library, and they might come across some things you wouldn't want them to see. A child could easily spot that and not understand what it means, but that image would stay in their head for a long time. A couple could go into the library hoping to find a good, healthy, funny movie but might stumble upon a movie that makes them uncomfortable. An older person could try to find some music from their era, but when they get it, all of it is about drugs, sex, or even alcohol.     The magazines always have girls half - clothed, even in Seventeen magazine. The car magazines feature girls modeling in front of the cars to make them more appealing. You can get a baby magazine that shows a mom breast - feeding. You might have just wanted to look at it because of the babies, but you or your child don't want to see a mom breast - feeding.     The library is a very resourceful place, and you can obtain very good information about various things there. However, they also have some bad aspects. I think the music that talks about personal and bad things should be in its own separate area. The same goes for the magazines, movies, and books; they should all be in a room together, away from the rest of the items in the library. There should be an age limit to enter that room, and they should inform you about the type of content inside before you go in.     I'm not saying the library is a bad place for kids, teens, or anyone. I just believe that certain books, music, and magazines should be stored in a different location instead of being out in the open where everyone can see them. This way, the library can maintain its educational value while protecting the sensibilities of all its visitors.

Like Katherine Paterson said, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. I think that if something is a problem for only some people and not everyone, why can't we just separate the items into sections? That way, there would be no problems. By having separate sections, those who are bothered by certain items can avoid them, while others can still access what they like. Censorship is a very sensitive topic. There are so many things people dislike, so they censor certain aspects, hiding the ideas from those who aren't aware of them. I personally detest censorship. I would rather the world be an educated place with minor dangers than a place where everything is kept secret and seemingly safe.     You must be thinking, 'There are some things we have to censor; certain topics can harm our children's minds.' But in truth, your children will find out about these things in the real world eventually anyway.  In reality, drugs, alcohol, sex, rape, violence, and all the other things you censor are common occurrences that your kids will hear about. Most children first hear about these topics in school, usually in elementary school, and if not, they will definitely find out in junior high. If they will eventually find out regardless, wouldn't it be better to let them find out the easy way?     Now you must be thinking, 'But if they find out too young, it could traumatize them.' That is a risk, but most teenagers are more traumatized when exposed to these topics without any prior knowledge. If they already know what they're dealing with, they would know how to react. However, if they have no knowledge of what's going on, they could make a major mistake without even realizing it. Once again, wouldn't it be better for them to find out from you or a book rather than finding out the hard way?     Now, you might be thinking, 'Our children must be protected; this knowledge could just put them in more danger.' It might put them in more danger; there's always a possibility. The world is full of possibilities, though, and anything could happen. This knowledge that you always hide from them might be what they need to know later on, and they won't know when they need it. What would they do if they see their friends start doing drugs, and since they have never heard of drugs, they don't know it's a bad thing to do? Or if they see older kids drinking and are offered a drink but don't know they shouldn't accept it? Or if they wind up kissing someone they like, and the situation goes too far, but they don't know what they're doing?      Anything could happen, and your children need to be prepared. If they don't know about these things, they can't tell if what they're doing is good or bad, and they might wind up getting in trouble or hurt. By sharing this knowledge in a proper way, we can help them make informed decisions and be better prepared for the real world.

Katherine Paterson wrote, ''If I had the right to remove that book from the shelf, that work I abhor, then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else.'' This quote highlights an important aspect of freedom of speech. Having the right to do something is almost a part of freedom of speech. It's about believing in the decision or choice you have made. If I were to reflect on my views on censorship in libraries, we all would have that same opportunity to state our opinion about what we feel should not be included. There could be inappropriate books in the library that we absolutely would not want our younger siblings reading. The best thing is to ask ourselves: Should we have the right to take away our kids' freedom and right to read, listen to, and access updated media and publications when we had it? Should we really put a censorship on the libraries? I feel that censoring a library would not be necessary considering a library is a manual guide of history. Our libraries are organized from A to Z in authors' names, separated into non - fiction and fiction. CDs are separated in one section, movies in another, and there are also sections for magazines, with adult books and children's books separated in different areas. What would a book hurt them when there are plenty of bad influences, peer pressure, violence, and sexual publicity everywhere, and especially in the media. It would not be fair at all for us to rob our kids of the chance to read and learn from books. I feel no, we should not take away our children's learning opportunities. Growing up as a kid, I loved being able to go to the library. It helped to enhance my vocabulary, spelling, and I learned plenty of new words. The books I read growing up weren't perfectly clean, but I could relate to a lot of the books I chose as a kid. So, no, I feel we should not censor libraries. We need them to be a fun place for our children and us to go to for learning, fun, comfort, and more. We can't take that from our generation; it just would not be right.

Censorship. When was the last time someone told you what you could, and couldn't do? Especially if it was something you didn't want to do. How'd that make you feel? You probably didn't want to do it, did you? Censorship is somewhat the same way. The other day, my friends and I wanted to go see a new movie that just came out. We weren't allowed to see it though. You know why? Due to censorship, we weren't old enough to be able to see this movie. So, now the only way we'll be able to see this movie is if our parents go with us. Have you ever had your parents go with you and your friends to a movie? It doesn't go so well, does it. Censorship violates freedom of being different. You can't listen to music, watch movies, or even read certain books, unless you're of a certain age. That's not fair. Censorship is like a modern - day dictator. It tells you what you can and can't do, how you can dress, and what to say. Everybody would be the same then. How did the dictator do with his idea? He failed miserably. How do you think the oppressed victims felt? They were punished for believing, or doing something different. They weren't hurting anybody; they just wanted to live their lives a different way. That's what censorship is doing, classifying people into certain groups, telling them what they can and can't see, do, or listen to. That's what makes the world different, people that are different. Don't make everyone be the same; we should cherish our diversity and oppose unnecessary censorship.

The content written, sung, or played in these things might seem to harm these people, but that is not what it is there for. The things that might seem harmful are in there to show people in the younger generations how life was lived in the older days, such as the era of slaves. This would also have an impact on children who use this library. If this literature was taken out, children might think that things have always been the way they are as they see it. If these children grew up and were to see a book, hear a song, or watch a movie about how things were in the olden days, and how much it has changed, then they might never believe it because they were not taught as children. As they are older, they might still never have the interest to learn about these types of things because they never knew about them growing up. These things are written to teach people and children about how things used to be; they are not used to harm people. When people take these things as harmful, they are not getting the true meaning that the author had in mind when they wrote them. Libraries should keep these pieces of literature on their shelves, only to teach young people of what the world has come from, how their older relatives lived, and what they came from. In this way, libraries can fulfill their educational purpose and preserve cultural heritage.

Are there truly universally evil books that no one should read? Are good and bad no longer matters of opinion for the readers themselves? The answer is a resounding no. There is always something we can potentially learn from books, and it's never right to take that away. Freedom of speech should certainly come into play here as well, allowing the authors' words to be heard without interference from those who would dictate what we read. There is a reason libraries have many sections. They have to cater to the individual tastes of the masses, without regard to what other people find offensive. If one was to go through the library and burn every book they did not like, there would be scarcely anything left. Send in another person with different tastes, and then you have a completely empty library. It is far better to leave all the books alone so that everyone can find something to enjoy reading. Basically, there are bound to be people who have similar opinions to the author of just about anything, so allow the authors to share those opinions and let readers make their own choices. Then we have the knowledge portion of the issue. Offensive material to one person might be what another person wants or needs to read, whether for recreation or class. There is much to be learned in the way of psychology and human nature from almost any writing. Perhaps a restricted section would be in order if the problem would involve corruption of innocent minds, but a full - scale censor would never be necessary. Finally, there is an amendment in the Constitution of the United States for preventing censorship. It is unconstitutional to restrict any form of expressive speech, whether it be books, movies, music, or magazines. And what is more restrictive to an author than to have their books banned? We would be moving towards a society that suppresses the free flow of information and thought. In short, censorship is a harmful practice that should never be used. People all have their own opinions, all media can be learned from, and our freedom should not be restricted. The practice of censorship is what should truly be banned from the shelves, as it undermines the very foundation of a free and democratic society.

Censorship is one of many important issues facing the world today. Many argue that materials considered offensive are damaging to society, and should not be tolerated. They claim that such materials can spread harmful ideas and corrupt the minds of the public. Others believe that freedom of speech is a universal right that should extend to any and all forms of human expression. They think that people should be able to express and access diverse thoughts. The issue is further complicated by the concept of what is and is not appropriate for children. Are there materials that are acceptable for adults, but not kids? Questions such as this have plagued humanity for hundreds of years, and there is no simple solution. Today, so many people think of censorship as a bad word. In fact, there is nothing inherently wrong with the concept of censorship. It is only when people begin to abuse their power and censor materials that should not be censored that problems arise. For example, many countries have restrictions on selling and owning copies of '@PERSON2,' the book that @PERSON1 wrote as a sort of mission statement for @LOCATION1. While many of the ideas contained within the book are horribly offensive, it still should not be censored. People have the right to read the book and form their own opinions on @PERSON1's teachings; it is not the government's place to decide for them. While oppressive dictatorship and mass - murder are crimes, reading about them is not. There are few materials available that should rightfully be censored and taken out of adult hands. If someone understands what they are reading, and are able to form an educated opinion on the material, then nobody has the right to stop them from expanding their knowledge, or expressing themselves by creating similar material. However, the issue changes completely when one considers children. If adults want to view pornography, or read accounts of extreme violence, that is their business. However, those concepts are obviously inappropriate for children, and any decent parent wouldn't want their young kids filling their heads with such things. Children need to be slowly and gently introduced to these concepts so they can fully understand them. In the case of children, careful censorship is necessary for healthy development. When it comes to libraries, there are very few materials that should be banned. If libraries are meant to be places of learning, then one has no right to limit the information they contain. However, that does not mean there should not be any limitations. Libraries should offer a children's section, as many do, that would contain materials only appropriate for youngsters. Then, it becomes the parents' responsibility to ensure that their child stays in that section. When a parent believes the child is ready to explore the adult section, they are free to take their kid there. This system gives parents the ability to keep their children away from harmful material, without taking it out of the hands of adults. Many would argue that unsupervised children could gain access to inappropriate material, but that is really an issue that needs to be handled by parents, not the library. After all, it's better that a few kids see something they shouldn't have than all adults have to read censored material. In conclusion, censorship is a concept that has its place in society, but must be used very carefully. When the goal is to protect people, especially children, from harmful material, it can be used sparingly. However, when those in power use censorship to attack ideas they disagree with, it becomes a form of oppression. Above all else, people must be free to educate themselves, form their own opinions, and express themselves.

When I was in fifth grade, chaos broke out in my community. Everyoneteachers, students, parents, school board members, community leadershad something to say about the topic at hand. This topic was censorship. A high schooler's parents were outraged that their daughter had read *The @ORGANIZATION1 @ORGANIZATION1* in class. In these parents' opinion, the rape scene in the book was far too disturbing for their precious daughter. While this seemed a fair stance to take, the parents then took things a step further. They sought to ban the book in the schools in our township, wanting to spare all other children the experience of being exposed to what was clearly traumatic material. This crusade of theirs posed the questions 'What can and should be censored? And when?'. As the debate continued, I myself began to ponder the subject. Who had the right to tell me what I could read? Or listen to? Or watch? The answer I came to was 'no one'. No one has the right to censor anyone else. This comes with one exception: parents and children. Parents have the responsibility to monitor their children. They must use their best judgment to decide what their children are old enough and mature enough to hear, see, or read. This was true in the censorship of *@ORGANIZATION1*, as well. No one fought back against the family because they did not want their own child to read the novel; it was only once they tried to keep others from the book that the problem arose. This is why libraries should not remove materials from their shelves because they are, in the eyes of some, offensive materials. Music you love might be offensive to me. Books your teacher assigned might not be appropriate for five - year - olds. Your friends might be offended by your favorite movie or TV show. These feelings are subjective; almost nothing is universally offensive or universally appropriate. We must, as a society, be able to accept this. We learn through what we see, what we hear, and what we read. These experiences teach us what to do, as well as teach us what not to do. Because of this, it would be unfair for materials to be removed from libraries based on solely opinions. To do that would be to steal from community members their chance to learn. Parents have the right to censor what their children see, hear, and read, but even this censorship must be done carefully in order to not hinder the child's ability to learn. We must not hinder our children's ability to learn from the mistakes of book and movie characters, singers, comedians, and artists. If we do take away that ability, we are setting these future adults up for making mistakes that could have been prevented by allowing them the chance to learn. Removing materials from the shelves of libraries based solely on opinions is not only damaging to our society, but, ultimately, it is dangerous to the people we wish to protect.

To censor, or not to censor? That is the question. Undoubtedly, there are numerous different views on this topic. Everyone will present valid points for either using or not using censorship in libraries. I don't think it's very offensive at all. There are movies and materials specifically designed for a mature and older age group. This is perfectly acceptable; if a person is of the appropriate age, they should have the freedom to choose advanced material. A mature individual won't want to read elementary - level books throughout their life. Eventually, they need to be introduced to real - life content. Sheltering them for their entire lives won't benefit them or society.  If the person is a child, there should generally be no reason for them to select older - level material. There may be times when a child does choose such material, but this isn't a problem. Parents can simply explain to the child that they are not old enough yet. It's an easy solution. Libraries are meant to assist us in learning, not hinder it. I'm sure I'm not the only one who is satisfied with the current state of libraries and sees no need for change. In conclusion, censorship in libraries is not only unnecessary but also detrimental to the free flow of knowledge and the rights of readers.

Censorship in libraries is an almost primitive, if not childish, way of excluding what one might consider offensive from everyone else, isn't it? Think about it. A kid who refuses to let another kid play with him at recess just because of a minor incident in math class the previous day seems rather childish, and there are many more reasonable solutions that come to mind with just a bit of thought. This situation is similar to censorship in libraries.  A book is meant to be read, which is an obvious fact. But why do we read books? To gain information, learn something new, or expand our existing knowledge. For example, if you want to know how to cook an exquisite meal or graph linear equations, you can find relevant books. Is it fair for an astronomy enthusiast who has no interest in cooking to remove a book on cooking a turkey from the library? Of course, cooking a turkey is unlikely to be offensive to library - goers, but consider this: the fact that a book has been written means it's not offensive to at least one person, the author.  There will always be things that people don't agree with. Just when you think you've found something that everyone likes, someone will come along and disrupt the harmony. Not everyone likes rap music, but it still plays on the radio. Listening to it is a matter of free choice, just like reading a book, regardless of its content. Just because someone accidentally encounters offensive material and expresses their dissatisfaction to the library staff doesn't mean the material should be discarded.  Let's further compare radios and libraries. Radios have specific channels for different types of music. There's a country - music channel for those who love country music. In libraries, while there is the Dewey Decimal System, categorization could be more detailed. Suppose books were further distinguished by their location within the library. Specific areas could be designated for different genres. That way, if someone finds books about a particular topic, like concentration camps, distasteful, they can avoid the relevant aisle in the history section. Problem solved. It's hard to be offended by something you can't even see.  You see, outright removal isn't the best way to satisfy dissatisfied people. Compromise is the key. After thinking about this situation for more than a moment, I'm sure you can come up with more reasonable solutions than the ludicrous idea of censorship. In the end, the goal is for people to enjoy books without being offended by the ones they don't like.

We all find things offensive, whether it's in a book, magazine, movie, CD, TV show, or a newspaper article. Then, fewer people would be offended, and they wouldn't have any concerns about letting their children pick out books independently. However, it may not be the writers' fault. It could be the readers. Some people should stop taking everything so seriously. Then, they wouldn't have to worry about what their children are reading.   Yes, most adult - oriented content is inappropriate for children, but that's why it's intended for adults. Children have their own selection of books and movies. All types of entertainment are categorized by age, and people should start paying more attention to these categorizations. If parents start monitoring what their kids do, they won't have to worry about their children reading or watching something they shouldn't. That's what parents are supposed to do: take care of their children, and some people don't do a very good job of it.   If there's a book you read and you don't want your child to read it, it's likely something you read when you were older. So, don't worry about it until they reach that age. Maybe by then, it would be okay for them to read it because they're old enough to distinguish right from wrong. Parents can't always control what their children do. And if their children happen to pick up a book their parents never wanted them to read, they may view it differently from their parents and learn a very valuable lesson from it. In conclusion, a combination of responsible writing, parental supervision, and allowing children some freedom to explore can create a healthy reading environment.

If a person wants to check out a book that could offend another individual, technically, by the law, they have the right to do so. Conflicting works of art, such as thought - provoking books, soul - stirring music, and captivating movies, have long been fixtures in libraries. Whether it's a controversial political book or a music album with radical lyrics, someone is bound to be offended. But the question of whether these potentially offending works should be banned is a hot - button topic among authors, musicians, and movie - goers. I firmly believe that all these works deserve to be seen, heard, or read, as the creator has poured their heart and soul into expressing their opinion and has the right to freedom of the press.  You could pick any well - known work, and there's a chance someone will be offended by it because it goes against their deeply held beliefs. However, this doesn't mean the work should be banned! Banning a book is a complete rejection of the author's thoughts and opinions, and everyone has the right to those. The censorship of any work is unconstitutional as citizens of the United States have total freedom of the press. You simply can't impose censorship because, regardless of whether the work stays on the shelves, someone will be offended. Also, as Ray Bradbury's Fahrenheit 451 shows, the censorship of books could lead to a society that lacks a true understanding of the past and the feelings and thoughts of people from that era.  To me, 'offensive' books, movies, and music aren't bad; they're catalysts for debate. They enable you, not just the author, to voice your feelings about what's presented in the works. But eliminating the opportunity for debate would be a disaster. Gloria Steinem once said that 'if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf...then you also have exactly the same right and so does everybody else.' By saying this, she's highlighting that if we all went into a library and removed the books, magazines, movies, or music we don't like, there'd be nothing left. Every work would be removed because at least one person is offended by each one. Therefore, allowing books to be read, music to be listened to, and movies to be watched is granting everyone the freedom to write down their thoughts or stances.  The censorship of any work, anywhere, is stifling ideas. These ideas are what drive society forward, making us think and helping us form our opinions. By allowing the free flow of these ideas, we're nurturing future generations of great thinkers. In this case, by keeping books, magazines, and music on the shelves, we can continue to 'learn from the past' and make use of the information and ideas that have shaped history.

If censorship isn't carefully observed, we could anger foreigners or make our children become violent and reckless because of the inappropriate films on the shelves. And people from other countries might never return to our libraries if they pick up a book they thought was interesting but turns out to be offensive in their opinion. Censorship is very important in libraries and on the shelves to ensure a positive and appropriate environment for all.

If someone is offended by a book or a movie from a library, should they be able to get it removed? In the following, I'll explain my opinion on censorship in libraries.  If some parents come across a book they find offensive and think their children shouldn't be able to access it from the library, they can simply forbid their children to read it. I also think that when the library is selective about the books it acquires and doesn't have certain inappropriate books, that should satisfy other people.  So, all in all, I don't think people should be able to remove certain books because everyone has their own view on what's offensive and what isn't. We all should have the freedom to read or see what we want, not what others think we should. By respecting this freedom, we can maintain a diverse and inclusive library environment.

In conclusion, censorship should be allowed in libraries because of the wide - range audience, public materials, and the strong opinions of the people. Does censorship solve any problems? If one person wants to censor something in a library, there is bound to be another person on the other side of that argument trying to protect that work from being taken away. As a free country, it is every individual's right to take in whatever form of literature or music that they find pleasing. History has shown the world that censorship leads those in power down a dark road. The shielding of offensive materials is only necessary and fair when the young, impressionable minds of the world's youth are at stake. But once a person is old enough to make informed decisions, it should be their prerogative to choose their own material. Censorship is unacceptable on the grounds of personal rights and how it has affected history, but necessary when protecting the young. It is a person's right to choose what kind of literature they would like to read. If someone does not like a book and it becomes banned from a library, then everyone will want to have a book that they do not like banned. For example, take a hypothetical public library: a public library is an open, free place where men, women, and children of any background can come to learn and enjoy themselves with a good book, magazine, or music. It presents a great mental image of serenity and peace. How does this picture appear to a bystander once books begin to disappear off of the shelves? Suddenly, right and left, books are disappearing as if by magic: a certain book is disapproved of by mothers, a religious group does not like the message this book sends, and this book makes people sad. Before long, there are not very many books left in this hypothetical library other than books for toddlers. With this system, everyone suffers. Everyone should retain their right to read what they would like to. It would all just be simpler if books were just not banned from libraries. History has given the world many a cruel dictator. Oftentimes, once he comes to power, he is not the most popular of governmental forms. To keep his subjects under his rule, often he has to resort to taking away civil rights. This could be a curfew, fake elections, or censorship. If the ruler has the power of censorship, he or she can control what the public thinks, feels, and believes. With this power over them, the people are weakened and often abused. Now imagine that censorship occurring in a country that has civil rights. People would not stand for it. So why begin censorship in an area that promotes freedom? There is absolutely no need for censorship to occur, and as history has shown, it certainly is not a good thing. Censorship is unacceptable in all forms in a free country that promotes civil rights. There is, however, one other element at play here: protection of youth and innocence. Almost everyone can remember a time as a child when they were young and innocent, free of worry and trouble. That can disappear in an instant. Children should not be exposed to things that are inappropriate for their age. Nearly every movie nowadays has violent and risque, if not full - blown adult, materials present in it. The age of innocence is getting younger every generation, and children are becoming conditioned to this material to an extreme point. A claim like this might sound hypocritical coming from the mouth of one against censorship, but it is not 'censorship' when one is protecting the young. Due to personal rights and what history has shown the world, censorship should never be tolerated unless on the grounds of protecting children. It is each person's choice of what they would like to read and absorb, so their choices should not be infringed upon. The world has seen on several occasions what censorship can do to people. Also, children should be protected, and that is not censorship. Censorship solves no problems, but it makes everyone unhappy. Therefore, we should carefully balance the need for freedom of choice and the protection of the young, ensuring that neither is overly compromised.

There are many books, music, movies, and magazines in the world. Some are humorous, historic, or romantic; however, some are offensive in some way. People, perhaps during a certain month like March (@MONTH1), get offended when they read or listen to certain things, but does that mean that those things should be removed from the shelf? Some people in that month might find something offensive while another person does not. Therefore, the music, books, movies, or magazines should not be removed from the shelves. If a person thinks that a song should be removed from the shelf and it does get removed, what about the person who did not find it offensive? People are entitled to their own thoughts and feelings. However, that doesn't mean that one person's feelings are better than someone else's. If everyone tried to make everyone happy, then there wouldn't be a lot of options to choose from in the library. If one person finds something offensive in a book, another person might find another book that is offensive, and it goes on until there aren't any books left. With entertainment, it is hard to please everyone. No matter what it is, there will always be at least one person who doesn't like it. This, however, does not mean that it should be removed from shelves. If one person does find it offensive, then there is most likely someone else who doesn't. The people who don't find something offensive want to be satisfied, too. It is impossible to please everyone, so what should be done? If someone finds something offensive, they shouldn't read or listen to it. People can choose to quit listening to a song, quit watching a movie, or quit reading a book or magazine that they, in a particular month, might find offensive. They have the right and freedom to not pay any attention to it. This way, the person who isn't offended can still enjoy their choices of entertainment at the library. If I find something offensive, I try not to pay attention to it. There are many books or songs that I do find offensive, so I just avoid those. By avoiding these books or songs, I don't offend anyone else by taking away something that they might enjoy. I still am satisfied, and so are they. The library workers know what they are doing. If the library takes away a book because some people find it offensive, then they might be offending those people who didn't find it offensive by basically saying that their morals are better than yours. A library should take a book or magazine out if it feels necessary, but not to please certain customers because then they aren't pleasing the other customers and could offend them. People have the right to voice their feelings, but that doesn't mean that they are always right and that certain things should be changed because of them. It is impossible to make everyone completely satisfied, but there are compromises. The libraries shouldn't remove things off their shelves but should give more options that won't be offensive, and people should avoid the things that they find offensive.

Libraries have always been an outstanding source for information. Among the myriad of resourceful materials provided by libraries are books, movies, and magazines. Recently, the debate over whether libraries should censor offensive materials has caused quite a stir. Many parents argue that they don't want their children to be exposed to explicit materials, especially books, exhibited in public libraries. Others have retorted to this statement by saying that if every book that is viewed as offensive is taken off the shelves, the shelves would be nearly empty. Author Katherine Paterson stated, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children have taken off the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right, and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us' (Katherine Paterson). Books that are offensive should not be removed from libraries for the simple reason that they are still one of the most reliable sources for information and historical events, and, without books, society would suffer. The most important reason as to why people shouldn't be allowed to remove offensive books from shelves is that if every person was allowed to remove a book that he/she found offensive, there wouldn't be many books remaining on the libraries' shelves. There are many historical works that contain offensive images and content, but people have to overlook this because these books are accounts of our history. Without them, society would forget about the past events that shaped and molded our world into the world it is today. For example, some old historical records might have offensive language used at that time, but they are crucial for understanding the social context. Another important reason why library censorship is wrong is that material that one person, say in a particular month like June (@MONTH1), finds to be offensive may not be offensive to another. Every person has his/her own view on certain matters and events. For this reason, the censorship of a certain book shouldn't come down to the opinion of one individual. Rather, the decision to take a certain book off of library shelves should come from the opinions of a large group of individuals. By doing so, a fair representation is achieved. In most cases, most books are meant to tell either fictional stories or historical events that aren't meant to offend anyone. Fictional books are meant to fill the mind of whoever reads them with tales and mental images of a story created by the author. Also, historical books are meant to capture the events of our past so that people can be able to look back on these events both now and in the future. In all, the idea of censoring libraries is a negative proposal. Books were meant to provide historical accounts and fictional stories to enrich the minds of readers, not poison them with bad content. Everyone has their own views, which is why people should learn to respect the views of different books no matter how offensive the material might be to them.

With the world having a rich and wide - ranging variation of cultures, languages, beliefs, and races, it's quite evident that there is no doubt that different subjects will be offensive to some individuals and not to others. Books, songs, magazines, and movies all have specific purposes as to why they were created. This could be to entertain, inform, or persuade. People frequently use libraries as a reliable source to access these works. Many people visit libraries every day, either to conduct in - depth research or simply to gain knowledge for the sheer joy of it. My firm opinion is that any type of material, no matter what it precisely contains, should be able to be found on a library shelf. A library is a place where one should be able to freely find a book, CD, video, or magazine on any subject that piques their interest.   If our libraries took out every item that was offensive to someone, there would simply be no library left. Any item you read or listen to will have a word, a sentence, or a meaning that will offend a person in some way. This is because many of the items you will come across will be in some way biased. The way an author tries to entertain might also offend you if they use a certain language with a particular tone. Persuasion is also biased towards one side and you might not agree with the side the author chooses. The same goes for informing. You might think the author needed to address a certain point more thoroughly than he or she did. All of these purposes of writing will be offensive to someone.   I once was in a library and read a magazine that was talking negatively about teenage drivers. The article was obviously biased and did not have any teen sources to prove that not all teen drivers are bad. This article deeply offended me, but I am glad I read it as it allowed me to see a different point of view. Not everyone wants to see the different points to a story, but if you happen to run across one of these items that offend you, you can simply put it back down on the shelf. You are not required to read or listen to any item that you do not want to see or hear. However, there is going to be someone who needs to use that item for personal knowledge or for research. This is why all items need to be available to the public.   If someone does find an item offensive though, they should be able to request that a label be put on the item to further warn other readers. Likewise, if there is an item rated 'Mature' there needs to be an age limit set to protect our young readers and listeners. With these changes set, our libraries could make everyone happy.   With libraries being found in most communities, there is going to be discussion on the contents of the items they carry. While you might like a book, I might find it offensive. Even though I might have a problem with an item, it still needs to be able to be accessed by all people. The point of a library is to carry items which will benefit the public. It is the right of any human to be able to go to a library and be able to read about any subject he or she wants. Any item, whether biased or not, should be able to be found on the shelves of a library. Those who do not agree with or want to read an item should simply stay away from that section and choose a different item which interests them. We need to be able to go to a library and find what we need or want to see or hear. This is how a library serves a community, by providing a diverse range of materials for all to access.

As a place used to gain knowledge and wisdom, a library is truly a wonderful and invaluable resource. Multiple varieties of books can be found at a local library, ranging from documentaries to science - fiction or just plain fiction. The most amazing part of a library is the fact that one can freely choose what he or she reads. Yet if one man opposes the view in one book and firmly believes a certain book should be removed from the library, then the precious freedom of choice is lost. The selection of reading should be open to every reader, and although some might disagree, heavy censorship of libraries is an unnecessary measure that severely constricts the ability to gain knowledge.  In today's society, many people differ greatly in taste or genre. So much so, that at times it is extremely hard to find a common ground in a large group setting. The library is a place where people should be able to enjoy their differences, leisurely reading different types of books spread across many shelves. Yet if one person dislikes a book, their opinion should not influence the removal of the book due to their personal preference. Author Katherine Paterson made a wise remark on the idea of censorship saying, 'If I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-- that work I abhor-- then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books'(no pag.). If one person finds a work to be vulgar and believes it should be removed from the library, then what stops another person from removing a book that they dislike? If heavy censorship is allowed in libraries, then libraries will become diminished resources, only containing a few documents.  Still, censoring age - specific materials is necessary in libraries. Allowing a child to read or watch a movie or book that is inappropriate is an inexcusable action. Censoring books for children does not mean removal of said book though. Removing a book from the shelf of a library is just as wrong as allowing a child to read a book that is too mature for his or her age. Katherine Paterson stated, 'All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But... then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.'(no pag.). The censoring of books in a library cannot lead to the removal of books that have shaped our society and ideas, even if it is to protect a child. A medium must be found between true censorship and opinionated removal of books, due to one's beliefs. Doing so will not only help libraries thrive but also contribute positively to society as a whole.
