One of the amendments in the Constitution of the United States is freedom of speech. This crucial amendment grants the freedom of speech to anyone who has something meaningful to say, as long as what they have to say doesn't infringe upon the rights of others. It has been a long time since the Constitution of the United States was signed, but even today, there are still lingering questions on the subject. Should people be allowed to censor books? This is a matter that has been hotly disputed throughout the long history of humans and has been a topic of great controversy for many years. Some assert that one should have the right to censor a book that they find offensive. However, if one were to take the time to carefully think about the issue, they would see that if everyone had the right to censor a book they despised, there would be no books left in the world. In a population that encompasses so many different cultures and ethnicities and reaches to almost every corner of the globe, writing a book that everyone could enjoy and not find offensive could be an almost impossible task. We in the United States live in a very diverse society, and literature has, over the decades and centuries, adapted to the different types of customs, cultures, and religions so that anyone can find a book that they enjoy. The way of life that one leads might be different from that of others, but one should respect and accept the different ways of living, just as literature has. It's like being in school; there have many times been that one student that the rest of the class sees as really different. Our teachers taught us to be kind and accept that student for who they were and that not everyone is the same. Even after this and many other articles have been written about the topic, it will still remain a topic of much debate. This is because everyone is unique and has their own opinions. Some say it's a great idea, and others say everyone is entitled to their own ways of living. However, the issue will persist because, after all, we are all different and have our own viewpoints.

I think that censorship in libraries is and is not a good idea because some people wouldn't get to read the books they truly want to. I'm really into reading World War II books, along with a wide selection of other genres. If they take those away just because they're considered offensive, I'd be left with nothing to read. If I find a book I think is offensive, I simply put it back on the shelf and don't pick it up. I believe they should assign age ratings to books, like stating this book is for ages 12 and above, and especially to movies and magazines. This is because kids don't need to read or see certain inappropriate things. Books and movies sometimes contain references to drugs, alcohol, and murder. I don't think music is a major concern because music, on its own, isn't very influential. But music videos are sometimes inappropriate. Movies sometimes go too far, and I wouldn't want my kids watching such movies. So, I wouldn't mind if they take those offensive movies off the shelves. I don't think books should be removed from the shelf because parents should be aware of what their kids are reading anyway. I would at least thoroughly check the book or magazine before getting it for my kids, and other parents should do the same. There will always be offensive books and movies, so it's the parents' responsibility to ensure their kids don't get hold of such kinds of books or magazines.

I think other materials in libraries such as music and art should remain actively available in public libraries or school libraries. They vividly show symbolic meaning to the ever - evolving world as we know it. People hold different beliefs about anything. I firmly believe that, no matter what you say, everybody still has a distinct opinion about anything and everything. So, it's fine to just keep believing what you want to believe, but don't spoil it for others. You've probably heard the saying, '' if you don't have anything nice to say then don't say anything at all.'' Well, they should remember that saying and adhere to it. In my years of being in school, nobody has ever protested about certain reading materials in public libraries because everyone got to read what they liked as the library provided people with the material they wanted to read. Let's assume a person wanted to read a book about the fall of the Berlin Wall. If the library says they do not and will not carry such reading material about this important history, the person will be understandably angry. Even though they can find the book somewhere else, they should still be able to locate that book in that library. That is significant history in this world, and people should be aware of it. This situation is comparable to people wanting to destroy history made in this world, history that people risked their lives for to be recognized. This fully relates to the topic at hand. I sincerely hope that this essay will make the protesters think twice about the topic they're arguing about. That will be all.

I believe that libraries should not censor their literature. All of our media is like a vast and rich fountain of knowledge, eagerly waiting to be discovered. No one should have the authority to decide what is appropriate for the public to know. The right to determine what is and is not appropriate for us should not be in the hands of libraries. That right should firmly remain with every single individual, so they can make the decision about what's right for them. Over the last thousands and thousands of years, media has grown at an astonishing rate through various forms like books, music, movies, and magazines. With all this diverse media, we've learned numerous things that we still use today from past trials and failures. Media is something that's always present and serves as a constant reminder of our past mistakes, ensuring that they don't happen again. The amazing thing about all the media we have today is that we haven't even scratched the surface of what we can and will learn from it. Some of our media might not be the most appropriate things ever, but we can still glean a great deal from it. It might upset some people, and if it does, then they should stay away from it. It's not right to get rid of certain parts of media because what one person might find immoral and wrong, someone else might be able to learn something valuable from it. If you're offended by some of the material, you should avoid it, not get rid of it for everyone. Our media is extremely powerful and should not be censored. Media has an unbelievable impact on the world, so we should not attempt to hide some of it. We've not even seen half of what media can achieve.

Do I believe that certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive? No, it should not be removed. Katherine says, ' I have the right to remove that book from the shelf, that work I abhor.' First of all, she can have the right to do that but there are people who have a say in this. There are people who can freely read, listen, watch, and see what they like. Definitely, I really think that it should not be removed even though it doesn't have positive things. Although, it might offend some people, they have a choice whether they should see, watch, listen, and read it. Many people might agree with the author about what she thinks about this. Though, many people might go against it. One reason why I think that people should be allowed to see, watch, listen, and read whatever they would like to see is because it's their own choice. We make our own decisions whether people like it or not. Another reason would be because people would want to see the funny things that people invent that actually make the shows. Some people do not like to be bored with the same thing. Katherine Paterson, the author, is right in some ways. She wouldn't want her children to see things that are inappropriate. I have a daughter and I wouldn't want her to see things that are abhorrent. The last reason would be that children should not be allowed to see inappropriate things until they are eighteen or older. The author stated, 'then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else.' Right, she is meaning that we have a choice of what our children would like to see. For example, there is a magazine full of negative words and full of horrid stuff. Would you pull it out of the shelf for your child to not have a chance to see that? You should if you love your child even though it's your own choice. You would want the best for your child to not see, read, watch, and listen to things that are inappropriate. In conclusion, this would be your choice. There will always be things in the world that you don't like. You cannot stop the terrible things from happening. In the libraries, there shouldn't be anything negative anyway because you never know what your child might be doing. Simply, teach your kid what is wrong and right. Finally, from what you experienced, teach them the right things from the wrong things you learned so they wouldn't make the same mistake as you did.

I believe that all types of books should be available to all types of people. A library should never be intended for a certain group of readers. It is not fair to everybody to take books off the shelves of a library due to 'offensive' content. With different personalities comes different writers. With different writers comes different books. With different books comes different readers. There are a lot of people out there who like to read. What are the people who particularly like 'offensive' content going to do when these books are taken off the shelves? Books are written for two reasons: allowing authors to express themselves and giving readers the chance to explore and relate to the imaginations of authors. I think that if a writer has the ability to put whatever he/she wants in a book, that book should be available to anyone and everyone. In a world where diversity of thought is important, restricting access to books based on so - called offensive content goes against the very purpose of a library, which is to provide a wealth of knowledge and ideas to all.

Have you ever been to a library and found a book offensive? In my opinion, I believe that books, music, movies, magazines, etc., are at the library for a reason. If children under age were to wander off into the adult section, that would be their fault if they saw something inappropriate, not the library's. If the case was that every time a child or someone under age took a book offensive, I believe that the libraries wouldn't have as many books in their buildings that grown - ups would like to read. Of course, I'm not trying to say that there should be extremely inappropriate books wandering around in the library that small children should see. If somebody took that offensive and asked for the book to be removed, then it's their loss. Except no library in this entire world would have that kind of stuff up, so why worry about it. If there were ever to be that type of situation, then that would be bizarre. But I highly doubt that it would come to a point like that in time. So, in conclusion, that is my opinion on this matter, and libraries should maintain a balance between providing diverse content and ensuring the safety and appropriateness for all patrons.

Offensive material shouldn't be taken off the shelves at all. Books are written on various topics, from love to sci - fi. Throughout the years, many events have taken place in our history. Throughout these times, the events have been recorded, journaled, and filmed. These thoughts, opinions, and facts may be offensive to a select few in our society. The question is, 'Should our libraries take these 'offensive' pieces off the shelves?' The simple answer to this highly disputed question is no. Censoring our libraries would be a harmful and wrong thing to do to the general public. Censoring our libraries creates an illusion of a perfect society. If libraries were filled with tasteless articles and perfect fairy - land books, the library would become a place where reality is not present. Libraries hold information that is raw and true without leaving the facts behind. People need to get a taste of reality in order to survive in the'real world' and one of the greatest ways to obtain this knowledge is through books. Being exposed to offensive material and different viewpoints helps shape ourselves into who we are or will become. To take this away would be harming our development and growth, thus creating an 'imperfect' society. Certain points in history are not something that everyone can be proud of. The @CAPS1, @LOCATION1's genocide, and @CAPS2 @CAPS3 @CAPS4 are all devastating points in time that can be a touchy subject to one or a few people. However, history is an important factor in everyone's lives; we know history in order to not repeat it. Losing this information is a way for people to not be clearly informed, harming the future outcome of our society. Without public records of these happenings, it can cause confusion and mis - concepted views of important topics. If we censor all the media from libraries across the nation, ordinary people, such as yourself, would be 'living in the dark.' As people develop their own opinions and views over time, they begin to distinguish the difference between right and wrong. Your rights may be someone else's wrongs. What may be offensive to you may not be offensive to the person sitting next to you. Quoted by the author Katherine Paterson, '...if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf...you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' In truth, by removing offensive material from our bookshelves, there would be no media left. Not everyone will have the same opinion on matters that hold importance, but that is why the world goes around. We as a society have the right to guard our ability to share opinions, and censorship destroys our ability to do so. Everyone is different. The world is full of diversity and viewpoints that are bursting with interesting concepts. By censoring records of history, opinion, observations, our society becomes an illusion. We need to have these facts available to the general public. By ridding ourselves of 'offensive' media, we cannot share our opinions with one another for a more successful society. Censorship should not be allowed in libraries because it is harmful to our growth as a society and is overall the wrong thing to do. In conclusion, libraries should remain a place where all information, regardless of its potential to offend, is accessible, as it is essential for the progress and development of our society.

There are books, music, movies, magazines, and other media that are not appropriate for children. Having them banned from library shelves shouldn't even be a question. If children shouldn't read, watch, or listen to certain content, then it's the parents' responsibility to make sure they don't. However, I don't think they should take those kinds of books, movies, or music off the shelves because what about teens that like them or grown - ups? They're just going to take them down for the children but lose business from grown - ups and teens. That doesn't make any sense at all. I think either the child should know what he or she can read, watch, or listen to, and if they can't, then it's up to the parent or a grown - up around them to let them know what they can choose. A way to solve the problem can be to separate those offensive books, music, or movies from ones that are appropriate for children. Perhaps the author does not find it offensive, and is simply trying to make sense of the world because that is all [a person] can do with all of the problems that exist. Every single person has the right to be heard. The people that believe something should be censored or hidden could have completely different opinions from others. There is no absolute, divine being that can accurately judge a material. The people that censor could be wrong about the content of the material. Because of the great variety of opinions and the concept of respect, everyone must be heard. Censorship should not be allowed because time and knowledge are the valuable building blocks that determine the future of humanity, and not a single thought should go unheard. Censorship is a great hindrance to knowing what is occurring and what has occurred in the world. Truth is knowledge and knowledge is truth. It is up to the world to unleash it and make something out of it, and thus move forward in a more informed way.

People will always take things offensively. It is a fact of life. No one will ever be completely satisfied no matter what. We cannot try to please everyone, and it will never happen. That is their freedom of speech. We cannot take that away from them, but there should be some censorship at least to the appearance of books. For music and movies, they usually have a warning label if it is not intended for younger kids. It might be a good idea for some libraries to do the same with books and magazines. In order to see a rated, '[specific rating]', movie you have to be over [specific age] and for a good reason because of the mature content. The books being written now are more and more mature. But if we take on the custom of being of a certain age for books, we might invade the privacy of others. No one has the right to remove books from a library's shelf on the count of being offensive. Who can judge whether something is offensive? The libraries are publicly owned and therefore have no one owner. The city owns them. If there is a problem with whether a book should be at the library, it is the city's decision. Even if there is such an uproar about one book, unless the decision is unanimous, no book should be taken off the shelves. The book should simply be put in a spot either behind the counter or where it is available only on request. Taking books off the shelves, I believe, is taking away from the public's ability to read. If a parent is concerned about what their child might read, they should confront their local librarian. The librarian may be able to help them retrieve books that are appropriate and appealing to their child, ensuring that both the freedom of access to knowledge and the protection of children are balanced.

There are a lot of things that people think about. Do we really think that things that are found offensive in the libraries should be taken down? This is how I put it: make the library suitable for others, make them feel at home when they are reading their book, magazine, etc., not for you. It is how others think about what is out there in these libraries, not what you think. By maintaining a library environment that is free from offensive content, we can ensure that more people can enjoy and benefit from this public resource.

This is a very difficult topic to engage in an argument about. In my opinion, I firmly believe that there should be certain types of censorship in libraries. However, if there are young kids doing this, it is obviously a bad thing because it is teaching them wrong things early in their lives. It is even best if they aren't exposed to this at all. There are also certain books in this world that are inappropriate even for high - school students, and they need to stay out of all libraries so that there is no exposure. Once they are old enough to make their own choices, then it is their decision on whether or not they want to look at those books. There are some things that can and can't be put out into libraries. Children don't need to see that kind of stuff. It is all your own choice of things you want to read. Just make the right choice, and understand what you're reading, watching, listening to, or being around, so as to ensure a healthy and proper development.

Parents also take the initiative to censor what their kids read, watch, and listen to as a means of keeping them innocent. At a certain point in a young adult's life, this feeling of censorship gradually wears off, and the teenager decides to read, watch, and listen to whatever they desire. This is the common scenario in most cases, but is this strong feeling of public censorship too old - fashioned for today's society? In my opinion, yes. Censorship, to a certain extent, should not be present in libraries. There will always be something that one person finds inappropriate while another finds it to be perfectly fine. Today in our society, many things can be interpreted in many different ways. Many sayings, quotes, and even just simple words are twisted, turned, and made into something they are not. The author Katherine Paterson once said that a person has a right to remove harmful things that are explicit for children from a shelf, and this is true. Even with that being true, the real question is, will it do you any good to take those things away? In my opinion, offensive materials should not be removed because a librarian could be taking away material someone without money wanted, children - especially teens - will almost do anything for what they want, and things have a double meaning most of the time. If a librarian finds something offensive, he or she might not ever put that book on the shelf in fear of children finding the material. I think that action the librarian takes is completely unnecessary. He or she might be able to take that privilege away from his or her own library, but the material is still out there in the world. A child can simply go to another library, or even a store to find the same thing. I also believe that a library should leave the book on the shelf because what if an adult wants to read the book but does not have the opportunity to read it because it is found offensive. Being a teenager myself, I have witnessed what lengths some people will go to just so they can get this explicit material. If a teen goes to a library and can not find what they want at that location, they will simply move on to another location. In even the most extreme cases, a teen will take their parent's credit card and purchase the item they desire online. In this case, it would seem as if the library not having one thing because of something offensive could cause a big problem. When a person listens to music, or reads a book, that person could take something differently from how the writer intended it to be. For example, a person could pick up a funny book that finds humor in everyone, but the reader could end up thinking the author was only making fun of one specific thing; something that reader could be involved in. Libraries across the world are currently facing the significant obstacle of censorship. In this modern day and age, censorship has become an even more prominent issue. Censorship can affect various forms of media, including books, music, movies, magazines, and many other forms of creative expression. This situation poses the question: is censorship a good thing, or is it bad? Censorship allows certain books to be removed from the shelves of a library if a particular person finds the book to be offensive. Everyone has their own opinions about things, so why should one person's opinion affect what the rest of us are allowed to learn? What one person finds offensive could be perfectly acceptable to everyone else. Moreover, you are not being forced to engage with something you don't want to. If you find censorship offensive, then one simple solution is to avoid the censored material! Censorship not only impacts the learner; it also affects the writer. Censorship takes away the one thing a writer holds dear: their freedom of speech. Writers create books, music, and magazine articles to voice their thoughts on various topics, to show others how they perceive the world, and to share their personal experiences. Through their work, writers establish a connection with the reader that they can understand and relate to. Writers should have the right to choose what they want to convey to the world, and they should be given the privilege to do so. Even if you manage to implement censorship on books and music at a library, you can't censor the internet. The internet has become a place where anyone around the world can find websites they like, offering a vast array of books, music, magazines, and even shopping stores. A library is a public space, just like the internet. Anyone should be able to access and enjoy the content they like. Imposing censorship on things is almost equivalent to preventing a teacher from teaching because of their nationality or silencing our president from giving a speech because of his race. Censorship is based on an individual's opinion. It shouldn't affect the learners or the writers. Censorship restricts the voice of society and the thoughts of ordinary people. In conclusion, censorship should not exist as it goes against the principles of freedom and the diversity of ideas.

Libraries are often mistakenly thought of as just a room full of books inside a school building. In reality, they are spread all over the country and are utilized by people of all ages. Due to this wide - reaching usage, I firmly believe that there should not be a restriction on what books a library puts on their shelves. If the books and magazines are clearly labeled, then a person can simply stay away from what he or she finds offensive. However, in the case of a school library, all the books, of course, should be age - appropriate. Just because you don't like a particular item doesn't mean your neighbor won't. For instance, if someone finds a movie ridiculous and inappropriate, that doesn't mean someone else will share the same view. Since all people have different tastes and perspectives, no one will like the exact same movies as the next person. Therefore, a personally offensive movie should not be removed from the shelves, as it would prevent the enjoyment of another individual. This principle applies equally to magazines, books, and anything available at a library. Parental concern for their children is also an important factor. However, if a public library has a section of books or magazines that a parent of a young child finds offensive, I do not think that should require the library to remove the book. This is where I believe organization and limitations come into play. The adult books and magazines that might be offensive for children should be placed in a separate section, perhaps in a different room or on a different level of the building. This would prevent the accidental discovery by children. Along with proper organization, I think there should be a limitation. So, if a child were to purposely walk into that section and grab a book that is not appropriate or offensive to the parent, they would not be able to check it out at the desk from the librarian. Outside of public libraries, school libraries have different requirements in my opinion. Elementary libraries, of course, should contain no inappropriate material to any extent. All of the material in an elementary library should be strictly for educational purposes. At that age, children are far too young for any form of adult humor or magazine article. At the middle and high school level, I think things should change a little, but they should still be much more strict than a public library and contain absolutely no offensive content. I feel that magazines and joke books are welcome in the libraries of teenagers, as long as they comply with the school rules. Public libraries are a place for children and adults alike to find a book or movie to entertain themselves, and everyone has a different opinion. Because of this diversity of opinion, there should be no restrictions in public libraries, and people should be able to get the books or movies they want. Within a school corporation, the environment changes, and the rules must be adjusted accordingly. Nothing offensive should be placed within a school library, no matter how old the students are. In conclusion, libraries should not be required to remove books from their shelves, as they need to balance the needs of different users while maintaining appropriate standards.

Censorship has been the topic of many intense debates involving politicians, civil rights activists, and the everyday citizen. There are groups that firmly believe the government has every right to censor anything that is considered offensive in today's society. Some individuals could argue against this belief by supporting the statement that it is not the government's position to decide what is considered offensive and what is not. I just so happen to agree with this counter - argument. One common opinion, mainly supported by people with children, is that books, music, and movies, etc., should be censored to protect the younger generations. While it is true that parents should be concerned with what their children are exposed to, if the offensive material that is part of an adult's everyday life is completely restricted from a child, how is he or she expected to be prepared and thrive in the future? Why do we spend at least twelve years of our lives going to school? We go to school to prepare ourselves for the challenges of being an adult. We place ourselves in an environment that is specifically designed to make us comfortable with the responsibilities of maturity. If a child is not properly exposed to certain aspects of the real world, there is absolutely no way they can be prepared to encounter them in the future. However, not all individuals support censorship because of their children. There are adults who would like to see no more of today's offensive material for themselves than they would want their children to see. My rebuttal to this is that if you do not want to see it, then simply don't choose to see it. No individual is ever forced to be exposed to anything in today's media. You can turn off the television if the program bothers you. You can choose not to read the book or magazine. You can change the radio station. Every person is capable of controlling what they hear and see, and it is unnecessary to attempt to remove from society what could simply be ignored. Lastly, one of the most consistent debates around censorship is that the government should control what is included in today's media. Think back in America's history; when has giving the government more power in our everyday lives ever been beneficial for our society? The reason our forefathers founded our great country was to have the freedom they were deprived of in Europe. The Bill of Rights was created to ensure that the government could not attempt to control what they had no right to control. The freedom of speech is not just referring to what comes from an individual's mouth, but what goes into their eyes and ears as well. The citizens of this great country are more than capable of deciding for themselves what is offensive to them and what is not. It is the government's duty to protect our country from other countries and groups of people who attempt to break it apart, but not to control what we see and hear. Meetings and debates are held every day to enhance the quality of our freedom and occasionally to gain more freedom. I ask why some individuals would want to give away one of the freedoms we already have? The United States is one of the greatest countries ever to exist, yet we seem too lazy to decide what we are exposed to in our everyday lives? It is time for our society to stop relying on the government to make these decisions and start taking responsibility for our own media consumption. In conclusion, censorship by the government is unnecessary and goes against the principles of freedom, and citizens should be empowered to make their own choices.

Have you ever felt that books are offensive? Maybe, but it all depends on who you are and what angers you. Some people think that books, music, movies, and other forms of media can be offensive in some way. I know they can, but something can only affect a certain amount of people if they together understand the problem. I think there are several reasons for and against taking books out of our libraries.  From what I hear, people do get angry over things, but the question is what gets them so angry? What is offensive is different for some people than others. For example, a sports team fan reads a book about their team and the author makes fun of them or teases them. That is a way to make someone offended and angry at a book. Others can get mad at a movie because it discriminates against races of other kinds. Like how in the 1960s, some movies characterized African - Americans as stubborn, ignorant human beings. In my view, actually being African - American myself, it sort of aggravates me too, but nonetheless, I shouldn't argue because of one major amendment, freedom of speech.  What is offensive depends on how it angers them also. Like how back in World War II, the Jewish people were characterized as short, fat people with big noses taking all the money away from the Germans. That can be offensive and is usually used to sway people to one side. I think that if something offends you lightly, most of the time you shouldn't worry about it, but if you get offended very heavily and none of the stuff they say about that topic is true, maybe you should get someone else to read it with the same dislikes and likes as you. That could help determine if it is truly offensive to people in general, not just you.  Then after that, the main question we would ask would be what should we do next? If I were someone and the book I'm reading offends me massively, I would contact the library it came from and ask them to read it. If they think it is offensive, then they would more than likely take it off the shelves. Now, just because someone who likes a sports team reads a book about them and the book talks trash about the team, don't tell the library. That's just a waste of time. Just simply pick up another book and read it. I can understand how people will get mad over racism and discrimination, but not over a sports team.  So I hope that people can someday understand the limit to where something can actually be offensive. Or maybe it's just in our common nature for us to be offended when something we like gets made fun of. That is why I think that books should only be taken off shelves for only very good reasons, not silly ones.

Dear Newspaper Editor,  I believe that the country should take off all the books, movies, magazines, and music that has any kind of offensive cover, or any offensive, mind - grabbing, sexual content in any of the stories, music, etc. Children don't need to be seeing that stuff just sitting around. And adult books that are sitting around in bookstores, ready to be read by adults, not children.  The children need to know about all the sexual conflict some day, just not when they are 10 or 12 years old looking at pornographic magazines and movies. Banned books. All of us can think of a book that we hope none of our children or any other children have taken off the shelf. But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work that I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us. Katherine Paterson Author  I believe and will stand by Katherine's statement above. Who has the right to say if a book is offensive? People have a right to their opinion, but I do not think any one has the right to take books away from a public library.  A public library, the facts are in the name. It is a public library, where people can go and find a book to pass time, a book to use on an academic assignment, or a book to read to their child. Taking a book off the shelves just because it offended someone does not make sense to me. A person can pick up a book, be offended and complain about it. That is freedom of speech. I do not see fault in that. But when a person picks up a book, is offended, and demands that the book per se be taken off the shelves of a public library. That is when I have issues seeing where they think they have the right.  Katherine Paterson said in her text that 'If I have the right to remove that book from the shelf - that work I abhor - then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Isn't that a scary thought? If a person was offended by a book they could take it off the shelf at his or her own will? I fear the outcome of that. I am sure that a person could figure out something offensive about any book.  Taking books off the shelf is taking knowledge away from the people. We as citizens have the right to read at our pleasure, any book that we have the slightest whim to read, and be able to read that book without prosecution from people that find the book in question 'offensive.'  The day we let people take books off the shelves because they offend them, is the day our First Amendment fails. As a nation, we need to stand strong against banning books from public libraries. For our generation and for the many generations to follow, we must protect the freedom of access to knowledge and diverse ideas.

Censorship is the most foul and terrifying part of society. Our lives have been increasingly taken over by political correctness, so much so that our voices are no longer truly our own. Until recently, we had the freedom to convey our thoughts, no matter what those thoughts were, in any form of media. But now, if something is found to be offensive in any way, it is essentially silenced or removed. Censorship limits our freedoms, takes away our rights as citizens and people, shields us from the truths of the world, and limits the knowledge we can access. It also ensures that one day, there may be little left of media that is truly free - flowing. The Constitution of the United States, the document that our country lives by, says that we as people have the right of free speech. Censorship actively and violently violates that right. Our country was built on the foundation of free speech, and now it is being gradually eroded. Our own words are being forced down our throats, never allowed to come out. Censorship ensures that no diverse opinions will be heard, that no one's beliefs will be questioned, and that no one can think independently. Is this not what we are supposedly guaranteed by freedom of speech? We are supposed to be able to say anything we want to say. We know there are consequences for saying certain things, but we are supposed to have the right to express them. Letting our own ideas into the world allows for new ideas to form. Arguments come, but these arguments allow people to see other perspectives that they hadn't considered and look at issues from new angles. We are able to see our world through different eyes when we hear or read someone else's opinions. And from there, we can form our own opinions, allowing our world to be rich with ideas and knowledge, and enabling our society to advance. But censorship wants to take this all away from us in order to please everyone. However, there will always be someone who is unhappy. It's the inevitable truth. Censorship is trying to shield us from the ugliness of this world. In a way, this makes sense. We don't want our children to be exposed to the atrocities that happen in everyday life. We don't want them to know what's happening behind closed doors. However, if we don't allow people to confront these realities, they can never truly understand the world or be prepared for the experiences that are to come. Learning the harsh realities of our society educates people, allowing them to take steps to stop these realities and be prepared for when they happen to them. For example, let's look at the issue of rape. Rape is a horrible thing, but it happens. It is a harsh part of reality. Rape can be censored from books, television, and other forms of media. We can walk around pretending rape doesn't exist. But that doesn't solve anything. That doesn't get rid of rape. It still exists. And if the people are uneducated on the issue of rape, how will it ever stop? How will a rape ever be able to be prevented? How will someone know what to expect or what to do? By censoring rape from media, we are ensuring that the people in future generations never learn about rape. Knowledge of rape is crucial if it is ever going to be stopped. Pretending something doesn't exist doesn't make it go away. Censorship is supposed to protect the people, but it fails to do so. It hurts the people by cutting off their access to knowledge. We as people need knowledge. We thrive on knowledge. And the way we obtain this knowledge is through various forms of media. Censorship takes away pieces of knowledge gradually. It may not seem like a lot is missing now, but as time goes on, the gap will widen, and more knowledge will be taken from our grasp. Is this fair? Is this right? Is this helping us? How does cutting out knowledge ever benefit us? It brings us backwards in time, instills fear in us. It is human nature to fear the unknown. The more that becomes unknown, the more we have to fear. Censorship is taking away crucial pieces of knowledge that we must understand to function in society. This is wrong and immoral. It is unfair, if nothing else. We should be allowed to access any knowledge that exists. No good comes from hiding it. Lastly, this gradual suppression of knowledge is affecting society in horrid ways. And as time goes on, it can only get worse. Censorship is based on the concept of offensiveness. If something could be offensive, it is removed. However, everything that exists in society could be offensive to someone. Therefore, following the logic of censorship, everything and everyone should be censored to fulfill its goal. This means all media of any kind should be destroyed. No one should be allowed to express themselves. The world would be forced to be silent. All knowledge would be taken away. Chaos would ensue. The people's freedom would be completely taken away. The freedom to know would vanish right in front of their eyes. This is our future if we allow the censorship to continue. We cannot allow our lives to be taken over by censorship. Yes, people's feelings may be hurt, but we cannot sacrifice our freedom of speech and access to knowledge to spare those feelings. These ideas and knowledge are too important to let censorship take away.

Every individual is entitled to his or her own preference. Some people prefer R - rated movies or music with explicit content. If that's what people are interested in, then so be it. Anybody should not have to stop renting something that they want just because someone else doesn't approve.  Furthermore, if someone doesn't want something offensive in his or her house, then they can simply choose not to get it. No one is forcing anyone to listen to or watch something that they don't want. It's a straightforward choice. People don't have the right to tell someone else that they can't watch or listen to what they want. There are plenty of R - rated movies that have won numerous awards and other rewards. Another example is the singer Eminem. While his music may be offensive to some, there are still many people who enjoy it. Certain things that offend people can be enjoyable for others.  In conclusion, no one has the right to stop anyone from renting what they want from a library. People should mind their own business and not worry about what other people find enjoyable. Certain books, movies, music, and magazines are only offensive if certain people believe they are. People can only make choices for themselves, and that's all there is to it.

Library Censorship. Libraries shouldn't have 'offensive' books removed from shelves. Parent supervision, librarian supervision, and your own common sense are three of the key reasons why books shouldn't be removed from shelves if they are considered to be offensive. Parent supervision is one of the top priorities for knowing what your children read. If they don't want their children to grow up being 'stupid', then they should teach them to focus on educational books more. When they see their child in a row of books that they think is inappropriate, then they should gently remove their child from that area and take them to another area. The librarian's supervision is also an important priority. Maybe they don't know the children's actual age, but if the librarian sees them in a place that they think is inappropriate for someone around their age, they should show them another bookshelf. Just like parents, librarians will try to find an educational book that the child might enjoy. But, librarians obviously like to read since they are around books all day, so the child might be lucky and the librarian finds an adventure book for the child, or something else that the child finds interesting. The person's common sense is also a reason why 'offensive' books shouldn't be removed from libraries. Most people clearly know how old they are and what kind of books they should read. If they are in an area of the library that other people might think is inappropriate for them to read, they should go to a different area. Once again, I don't think there should be a censorship in libraries. If parents want their children to read books that won't 'rot your brain', then they should closely observe what books their child reads, trust the librarian to show them the correct books to read, and expect their child to have good common sense. In conclusion, a combination of parental, librarian, and personal responsibility can ensure a healthy reading environment in libraries without the need for strict censorship.

You are the mother or father of a young child, and you take them to the library. While there, you notice some eye - catching advertising for a new book. The sign is all bright and flashy, so you stop to carefully read it. It turns out to be advertising a book and some movies that you firmly believe should not even be available in a public library, for they are far too inappropriate and offensive. What would you do? Personally, I believe that if you see something like that, which you believe is offensive, you should take action and say something. Talk to the librarian and clearly state your case about what is going on. Having offensive articles in a public library where kids of all ages go to do their homework and study is just plain wrong. What if that certain library had no restrictions on who checked out what? So many kids could check things like that out, and not even understand what it actually is! Could you imagine your child coming home from the library, and handing you a book, magazine, or movie that was way beyond anything they should ever see at that age? It would be disastrous! I do not have children, but I do have younger cousins. I know for a fact that if they brought home something inappropriate or offensive, their parents would be having a serious and major talk with the librarian. Libraries should have major restrictions on what gets checked out by whom. For example, my library has three different kinds of library cards. One card is just for checking out regular books. Another is so you can check out movies, music, and books. Then the third and final card is so you can check out books, music, and movies from the adult section in a small room at the back of the library. However, to even be eligible for the third card, you have to be eighteen or older. I strongly believe that if a library does carry materials some find offensive, they need to be kept in a small room at the back of the library, or behind the librarians' desk. This way, no one who does not want to see the materials doesn't have to. If someone did want to see or check out these materials, they should need to provide proof that they are eighteen or older. This would make it easier for the librarian to keep track of who looks at or checks out the materials. Another thing, what if someone finds something offensive that someone else doesn't? Well, I honestly think that at least two or three people should comment on it being inappropriate or offensive, before it is actually taken off the shelf. If more than one person does say something, the librarian should place the book, magazine, movie, music, etc., in with the other offensive materials, where there is an age restriction. This is how it is at my neighborhood library, and I strongly believe that this library is a model for all libraries wanting to have more restrictions. If all libraries had more restrictions, it would be better off for everyone. Parents would not have to worry about their young children wandering around and finding something that is totally wrong for them. Older teenagers and young adults would be able to get their homework or projects accomplished without having all the distractions of the offensive materials. In conclusion, implementing proper restrictions in libraries is crucial for creating a safe and appropriate environment for all patrons, especially young children.

Censoring History We all know that language is the very foundation of human legacy. Language is spoken to precisely convey anything the speaker is trying to communicate. To take books from the shelves is equivalent to stealing the words from the mouths of many great speakers. We have a solemn obligation to keep the history that we have created alive. If something is forgotten, it is as if it never happened. And if it seems like nothing happened, it will reoccur - whether it is good or bad. To hide away words from our children is a grave mistake. If not by reading from a book, word - of - mouth will surely lead them to the same discoveries as they would have made if reading it from a book. But even more importantly, what good is there in hiding the truth? When many speak of tragic incidences, they often say, 'Let us not forget.' If we should not forget, why should the youth be prevented from learning? There is nothing in print that cannot be conveyed in a different communication form. Our history is vividly written on the pages of literature. The books we read are the precious property of all humanity and should be read by all to educate us about our past mistakes as well as our glorious triumphs. A commonly debated topic in the world of censorship is 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn.' 'The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn' is a novel that realistically displays what life was truly like in one of America's most racially barbaric times. One might argue the fact that it uses an offensive 'n' word more than a few times. To counter this argument, one might point out that Jim, the black slave that stood by Huck was deeply loved by Huck. A book in that time displaying a friendship between a black and a white man is truly a ground - breaking feat. The 'n' word was common place in that time period - a friendship between a black man and a white man was not. Is it really important that a child knows of just another offensive word that they are bound to discover eventually anyway, or is it more important that they learn that the color of skin does not change a person? Do not take the opportunity for a child to learn what really matters away. To take one book away is to set a dangerous precedent of taking all of them away. Censoring one piece of literature opens the floodgates of debate for every other piece ever created. The world has witnessed what can happen when things get censored. During Hitler's dictatorship, nearly everything from the internet, to books, to newspapers, to television programming, to movies, to music, to magazines were censored so only what the dictatorship wanted got through. The people were brainwashed, and those who were not rose up, and when they did, they were brutally shot down. Do not let the world come to such a disastrous state. We are better than that, and our literature clearly shows it. In other words, to censor media and the literature that surrounds us, we deprive ourselves of the education and freedoms that are absolutely critical to the well - being of future generations. Do not hide the free speech of authors. Do not hide our history from our children. Do not let us make the same mistake that has been made before. Let us educate our children for the future of humanity. Let our history not repeat itself. Let us innovate and create a new, better world. Let us allow our words to flow freely. Let us allow our legacy to live on and continue to inspire generations to come.

In conclusion, a balanced approach that respects both individual beliefs and the freedom of expression is essential for a healthy literary and cultural environment.

In the classic novel by Ray Bradbury, Fahrenheit 451, the protagonist struggles through life in a world antagonized by the banning and burning of books. The story takes place in the future; however, it contains an interesting undertone that hints at the possibility that this 'future' might be nearer than first imagined. To be blunt, the protagonist's life is horrible. He lives in a world that bans books, yet he is quite the bibliophile. He is employed as a fireman, not to clear fires, but to create them. Bradbury's firemen are responsible for the delicate task of book burning, which is a rather frequent occurrence. However, with the main character's love for literature, how can he burn books? Throughout the novel, the character tries to come to terms with himself and attempts to put an end to the madness, only to be forced out of civilized society. The book is frightening, but an amazing read: it emphasizes the dire reality of censorship. It's everywhere. Now, one certainly doesn't need to worry about Bradbury's futuristic hell coming to life any time soon. But one should know the dangers of censorship. No one person has the right to remove a book from the shelves that they feel is offensive, let alone ban it entirely. The banning of books is a banning of freedom: freedom of speech, freedom of ideas, freedom of thought. Another dystopian world that comes to mind is the world of George Orwell's 1984. Though, granted, our society is certainly not headed for that any time soon, if ever: it is still a valid point. Once some freedoms are removed, others will follow. Whether this knowledge be gained through books, magazines, movies, or music, it needs to be readily available. Instead of banning certain media, one should label said media with a warning. Parents should have enough sense to pay attention, and thus, the problem is solved.

The common phrase 'knowledge is power' accurately paints the situation at hand. Through censorship in libraries, which are meant to allow free and unrestricted access to all media - related materials, we take away the precious opportunity for people to empower themselves through knowledge. The reasons for not censoring media in libraries are numerous and include, but are not limited to, the unconstitutionality of censorship, the lack of a proper and clear - cut definition for 'offensive', and the blatant contradiction censorship poses to the very core of what a library is. The first, and most blatant, reason for not allowing the censorship of materials in libraries is the unconstitutionality of the matter. Freedom of speech and freedom of press are both firmly protected by the constitution upon which our country was founded. Censorship of said materials will effectively and severely undermine both of these rights. Authors, illustrators, journalists and the large number of other individuals who compose the materials available in libraries are exercising their right to free speech through their works. They are constitutionally protected in the things they say. Notice that @CAPS1 have a right to free speech and not a right to free speech so long as no one is offended. The freedom of press is the means by which they share their unique ideas and concepts with the world. They are utilizing their free speech by means of press. Censoring library materials would be unjustly limiting the means by which artists can share their ideas with citizens of the @LOCATION1. This would be a clear failure to uphold the rights of the citizens. For this reason, we cannot censor libraries. The constitutional concept of equality of man plays into the situation as well. There is no adequate legal definition of 'offend'. People could be offended by something as serious as a personal attack on their beliefs and personal entity or something as light as a personal distaste for certain mindsets and ideas. So, because all men are equal, we would have to respect the 'offense' taken by all people and to all degrees. This leaves every single work of art, whether it be a book, movie, magazine or any other form provided by libraries, open to the fickle definition of offensive and vulnerable to the personal feelings of every individual. If said offense taken by individuals to works is able to mark a work as 'offensive' and thus make it open to removal from libraries, we are effectively allowing citizens to undermine the rights of other citizens. This is something that cannot be allowed in our libraries. The final core issue is the essence of censorship versus the essence of a library. Censorship is meant to create a politically correct and non - offensive environment through the strict limitation of exposure to materials. Libraries, however, are meant to allow public access to works that stretch and challenge knowledge, beliefs, notions and all ideas held by people through the works of others. Censorship cannot be implemented without a sharp clash with the essence of a library's purpose. If censorship were to be enacted, a library could not provide new and valuable information if someone else did not like what was being taught. A library could not provide works that challenge and stretch individual beliefs if someone was offended by the means by which the stretching occurred. Pre - conceived notions could not be defeated with the presence of factual knowledge if someone did not like the truth. In all of these ways, and many more, a library's core ideals and purpose could not be upheld with the induction of a system of censorship. All in all, we can clearly see that censorship could only hope to destroy the system libraries abide by. The constitutional rights of citizens would be infringed upon, the fickle nature of humans and the lack of definition for 'offensive' would allow people to undermine the rights of others, and the essence of what a library really is would be severely ravaged. We cannot, as @CAPS1 with rights, employ a system of censorship.
