Throughout time, fellow people have struggled to censor or ban material that they consider offensive. It might be due to the way they were brought up, or simply what they believe. I do not believe that it should be up to anyone to say what should and should not be censored for anyone but themselves. Everyone has one life, and in this one life we create our personal opinions and beliefs on what is wrong and what is right. We are completely unaware of many people throughout our life cycles, and saying what should be banned from everybody is almost claiming you know the morals, beliefs, and customs of everyone in the world. If I came to school one day and brought a book that contained material that I think is relevant and not just pure exploitation, then I should be able to read that as long as I don't influence others against their own will. Let's say another student sees me reading that same book and he has grown up in a household that taught him that the situations and material in my book are overly offensive. I do not think he should be able to create a ban of this book just because of his own upbringing. There is such a thing as mass agreement, but there is also a thing called mass ignorance, and to say that I know what should and should not be shown to other people is completely ignorant on my part. I think the only allowance of censorship should be from parent to child. That is the only situation that someone should be allowed authority over someone else, because they have undeniable duties as parents, and they should be able to say what is right knowing they are creating a child to think what is wrong and what is right in their mind. In conclusion, censorship should be a personal and parental choice rather than a universal one.

At Jeffersonville High School, we don't have the right to remove a book from the shelf. If there's a book that isn't suitable for you, don't pick it up, just like you wouldn't watch a bad movie. It's like getting a bad lunch; you're not going to choose it, so why choose a bad book or movie? We should respect the diversity of materials available and let individuals make their own choices. In conclusion, the school should maintain a diverse collection and let students decide what they want to engage with.

Censorship is when a group of people agree that a certain book, song, movie, or magazine is found offensive in any way. Mainly parents and educators find these materials such as books offensive and do what they can to get this book taken out of libraries at schools. Censorship was originally started during the 'Dark Ages' in Europe with the Catholic Church. It was used to hide information from the public by taking all records of it away from the public's use. In the United States, we are a democracy, but we still choose censorship to hide certain information from certain people. In some parents' opinions, books are great and educational for children, but in other parents' opinions, books do things like promote homosexuality, use false language, or even show drug use. Most of these books are not trying to promote these things but they are just part of the story. So, pretend like we hide all the bad events or situations in the world from occurring in front of our children. They have no knowledge of this part of life, so what happens when they get in the real world and grow up? We can't just hide drugs from them; we can read these books and teach them the harm drugs can do to someone and how to avoid them. If we send our children out into this world without any knowledge of drugs, things will get out of control. The majority of these books that contain 'harmful' things to children actually teach lessons that parents don't think of. They just think of what's written down on the paper instead of the moral overall lesson that the story is bringing to a child. If a story has false language, our child will ask us what these words mean and we will tell them not to use them and what they mean so the child knows not to repeat them. If not, they can go into school and another child will tell your child to say these words and your child (not knowing the meaning of the word) will go out and say it and be awarded with a detention or even a suspension. Personally, I don't want my child receiving a detention or suspension. Censorship is a growing issue in the United States. It can do good things like hide actual sexual interactions from children, which should be hidden from children anyways. Censorship can also do the bad things like I discussed earlier, which do more harm to a child than good. When you're asked for your opinion on censorship, just always remember what's best for your child, and knowledge is always better than cluelessness. In conclusion, while censorship has its place in protecting children from certain content, it should not be over - used to the point of depriving children of valuable life lessons.

Going to the library is one of the best ways to explore new things. Some items are not appropriate for everyone though. Certain books, movies, magazines, and music should not be accessed by everyone. Having an adult - only section would be a way to solve this problem. Removing certain materials from the library would not be in good interest. Any popular material should be available at the library. Many best - selling books would be wrong for children to read, but they would be perfectly fine for adults. That doesn't mean these books need to be taken out of the library. Children should be restricted from viewing the explicit materials though. Having a section in the library from which only adults can rent the items would remove this problem. People under 18 should also be restrained from looking through these materials. Having a children's section in the library would also keep them away from adult materials. The library needs to make itself user - friendly. People who frequent the library often pick up a book, not knowing what it holds. When inappropriate material is inside, a child might innocently read into or see something they are not supposed to. Parents should not have to worry about their kids seeing inappropriate pictures or text. They should feel safe letting their children look through all the books at the library. Library workers should also make sure the adult materials stay in the hands of adults. Allowing children and their parents to feel safe and welcome is an important part of the library. Taking adult materials out of the library is not a good idea. It would lower its popularity. Everyone has different interests, and they want to research them at the library. The safety of children is also important. Making sure children cannot reach these materials is a concern. Having separate adult and children sections could solve this problem. Not allowing anyone under 18 to check out explicit materials would also help. Keeping the library full of information but still safe for children is the ideal situation. In conclusion, creating distinct adult and children sections in the library is a practical solution to balance the diverse needs of all library users.

I believe that not all books should be banned, but some books should. For example, there are many good books that are banned because they might have a little bit of cussing in them, but I believe that is okay. I mean, it isn't like the child wouldn't hear the same words, maybe even worse, if he turned on his TV. But if a book talks about certain things it should be banned, such as hate against other races, or it talks negatively about someone's religion. For example, I read a very famous book called The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn by Mark Twain. This was a very good book but for some reason it was banned in my school library so I couldn't check it out. I had to go to the public library to get it. I don't understand what is so wrong with The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn that it is banned by some educational institutions. This book might talk of a mischievous youngster who runs away, does a lot of different crazy activities, and even smokes, but this is no worse than what we are exposed to on TV. If I was an administrator in a school, I would look at what is the meaning behind the book and what it is trying to express. For example, if a book is offensive to someone, for instance a book written by a white supremacist, this piece shouldn't be allowed on the shelf. But if it is a book about the Civil War and the Confederacy's view on slavery, this would be okay. Because the white supremacist book is more hate than anything; it is, for instance, promoting racism and that isn't right. But the book on the Civil War and the Confederacy's view on slavery is a part of our history. It shows different ways of thinking of the time that we don't really know if they were right or wrong; it is just what they believed. So my point I am trying to express in this piece is that don't hate a book because maybe the language in it or the events in it might not be what you agree with, but judge the book because of the message that it is trying to express. Hopefully, you will agree with me in this. But if a book talks about certain things it should be banned, such as hate against other races, or it talks negatively about someone's religion. I have expressed my opinion on this matter. I hope you agree with me and can maybe convince the school that they need to take a second look at what kind of books we keep on our shelves and what kind of books we take off our shelves. In conclusion, book - banning decisions should be based on the underlying message and moral value of the book rather than surface - level content.

Whenever you go these days, you see violence in every store around the world. Children growing up in this world are our future, and they witness that negative output. A lot of kids and young adults thrive on the offensive materials the world presents. I think that offensive items should be taken off the regular shelves and sold in stores only for adults who are twenty - one and older. If people sell offensive things in stores where young teenagers can buy those products, then we are just putting ourselves at harm. I was just in a book store the other day and saw magazines that were not appropriate. I thought to myself how they could sell these types of magazines. Music, movies, and magazines shouldn't even be sold in a book store; that's why it's called a book store. It's not called a movie, music, or magazine store for a reason. If students read books or listen to music that is offensive, they are going to grow up thinking it's okay to be that way or treat somebody differently because of who they are or what they represent. I'm not saying take all the books out of the store, just take the offensive ones and have a twenty - one or older sign. So the kids don't end up getting a hold of the book and learning something they shouldn't. When I was young, I went to the book store all the time with my mom. I would just pick up any book there was and start trying to read. A lot of the time, my mom would take the book from me because it was offensive. I didn't know that at the time; I was just a little kid. In today's society, kids are growing up quicker than they really have to, and that's not a good thing. Kids should be able to be kids and read kids' books. I guess it doesn't really matter for middle school and high school kids because those kids really don't like to read at all. The kids that we have to look out for are the ones in elementary because those kids actually want to learn how to read. And if we put a book about drugs on the shelf, those kids will read it, learn about it, and be curious about what that drug has an effect on them. In the end, it doesn't really matter what I say because people are going to keep making books. Any type of book is all based on how much money they can make. It doesn't matter if it is a negative or a positive book; the company wants to make money, and so does the author. We need to find a balance to protect our children from harmful content while still allowing the free flow of ideas.

There are many different topics that could be offensive; it just depends on the person's own personal judgement. In my opinion, I do not believe that materials should be removed because not everyone has the same view or opinions. If someone comes from a different country or even a different religion, topics like abortion and racism are going to be viewed very differently. I think having a variety of topics will help expand different thoughts and make the readers of the material see things in a different way. When I am older and if one of my elementary - aged children was to bring home a book about abortion, I would be concerned. Honestly though, I do not believe schools would let inappropriate topics for younger children be in the books they read. It is a little bit different with a high - school student though. Their maturity level is going to be mature enough to handle the material, and I do not think it is right for schools to remove something that could actually help someone. In the book, 'A Child Called It', there are a lot of detailed events that happen. Some might say it is too graphic for children, but the reality is, events like those happen in today's society. It really opened up my eyes, and I am extremely happy I read it. The realization actually made me want to help those children who grow up in homes like the one described in the book. I believe it had the same effect on other people too, and some children might even grow up to help others in that horrible situation. Libraries should be able to have a variety of different books. I am not saying however that they should have books on murder and say it is alright, but books that will help expand the children's minds. It could even change their lives. Some books are a sensitive topic, but who has the right to tell someone something they should believe? It would mean more to someone if they found their own way and beliefs rather than having people tell them what they should and should not do or believe in. I have also read a book recently titled, 'Unwind', which is about the government granting the ability to unwind your children and then the body parts will go to those in need. It is sort of cruel in one way, but the topic the author is trying to get across is not. A quote from the book is, 'On one side you have people killing abortion doctors for the right of life and on the other you have people getting pregnant just to sell their fetal tissue'. It states that everywhere you go, people are going to disagree and agree on things, but not everyone will believe in the same thing. The book changed my perspective on many different topics and helped me open my eyes to different views. Racism, abortion, child abuse, unwinding your children, whatever the case may be, some people will support it and some will not. I think it is time for children around the world to discover for themselves what they truly believe in, and taking 'offensive' material from school libraries is not going to help any. My opinion on this topic is strongly advising to leave the material alone because for there to be a book about it, the author had to have had a reason to write it, and honestly, what is better for the future than a generation of children grounded in their own true beliefs?

Since the beginning, there has always been someone who is offended by certain media. Books, movies, and music have been the main focus of this controversy. There have been arguments over it so severe that it has gone to court! The people who have been upset over media have caused there to be certain censorships over these materials. I believe that there should not be censorship in media. I think that there are books, movies, and other media materials that can be found offensive to someone or a group of people. This is why they should have labels or at least a description on the back of these products that explain what could cause someone to become upset by it. If something is considered too vulgar for the public eye, then they should have it in a more discrete area, but not be taken off the shelves. I disagree that media materials should be taken off shelves for being offensive. Media is all about someone's free expression and trying to share it with the world. There are around 7 billion people in the world, and at least one of them is bound to enjoy the same type of media you do. A great example of a media material that is challenged every day in every part of the world is a book called the Bible. The Bible is considered to be one of the oldest books in the world and is still in print. People of different religions can sometimes find the print of Bibles alongside their religious books offensive, and there is always great controversy about it. All these movies and books are great because they are different and free! The world needs people who challenge ideas and religions. Every single person in the world is unique, and I think it is great for everyone to put their opinions out for others to find so they can have a new view on the subject or at least contemplate it. Society has already put parental advisory warnings on CDs, put ratings on movies, and labeled books as challenged. All this does is restrict the public from finding new ideas to compare to and form opinions. I believe in freedom of thinking because it is the most valuable resource that we have; it is what sets us apart from each other. Let media be free so men, women, and children from all over the globe can be unique and wonderful! Censorship will be challenged in years to come, and I will help challenge it for all to be free and happy, as a free - thinking society is a progressive one.

Books, music, movies, and magazines that are in libraries should be appropriate material. But in some cases, it's fine to have some offensive literature because people can learn from it. However, there needs to be an age limit to checking out these items. So I do believe we should keep offensive literature on the shelves, but with a certain extent. There are so many books and other kinds of literature in libraries today. Libraries are a place of silence, and to some people, that's boring. So, like me, when I go into a library, I go to the books or magazines that seem very interesting to me. Although they may seem interesting to me, others may find them offensive. For example, it might be a comic book that says something that someone may take offense to. Libraries can't please everyone that walks through the doors. Just because someone does not like the offensive stuff that's in there doesn't mean they have to take it out. Because there might be someone like me who likes those kinds of books or magazines. There is offensive stuff all over the world, so you can't avoid it everywhere you go. I believe there is a good outcome for keeping offensive literature material on the shelves. I think that keeping offensive material in libraries may have a good cause for one very good reason: learning. As I said before, it may be offensive to some people, but to some, it's not. So some people might like to learn about offensive things. Maybe they never knew those things that are in those books. They also may never know what's in those books unless they keep them on the shelves. They need to have a section where offensive books, magazines, music, and movies go. If something is offensive, put it on the shelf, and they must be 18 years old to check it out if it's on that shelf. Yeah, there may be a down - fall to keeping offensive things in libraries. But you can't hide from it all your life. So instead of going out into the world and learning about it the hard way, go to the library. You could pick a book up, learn about it, and learn how to deal with it. It's just part of life; there is offensive material everywhere. You can't be sheltered your whole life. So, in my opinion, I do believe that we should keep these offensive materials in libraries; it could be a learning experience that enriches our understanding of the world.

I am not in agreement because young children should not be exposed to certain offensive books. However, I believe that books should not be removed or censored in the libraries. Removing or censoring them would be like washing away some bad things, but it would also be a bad idea. By keeping these books in libraries, we allow for a diverse range of ideas and perspectives. While offensive content can be a concern for young children, libraries can implement measures such as age - restricted sections or clear labeling. This way, older and more mature readers can access these materials to gain different insights and knowledge. Censoring books limits the freedom of thought and the ability to explore various viewpoints. We should trust that libraries can manage the presence of offensive books in a way that balances the need for knowledge and the protection of young minds. In conclusion, we should find a middle - ground approach that preserves the integrity of libraries as a source of diverse information while safeguarding the well - being of young readers.

I think that the censorship in libraries should definitely be relevant. For instance, if someone wants to check out an adult book, they should be required to show ID at the front desk. Many children take advantage of the current system; they rent books and games they know their parents would never allow. A censorship system should be a quite simple arrangement for public library systems. Private libraries can do as they choose since they are not under any state law. On the other hand, public libraries are under state and city law, so they should not be able to expose adult content to children. For example, in many libraries around the U.S., there are books called manga or anime books. A lot of them show partial nudity and other graphic things not suitable for younger children but are only rated 13+. I think there could be many changes in the library systems. It is your choice if you want to change them or not, but implementing proper censorship would better protect young patrons.

I do not believe that materials in libraries should be censored. If parents don't want their children reading or listening to inappropriate things, they should pay closer attention to what their children are doing. By closely monitoring their children, parents will be able to control what their kids are exposed to. There are a lot of inappropriate things for children to read, look at, and listen to out there. Parents need to do a better job of teaching their children about what they can and should look at, read, or listen to. It isn't often when you go to the library that you find something inappropriate unless you are actively looking for it. It is very easy to tell what is good and what is bad. Most of the time in a library, the more adult - oriented books and magazines are separated from the children's books. This, to me, is the way it should be in all libraries. In all of the times I have been to a library, I have never accidentally come across something inappropriate. A library is a place for people of all ages and it should not be limited to just one age group. If libraries were censored, more people would be upset. It would be similar to a store stopping the sale of your favorite product because one person did not like it. A lot of adults probably would not go if the library were censored. Then, the library would become a place mainly for children. Most small children do not even go to the library, so it would become virtually useless. In all of my years, I have never once heard of someone being deeply offended by something at a library. Whether it be in a magazine, on the news, or by word of mouth, I have never seen a complaint. Most parents do a good job of monitoring what their children look at or read. Those parents should not be deprived of their privileges to look at more adult - rated things if they choose. Just because one parent was irresponsible to monitor their child does not mean that all parents should be punished. The library is a place for people of all ages. Therefore, the library should keep materials for people of all ages and not just for children. The bottom line is that if people do not want their kids looking at inappropriate things, they should keep a better watch over them and teach them the difference between what is acceptable and what is not.

Censoring books in libraries because a certain group of people doesn't like them and finds them offensive is simply not fair. A good library is diverse and has something that everyone of different backgrounds can enjoy. A compromise wouldn't be as difficult as some people might actually think. Simply regulating books and other products by creating age limits based on the books' content and maturity level would be an excellent alternative to actually censoring the books themselves. Take an author like Mark Twain for example. His books contain subject matter and offensive crude language that would obviously not be deemed acceptable for most younger people. That being said, censoring the books' language wouldn't help in the slightest. If a younger person has the mental capability to read a book like Mark Twain's, then they would have no problem making inferences on what material was said, and the ideas in the writing are going to be realized. The other fact is that taking out mature - level books completely from the libraries is not a possible solution either. If you take out the diversity in your product, you're going to lose the diversity in your customers as well. For instance, think about a movie store. If the only movies sold were G and PG, there would be a lot less people wanting to go to that store, because then it just turns into a child's store. Even censoring the movies would not be effective because you're taking away the art of having an unfiltered movie. So my simple solution is obvious. Movies have ratings based on maturity content, so why shouldn't books? Books that deal with more controversial content shouldn't be placed on the shelves next to young readers' books, and they should have a label indicating that the specific book may contain material not suitable for a person under a specific age. People trying to censor entertainment and look into the best interest of their loved ones is perfectly fine, but you can't shield them from reality forever. We're all on the same planet and we all reach the age of realization of reality, so a balanced approach is needed.

That is why I believe what I think about this issue, and proper regulation of these items on store shelves is necessary.

Do you think books, music, movies, magazines, etc. that could be offensive should or should not be pulled off the shelves? I believe they shouldn't. All kinds of people buy books or movies, and they all have different preferences. Companies that manufacture books, movies, music, and magazines would be losing out on money if people can't find something they like. If they don't have the money to produce what they make, then they will go out of business. Then you might be out of luck for finding what you are looking for. All kinds of people buy things that they like. How would you like it if your favorite candy was taken off the shelves because one person did not like it? Well, that's how people feel when offensive - labeled items are removed. What would be put in their places? Stores have to have something to fill the shelves. Would they put more candy and make the world fatter? If you come across something you think is offensive, just don't pay attention to it. Others may like it, just as you like your favorite candy. We have a great number of other things you can pick from. In conclusion, removing offensive items from shelves would have negative impacts on both consumers and businesses, so it's better to let the market and individual choice prevail.

A curious young child, full of wonder and excitement, goes into the library for the first time with the eager hope to find an interesting story to read. Yet, when she eagerly makes her way to the children's section, the particular book she wants so badly is not allowed in this library because it is said to promote certain ideals to children. The child, feeling a bit disappointed, then goes to her older sister for help to find a different book. However, the older sister is too busy looking for her own book. She had walked into the library looking to find answers to her in - depth questions over a liberal topic. Unfortunately, she can't find the book she wants as the library has censored it. Why would we censor libraries if we have the freedom of the press and the freedom of speech? It is definitely not right to censor libraries because that is restricting what is allowed to be read, which is taking away part of our freedom. The press is allowed to print anything, and we the people read it. Will that be the next thing that is censored? A book is just like the newspaper; it is relaying a story to entertain the audience that is reading it. By censoring libraries, that is taking away the freedom of speech. Writing is a beautiful way to express yourself. Authors share their expressions through writing, hoping they can touch someone else's life and be of some assistance. Whether the book helps its reader to escape a horrible day or to answer the questions of a curious teenager. I use books daily to escape the stresses of life. The '@CAPS1 @CAPS2' series gave me something engaging to do and allowed me to use my imagination and mind freely. I could escape into another world and leave my chores behind me. Some @MONTH1 say that offensive things should be censored. In our culture, the slightest thing can be called 'offensive' now. If we never learn about these 'offensive' things, how would we understand history? There will always be rude things that have been said, but we should be exposed to them so we can learn from it. By censoring these items, we will never learn, and neither will our children about other cultures, history, or liberal ideas. Instead of censoring items, there is another solution. Make certain items restricted and red - flagged. If certain items become restricted, it would mean that people over a certain age are allowed to read them. By doing this, a child's mind would not be polluted, but we could still be exposed to different ideas and learn from them. If there was a system to red - flag an item, this would allow the reader to know that this item contains what could be considered offensive material so they do not have to expose themselves to it if they did not want to, but others could. This would work because the books could stay in the library and still be used, but there would be a warning system for those who do not want to be around it or allow their children to be around it. In conclusion, censoring libraries is a bad idea. It takes away our freedom of the press and speech. We are also making ourselves ignorant this way. If we put out a warning system, it is fair to everyone. The 'offensive' material can stay in the libraries, but people will know ahead of time what they are being exposed to and what their children are too.

I think that no source of knowledge should be taken off any shelf in any library because a few people think it's offensive. In my own personal opinion, someone could find a book offensive, and another person could think it is reasonable. When I hear about a book being offensive, it makes me want to read it. It gives the book character and makes it humorous. Sometimes from those books, you even learn something about yourself that makes you wonder if I didn't read this book, would I still have found this out. Libraries are a wonderful place to go and look at all the books you could ever think of reading, and no one should be able to take that away from people. I want my kids to be able to have the same options that I had growing up, plus all the new books coming out. If you ask me, it's just not right to take away someone else's choice of knowledge. That's my personal opinion on taking books off the shelves of public libraries.

I believe that things shouldn't be taken off the shelves because a few people are offended. There @MONTH1 be a few that don't like something, but for every few that don't like it, there are some who do. For example, there might be a book that makes females look dumb, but personally, it doesn't affect me, but there are some girls who get offended because of their superior knowledge. I have a friend who gets offended by movies where the black guy always gets in trouble or dies first. So if we removed every movie that offended him, what would be left? I feel offended when a magazine shows girls are pretty because it makes people feel insecure about themselves. Even though I feel offended, I'm not going to request them to remove it because there are some magazines that give useful tips and actually help people feel better about themselves. My reasons are that just because something is there that you don't like, doesn't mean that you have to look at it or use it. There are plenty of people that would like to have access to that information or entertainment. Another reason is that if there's something that someone doesn't want their child looking at, then they should either trust that their child won't look at it, or prevent them from seeing it. Finally, what would be left if everyone were to remove something that they took offense to? Nothing would be left to read, listen to or watch. First, why I think censorship is wrong is that the people that take offense to what they want removed don't have to look at what's offensive. No one is forcing them to look at it or use it. They're better off just ignoring it. Because other people, that don't take offense to it, have the right to look at or use it. The library might be the only place that someone could have access to that sort of material. So if someone were to remove that material, the person that needs or wants it would not have the access to use it. And they are given the right to use it. Their child might even have the right to it. Second is that some people wouldn't want their child seeing those things. But removing it shouldn't be that person's first instinct. I believe that the parent should be able to trust their own child not to look at it. And if they can't, then they need to somehow prevent their child from viewing it, not by removing it. The parent should be able to come up with a reasonable way of preventing their child from viewing things that they don't want the child viewing, rather than taking that thing away from the child and the whole community. Lastly, let's say that in a library, there's at least one book to each person in a community that offends that person. If they were each given the right to remove the book that offended them, what would be left to read? Absolutely nothing. And each of those people that removed a book, most likely would enjoy another book that someone thought was offensive. So now there isn't a single book for that person to read, just because everyone else disliked the books they didn't think were offensive. Once someone starts removing, other people will join in, and you'd be left with an empty library. That's what I think about censorship. It's really just wrong. Personally, I would like to be able to go to my library and pick out a good book. And I know other people like to do that too. So why should anyone else be able to take that away from them. In conclusion, censorship undermines the diversity and accessibility of library resources and should be avoided.

In our great nation, we enjoy numerous freedoms. One of these precious liberties is the freedom to read, hear, and see whatever we desire. Each of us holds distinct views that align with this freedom, whether it's the TV shows we watch, the books we read in our leisure time, or the music we love to listen to. However, if we were granted the right to remove things we dislike, we would surely ruin the enjoyment for others. This would ultimately erode our freedom. Many authors, musicians, and directors have emphasized that this freedom is essential for leading an enjoyable and creative life.  We, as individuals, have diverse perspectives on a multitude of matters. Fortunately, our freedoms allow us to hold these views without interfering with the views or ideas of others. If we were to remove books, movies, magazines, etc., there would be nothing left for anyone. Our libraries would be emptied, classrooms would lack books, and stores would have nothing to offer. We should not possess the right to remove what we deem inappropriate or what doesn't conform to our values or interests.  Even though the idea of removing things might seem appealing, we must consider the thoughts and ideas of others. Take a public library, for example. It houses books for children, teens, and adults, each with their own individual preferences. Similarly, a school library has books tailored to the preferences of children and teens. If we allow this right, these libraries that celebrate individuality would cease to exist. People would be unable to exercise their freedom of individuality. Should books be removed from shelves if they are offensive? Who would determine if something is offensive and to whom it offends? Would removing books from shelves limit our ability to learn or see things from a different perspective?  First of all, who decides what is offensive and who it offends? It's entirely possible for anything to offend someone. Moreover, removing a book from the shelves could be offensive to the writer and the writer's followers. Bringing up the idea of removing a book from shelves could create more problems than simply leaving the book on the shelves. If offending others is the concern, wouldn't it be better to leave the book alone rather than making it an issue to please one group while upsetting another?  Secondly, could removing a book from the shelves limit your capacity to learn something or hear a different point of view? If books that offended people had always been removed, we wouldn't have much of the knowledge we possess today. For instance, a biology book might be offensive to those whose religion offers a different explanation of things, making certain scientific facts seem untrue. Conversely, a religious document such as 'The @CAPS1 @CAPS2' or 'The @CAPS3' could be offensive to those who believe biology books to be true. If we removed both types of books from the shelves for being offensive, we would lose both religion and modern science. This example can be applied to any topic or genre of book because people can find many things offensive.  As a solution, I firmly believe that it's impossible to please everyone. If one person is satisfied, another is offended. If that person is satisfied, the first person is offended. If books could be labeled as'some might find offensive' or 'this material may be offensive', people would be warned and could choose whether they want to read it or not. If they are offended, they can't blame the author or the place where they got the book because there was a warning. It would be similar to the parental warnings on CDs. This may not solve the problem of people being offended, but it could significantly reduce the number of complaints about a book being offensive.  In conclusion, books should remain on the shelves regardless of people's complaints about them being offensive. Removing books from shelves could lead to all books being removed, which would mean no education or learning. That's simply not an option. Leaving books on the shelves may cause controversy, but if appropriate warnings are in place and the proper procedures are followed, the issues can be greatly reduced. Think about all this the next time you want a book to be removed from the shelves.

Censorship is a matter of great contention today. Many authority figures have seemingly become obsessed with the notion that literature, video games, movies, and music are responsible for the perceived corruption of today's generation. Many believe in the idea of censorship because it will protect their children and allow them to remain innocent and morally upright. However, I believe censorship is a grand mistake on our part. Denying children access to certain literary works only keeps them ignorant, not innocent; so many books today are censored, and yet the information contained in them could have been vital to children who are seeking an understanding of the world they live in. One of the most difficult questions about censorship is the matter of what should be censored and what should not. Books that are viewed as offensive or controversial are the usual targets, but viewing something as being offensive is just that - a view. It changes from person to person because of varying cultures, religions, and moral codes. No one can agree on what will have a negative impact on children, making it impossible to establish a standard of what is best left off the shelf. The problem this creates is that many valuable books that should be permitted reading material are instead unavailable. Censorship can protect a child from information they are better off not knowing, but it also robs them of a chance to gain vital knowledge. Children should be encouraged to read and to learn, not blocked from doing so. Yet if this is truly the case, why does the censorship debate still rage? The argument continues because, in truth, there really are things that ought to be censored. Movies, music, and even books today can be very violent or sexual in nature, and these inappropriate subjects can have a negative impact on youths. Bloody video games and hateful song lyrics can encourage animosity towards others in children. But that cannot be the sole cause of such behavior; children will act right if they are taught how, not if they are hidden away from every instance of wrong. Censorship is greatly inferior to proper life lessons about morality, equality, peace, and respect. Inevitably, censorship will remain a common practice. But try this: think of a book that changed your life for the better, and then imagine if you had been denied access to reading it. Do you want to let your children miss out on an experience that could very well mean the world to them? In the end, while censorship has its place, we should be cautious not to over - censor and deprive children of the growth that comes from diverse reading.

Such material, however, should have reasonable restrictions on who should and should not check them out. Everyone has their own unique opinions and arguments about various things. There are a great many books that can be offensive to people in different ways. There can be over thousands of books in a library, and at times, I find it quite difficult to locate the right book that piques my interest. My personal opinion is that I do not think books should be removed from the shelf just because they might offend someone.  As I stated earlier, everyone has their own viewpoints. There are so many different types of books out there, ranging from murder mysteries, romances, and detective stories to those dealing with drugs and other controversial topics. These books should be placed in separate areas, just like many are already. If books are taken off the shelf, what does that imply for us? Everyone has their own freedom. So, if books are removed because of one person's offense, it's taking away from our individual freedom.  There's more to a library than just books. There are also movies, music, magazines, etc., and all of them can come in different varieties. I firmly believe they should just be placed in different areas. I understand where people think that this might influence young children if they pick up something disturbing, but they should be accompanied by an adult. Adults have a better understanding of what is right from wrong compared to children. For example, whenever I walk into public places, I rarely see children just running around, especially in libraries. Libraries are expected to be quiet, not a place for kids to jump around and scream. Kids should be with their parent or an adult so they can't grab something they shouldn't.  I understand that some teenagers can be offended by the mention of drugs or killings in magazines or books, but some people enjoy reading about that kind of stuff. Does that mean we have the right to take it off the shelf just because one person is offended? Many seem to think they have the right to do anything without negotiating with others. People who don't like that kind of stuff should simply put it back down and continue with what they were doing. I can understand if you think that restrictions should be put in place, and I agree. There should be sections for teens, adults, and children. But to me, that doesn't mean we have to remove anything from others just because it offends someone.  Libraries can have a positive impact on our everyday lives because of how calming and soothing they are. We should be able to have the freedom to access a wide range of materials without having things removed. Taking away things doesn't just affect one person; it affects everyone. We can have our own form of censorship in libraries while still respecting individual freedom. These are my personal views on why things should not be removed from shelves or other areas in libraries.

There are lots and lots of heated arguments over the censorship of books and how they could potentially affect children. Some people firmly believe that offensive books should be removed from library shelves. Others, on the contrary, think that they should remain available for those who want to read them. Some parents of children claim that their child has become more offensive towards others after being exposed to certain books, while others think it is just a result of bad parenting. So, as you can see, there are many different stances regarding offensive material being presented to children.  I think that there are some offensive things that need to stay on the shelves and some that shouldn't. Some articles that are offensive should be left up because they might teach children what is bad and what isn't. For example, there are books that depict historical atrocities so that future generations can learn from the past. Other articles that have no valid reason for being offensive should be taken off the shelves. For instance, there is music that talks about being extremely harsh and disobedient to others when that person has done nothing harmful. One good example of being offensive in a positive way is the book '@PERSON1'. This book vividly showed how bad slavery was and how it should never happen again.  If there is a book or any other piece of material that is offensive in a good way, I want to read it and understand what it is trying to convey to me. If it is portraying a bad image, then it should be removed from the shelves. If it isn't portraying a bad image, then I believe it should be taught to children so they can understand the effects and know the difference between right and wrong. Books that suggest harmful behavior towards anything without a purpose should be discarded. This is because children who read such books could be influenced to engage in what the book is suggesting, which could lead to bad consequences for that person or someone else.  I have witnessed accounts where someone has listened to bad music or read about something bad and then has been negatively changed by it. There have been incidents where that person did something illegal and then had to face the harsh consequences for that action. On the other hand, I have also seen accounts where people have been positively changed because of a book. I personally have been changed in a good way by the book '@ORGANIZATION1'. Now I realize how bad that was towards colored people, so I make sure to behave nicely towards them as they are just as equal to everyone else. In conclusion, we should carefully evaluate offensive materials in libraries and make decisions that balance the need for education and the protection of the vulnerable.

REMOVING BOOKS FROM THE LIBRARY BECAUSE THEY ARE OFFENSIVE IS A POOR IDEA. I DO NOT AGREE WITH THIS PRACTICE BECAUSE BOOKS SHOULD NOT BE PERMANENTLY REMOVED. INSTEAD, THERE SHOULD BE AGE LIMITS ON BOOKS. BOOKS THAT ARE OFFENSIVE SHOULD BE ACCESSIBLE ONLY TO ADULTS OR A CERTAIN AGE GROUP. THIS APPROACH WILL HELP KEEP CHILDREN INNOCENT AND PURE, PRESERVE HISTORY, AND UPHOLD FREEDOM OF SPEECH. BY IMPOSING AGE LIMITS ON CERTAIN BOOKS, WE CAN ENSURE THAT CHILDREN REMAIN INNOCENT AND UNAFFECTED BY INAPPROPRIATE CONTENT. FOR EXAMPLE, WITH BOOKS LIKE '@DATE1', KIDS @NUM1 OR UNDER SHOULD NOT BE ALLOWED TO READ IT. CHILDREN @NUM1 AND UNDER ARE STILL NAIVE. THEY HAVE NO KNOWLEDGE OF SEX OR PRE - MARITAL SEX. WITH @PERSON1 AND HIS GIRLFRIEND HAVING SEX IN EVERY OTHER CHAPTER, IT IS EXTREMELY INAPPROPRIATE FOR A CHILD TO READ. MOREOVER, WITH ALL THE TORTURE PARTS, IT WOULD TERRIFY A LITTLE BOY OR GIRL. WHEN WE GET RID OF OFFENSIVE BOOKS, WE UNINTENTIONALLY ERASE HISTORY. THINK ABOUT WHERE WE WOULD BE IF ANNE FRANK HAD NOT WRITTEN HER DIARY. WE WOULD NOT HAVE A CLEAR PICTURE OF HOW TRULY EVIL HITLER WAS. WE COULD ONLY MAKE ASSUMPTIONS. REMOVING BOOKS BECAUSE THEY ARE 'OFFENSIVE' IS A RIDICULOUS REASON. BOOKS ARE ONLY OFFENSIVE TO SENSITIVE PEOPLE. BOOKS KEEP HISTORY ALIVE! WE MUST ASK OURSELVES: 'WHAT ARE WE WITHOUT HISTORY?' FINALLY, FREEDOM OF SPEECH IS WHY THESE BOOKS SHOULD REMAIN. AUTHORS HAVE THE RIGHT TO WRITE WHAT THEY WANT. IF A READER DOES NOT LIKE A BOOK AND FINDS IT OFFENSIVE, THEN THEY SHOULD SIMPLY NOT READ IT. IF SHAKESPEARE HAD BEEN TOLD HE COULD NOT WRITE HIS STORIES, WE WOULD NOT HAVE THE TRAGEDY OF ROMEO AND JULIET. COUNTLESS BOOKS WOULD BE LOST IF AUTHORS WERE RESTRICTED BECAUSE OF OFFENSIVENESS. BOOKS THAT ARE TOO OFFENSIVE OR INAPPROPRIATE FOR CHILDREN SHOULD HAVE AGE LIMITS. IF WE GET RID OF CERTAIN BOOKS, WE ALSO LOSE A PART OF OUR HISTORY. REMOVING THESE BOOKS SENDS A MESSAGE TO FUTURE AUTHORS THAT FREEDOM OF SPEECH DOES NOT MATTER WHEN IT COMES TO OFFENSIVENESS. SO, WE SHOULD KEEP THE BOOKS AROUND. AFTER ALL, THEY ARE JUST WORDS THAT CAN TEACH US SO MUCH.

Many people claim that certain books should not be allowed on the library shelves. They assert that these books can be offensive to some and, therefore, should not be read. These books are known as '@CAPS2 Books.' Librarians and public officials, however, have gone too far in thinking they should have the authority to decide who reads certain books and who does not.  In the novel To @CAPS4 a @CAPS5, the author uses many words and descriptions that people find highly offensive. These words, nonetheless, are crucial to the setting of the novel. The author is not expressing that she personally believes @CAPS6 @CAPS7 should be described in the way they are, but a racist individual, such as @PERSON3 or many people during that time period, would not hesitate to describe them in such a manner. The novel, To @CAPS4 a @CAPS9, is an excellent way for people to understand the history of the @CAPS10. Without the descriptions in the novel, a significant piece of history would remain unknown to many.  The novel, @PERSON4 in the @CAPS11, attempts to explore the life of a pubescent, whiny teenager. The author, @PERSON2, uses many curses in the dialogue between characters. The characters, though, are high - school boys living at a boarding school. To tone down the language or make the novel 'kid - friendly' would make it impossible to accurately describe the true nature of the characters. The novel also contains multiple references to sexual situations. These situations, although offensive to some, are necessary to show the progression of the plot as well as the changing character traits of the protagonist, @PERSON1.  Literature is not the only medium being targeted by those trying to completely censor libraries. Music, movies, magazines, and video - games are also being affected. In many cases, certain materials should not be viewed by young children or those lacking the maturity to handle them. It should be remembered that it is the parents' responsibility to censor materials for their children. Instances of violence, prejudice, and death are a part of daily life. Library patrons should not be shielded from these real - life occurrences.  In conclusion, many times it is essential for an author to use words or descriptions that are offensive to many. Librarians should not be given the power to control which materials reach the library shelves. Libraries should offer a wide variety of books, movies, etc. to the public. If libraries do this, it becomes the responsibility of either the parents or the individual to select books that are within their personal boundaries. By maintaining this balance, libraries can fulfill their role as a source of knowledge and free expression.

Works of literature are works of literature no matter what they contain. All literature, whether it's a classic novel, a modern poem, or a controversial essay, should be placed on the shelves of a library. If for some reason the material is offensive or deemed as crude, then it should go into a restricted section where permission is required to enter. Literature is a powerful tool when it comes to persuasion. So we must be cautious about what we allow to be released or seen and to which eyes.   Literature is written by the author for many reasons. Perhaps the reason is to make money or to share a unique point of view, but either way the author generally wants his or her literature to be read. How would the author ever achieve his or her goal if we decided to remove their hard - work from the library shelves? It simply could not be read if it is not available. This is one reason why certain books should not be altogether removed from the library.   No matter how crude a topic might be, it still might be needed by certain individuals. If there were images of a nude person in a scientific book that librarians did not want children to get their hands on, then how would students study a topic such as sexual education or anatomy for a class? Of course, there are people who simply want to see nudity for foolish pleasure, and that is why permission should be required to obtain these books. A small, locked - off room in a library should be sufficient to contain all the books deemed crude. This way, the only access to the books would be to get a key from a librarian.   A book not read might as well never have been written. There is absolutely no point in destroying certain types of literature because some people feel offended. The simplest solution would be to simply make it so the only people to view these books would want or need to go view them. We simply can not lose certain pieces of writing because some parents do not trust their child's eye or because a person might be offended at the material. After all, when everybody has a chance to say what is offensive, there will be no books left. In conclusion, we should preserve the diversity of literature in libraries while taking necessary precautions to protect those who may be vulnerable to inappropriate content.

Everyone has their own opinion about certain things in life. Maybe it's politics; it could be a favorite sports team. Everyone has a right to their own opinion. As for reading materials, the opinions could be endless and even painful to hear.   Opinions of some books and media - type materials are often biased. People could often be offended by the materials that can be accessed through a public library. For instance, let's say a grandmother and her grandchild are at the public library. The grandchild picks up a self - help book and starts to read. Later, the grandmother reads it and finds out it says everything opposite of what the grandchild was taught about life by herself and her parents. To the grandmother, the book is offensive.   Through observation, I have noticed when a person picks up 'an offensive book' and reads a little of it, they tend to put it right back where they found it. It obviously isn't hard to do. So why should a book be taken out of a library when all you have to do is set it down and leave it? The same goes for music, movies, and magazines. If you don't like the music, don't listen to it. If you don't think it would be a 'nice' movie, don't go out and see it. If the magazine seems raunchy, don't buy it.   Mark Twain said it well, that if we took all the offensive books off the shelf '...then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' His statement is as true as any statement could be. What would be left? Everyone has an opinion, and likely someone will always find something offensive. Therefore, offensive books and media should be allowed to stay on the shelves.   Whether or not you find a book, movie, music, or magazine that is offensive, why fret over it? It's just easier to move on and forget it. Ignorance isn't all bad. In the end, we should respect the diversity of media in libraries and make personal choices based on our own preferences rather than trying to censor everything.

Taking books off the shelves will not change anything. Children are just going to go to a different place to find the book, like going to a book store or other libraries if they like it. If I saw a book and I knew I wasn't supposed to read it, but then I knew it was a good music - related book, or a good magazine, I would get it because that's what children do: they explore. Books are here to be read and to be looked at. I feel if you know I'm not supposed to read it, make me show proof of age or don't give it to me.  Really don't understand why some books are in stores and people don't want you reading them. Some children don't read at all, and to see them pick up a book and sit down to read should be good enough. But there is always an age group that isn't supposed to read some books. But at the same time, you can't keep the child away from the world and what it brings. The books are put there for a reason and not just to be walked past.  I feel like the reason why children listen to music is that sometimes the track relates to them in a way that another person would not understand. So they feel the song differently than what another person would hear, just the beats, the rhythm, the melody, and the lyrics. That's not what some parents want you to hear.  Magazines tell a lot of things and show too much for the younger minds. I'm a father myself and would not want my son at the age of 10 looking at any naked girl or ads about porn in Playboy books or any of that kind. Parents can sometimes be over - strict on a child and not let them do a lot of things. But they feel that they know what's best for you. Whatever they tell you is not wrong because they have been through it already. That would only lead to them doing things behind their backs. But if they want to learn the easy way, it's always the hard way. In conclusion, while parents should guide children, completely restricting access to certain media may have unintended negative consequences, and a balanced approach is needed.

When you go to a library, you usually have a lot of choices about reading books, watching movies, or listening to music. And sometimes, you might come across offensive words or abusive language that is not appropriate for your children. Students should have the right to remove the book from the library if he or she gets offended. Sometimes, if there is a student who has come from a different culture, they might get offended by the movies or music that are in the library.  Books are most commonly used in the library. In those books, there are some that are offensive to some students. If one student finds something offensive, he should have the right to remove the book from the library shelf. Many students like fiction books, which are based on true stories but might have some kind of offensive language or something that the student might find racist. School or any public library should remove books that contain inappropriate words that are not good for the kids to learn in their life.  Music is also one of the important things that is carried in any school library or any public library. The most common types of music that you can find in the library are pop, rock, or hip - hop music. Most of the time, those kinds of music might not carry any bad words, racism, or any offensive language, but some of the songs might carry something that is not appropriate for school use. Those kinds of music must be removed from any school library or any public library.  Movies are also carried in some libraries, but not every library carries movies. Some of the movies might have blood scenes, abusive language, which might not be appropriate for some children who are at school. You should check the rating of the movie that you are checking out of the library or if you are watching it at home or any other place. Movies might carry some kind of racism in them.  The library is a good source for reading books, listening to music, or watching a movie. While you are reading a book or watching a movie, you might find words which might not be appropriate for yourself or for students who read those books. These movies, books, or music can carry abusive language or something that is racist to some people who came from a different culture. Students should have the right to remove something that is not appropriate for school use, such as books, music, and movies, if they contain something that is not supposed to be in it. In conclusion, libraries should strive to provide a clean and appropriate environment for all users, and students' concerns about offensive content should be taken seriously.

A lot of people are offended by things that are uncensored. Some people think they should be censored, and others think it should not. It's all a matter of opinion. I don't think anything should be censored because it takes away from the freedom of speech.   With censorship, one can not fully express their self or opinion. That is why nothing should be censored. Censorship restricts the flow of diverse ideas and perspectives. When we censor, we limit the ability of individuals to explore different viewpoints, which can hinder intellectual growth and social progress.   In a free society, everyone should have the right to express themselves and consume the content they choose, as long as it does not cause direct harm. By censoring, we are essentially deciding for others what they can and cannot see, hear, or read. This goes against the principles of a democratic and open - minded community.   In conclusion, we should uphold the freedom of speech and resist the urge to censor. Instead, we should rely on education and critical thinking to help people make informed decisions about the content they encounter.

I strongly disagree with the idea of removing any materials from public shelves. Books, magazines, and other materials are based on the author's and musician's real - life experiences and their keen observations. With the large population of readers in the community, I know that the removal of books for what they might contain would have a bad impact on the people as a whole. The world needs its diverse materials. The writer of the book writes based on his Observations and his own personal life experiences. The creator puts so much effort into it, so why take it away just because someone doesn't like how part of it's worded? Movies that are considered bad probably just have a bad word or a scene with a little blood. Lots of people like to make a big deal out of nothing. I seriously think some parents think if their kid hears a bad word or sees a little pool of blood, the kid is going to end up in jail. Then there is music. The public thinks that kids should not be exposed to music like rap and hip - hop. I agree with that to some extent, but I also don't see what's wrong if it's Christian rap or a clean song. A musician is not just paid for his or her amazing skills with an instrument, but also for his or her ability to connect with the listener. I truly don't see any reason for taking any form of materials off the shelves. The artist who produces it has a right to their own opinion. The public, I feel, makes a big deal out of nothing. The smallest problems don't define the material as the reader hears the work of the artist. In conclusion, we should respect the creativity and rights of artists and let the public have access to a wide range of materials.

Where it all started, no one wanted to read. They'd say it's too hard or I don't want to. The best way to get out of reading was reading a magazine. For some reason, everyone wants to demoralize people, and that is where I think it all goes wrong. Stand up for your rights and censor out those things that will lead to worse lives of those to come. Censorship may just be a big word to most people, but it carries a big problem. For me, it all goes wrong whenever racism is a problem or else vulgarity is an obscene message. The music we listen to can get really intense. I'm a victim of the harsh music that we play more and more of today. Censorship is a two - sided question. There are people who believe that everything should be left the way that it is written. While other people believe that subjects that are offensive should be removed. Is a subject too graphic for students? People have the freedom of speech. Knowledge is power. These are some important reasons that can be thought about before deciding if censorship is right or not. What is too offensive for a student to read? In history, many things are considered offensive. If all the books that talk about history are gone, then how will students be able to learn about the past? If students can't learn about the past, then the past is bound to repeat itself. Other books like horror books are for entertainment purposes, so what is wrong with someone reading a book on a murder if it's just for entertainment? There are books that must be kept so that students can learn to their full abilities. If books are censored, then that takes away a person's right to freedom of speech. That restricts someone's creativity and sense of wonder. If certain books are taken off the shelves of a library, then books that are famous now might have never have been read. Books, even if they are offensive, can show someone's thoughts and ideas that could have changed the world. People everywhere learn from books. Books about the past help people understand what to do differently for the future. Many things are learned from books every day, and if certain books are taken down, there will be things that will never be learned, because someone thought that the book was not appropriate for a student to read. Students read books about the past so that they learn. The past is the best teacher, and when the past is gone, there is no way for those students to learn about the past. Having books that are said to be offensive can help in many ways. All books should remain on the shelves. No matter what the book talks about, a student can learn from that book. If the book is something that a student doesn't want to learn about, then they don't have to read the book. A lot can be learned from books, and without books, there can not and will not be knowledge that is spread for future generations to come. In conclusion, we should preserve the integrity of the book collection in libraries to ensure the free flow of knowledge and ideas.

Libraries contain thousands and thousands of books and other materials. Within those books, magazines, and movies holds a vast amount of knowledge. The non - fiction selection offers valuable information, and the fiction selection of books contains many entertaining stories and good morals. If libraries began censoring their books, much information will be hidden from the public. The government could have multiple reasons as to why they feel certain books should be taken off the shelf. Some possible reasons could be that they are racist, send the wrong message to children, or spread knowledge that the authority wants to keep away from the common man. Censoring books would be a horrible idea and affect everyone. Some books that could easily be considered to be taken off the shelf would be books that are racist, or suggest radical ideas. Everyone in the world is deemed equal, and books which suggest one race is better than another could offend the readers, and for which the authority decides to have it taken off the shelf. Books that suggest radical ideas could also belong in the group of books being taken off the shelf. The authority could be worried that the reader might carry out this radical/terrorist idea and would in return censor them. But censoring these ideas would be denying the public their chance to learn. There are racists everywhere, and just because you simply toss the book away, won't suddenly rid the world of racists. Another cause why books or magazines might be removed from the shelves could be that they send the wrong message to children or contain vulgar content. Parents try the best they can to repel the content away from their children, and books they begin to read, whether it be on their own or in school, could introduce kids of all ages to new content that their parents might not prefer them learning at their age. Parents might have a point, but children can not be protected from everything. They must learn and accept certain ideas as they grow and develop. Parents might be able to censor what their children read in their own home, but to take the books or movies entirely off the shelf would prevent the people who enjoy or see comedy in these articles, movies, music, or books from acquiring knowledge, even if their only purpose of reading is just for laughs. Censoring might also be introduced into libraries because the authority does not want the public learning and developing ideas on what they think the right way of doing something is that the authority disagrees with. They might think if people start learning and developing opinions from books they've read, they might start to oppose the authority. Although people are always going to oppose the authority, not everyone will like what is going on, and to have a growing society and economy, knowledgeable people are needed to invent and develop concepts. In terms of race and religion, everyone is considered equal, but in terms of level of intelligence, everybody varies from one another. Which could be another reason to censor, so the public stays at the same level as their neighbors, so everyone is truly equal. Doing this would once again stop the modernization of the world. Smart people would go unrecognized, and the inventions that could have been stirring in their heads could turn to a blank thought, which is the same as everyone else's. In the book Harrison Bergeron, censorship is the main idea. They censor the books so that everyone is truly equal, and even censor so that people's looks and qualities all are equal to the others. This is not the way to go in a modern society. The authority would have full control, and knowledge would not be blossoming in the schools. Even just a little bit of censoring in libraries, whether it be books, magazines, music, or movies, would put a damper on the knowledge and brain - power of the society around. Censoring books is an awful idea that should never be put into place. The authority should never be allowed to decide what the public views. It is in everyone's own opinion and interest whether they themselves read or listen to the material provided. In conclusion, we should oppose library censorship to promote a free and knowledge - rich society.

There are many things out in the'material' world that people take offense to. No matter what, there are always those people who have to be against whatever it is, whether it be a book or a song or a movie. But they do not have any idea what they are doing when they bring up their 'rights'. If they get to say that they are offended by the certain media product, not only do they announce that they have the right to try to have it banned, but they are giving the people who do not find offense in the material the right to do the same. If they can pull something off the shelves that they 'find offense to', then everyone has a right to. Another thing is that they claim to find offense to the song or book or movie, but if it bothers them that bad, they should just not listen/read/watch what exactly it is that they are feeling offends them. It would be that simple, just switch radio stations, or pick up another book, or watch a different movie. Another thing that the 'offended' people can try is having an open mind. It would make everything far less dramatic. People that say that they have offense to whatever the material might be usually use the phrase 'Well, it's offensive and I don't want my kid to stumble across it.' They say that they have a right to take whatever the 'offensive material' is off the shelf and keep it from the public. They couldn't be more right and stupid at the same time! If they have a right to take a certain thing off the shelf, then the creator (the writer of the song/book/movie) can claim that he has been offended by some song/book/movie that the first person likes. Then it's just a free - for - all for everyone to start taking everything off the shelves, one by one. Everyone has the same rights, and if the first offended person uses them to bring the creator down, then the creator has the right to do the exact same thing. So the government shouldn't let things be taken off of shelves, because if they take one down, they might as well take everything else down with it. So, if someone finds offense to a song they hear on the radio, and they feel that strongly as to they want it removed from radios and anywhere that plays music, then they need help. When they find that song THAT offensive, then there is only one simple solution: turn the freaking radio to something else! Seriously, if someone finds the song offensive, then why are they going to sit there and listen to the entire song? Or if they find a book offensive. Would I sit and read an entire book if I don't like the content? Umm, no. If someone is that offended by whatever the material is, then they need to just do something else, because it's pretty ridiculous to waste more time attempting to ban the song or the book than to just change the radio or find a different book. So if you're going to complain about the song or book being out there, just take your attention to something else, because every song, book, or movie out there has a right to be sold. On a light note, they could just have an open mind so that the song, or the book, or the movie can still be sold. They can try and read through the book to see if there is a reason that the author has written it this way

Controversy in the public library. When someone walks into their public library, they are overwhelmed with an abundance of books. Even though one person could never read that many books, the library has to have a wide selection, for the people that read different things. The library should not get rid of books that offend some people. The library is a public place that allows people to read what they want. If someone does not agree with what another person is reading, they don't have to be there. Since the library is a public place, people cannot just throw away a book because it is offensive. Just like Katherine Paterson said, 'And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' If everyone would throw away books that were offensive, there would be no books left.
