Most movies, magazines, music, and books are considered offensive to at least one person in this world. These forms of media, which are so diverse and widespread, often fall victim to censorship and are challenged daily to be banned, especially books. Mothers and fathers do have the right to prohibit such materials from their own children, as they are responsible for their kids' upbringing. But they do not have the right to ban them from all the world's children. Whatever the reasoning may be, censorship is wrong. It restricts the creativity of the writer, the freedom of the reader, and, as Katherine Paterson well put it, would result in 'no books left on the shelf for any of us.' According to the principles of free society, everyone has the freedom of speech and the freedom of press. This does not exempt writers or artists who occasionally, or more than occasionally, include explicit content in their works. In every book, there is a message the writer is trying to tell his or her audience. How they go about getting that message across is their own business, and they have all the right to do so in any way they wish. People who wish not to see the writer's message have the right not to. But when they fear the message and try to stop anyone else from seeing or hearing it, then they are violating the rights of the writer by telling them they cannot include the offensive material. Most writers include this material for a reason. For example, swear words, such as the ones argued in a well - known literary work, often times show the characters' traits and also improve the setting. During those times, people did call others by explicit names, even those who were in no way prejudice. That was the way of life for them and the author was simply trying to show that to the reader. By censoring the word from text, people were, in a way, covering up the history of a particular era. Every person over the age of eighteen has the right to read anything they wish. They are no longer under the commands of their legal guardians and in no way are under the command of other children's parents. Parents who prefer their own children not to see or listen to certain materials have the right to censor the materials away from their children. On the other hand, they have no right to tell their neighbors what and what not their children can see. Every parent has different rules and guidelines for their children, and this is their right. They may believe that it is important for their children to be exposed to these certain materials early on in life so that they can learn right from wrong from the very start. It is possible that they even might not care. Whatever the cause may be, they have the right to expose their children to anything they see appropriate. For example, a well - known author has been challenged throughout her entire career. Many of her books include the topic of menstruation, which many parents found inappropriate for their grade - school children to read. Therefore, those parents brought the books to the attention of the school board, who quickly removed the books from its library shelves. Many parents, librarians, and teachers were upset by this and argued that the topic was not at all harmful. In fourth grade, girls are required to watch a video on the topic of puberty and in fifth grade many girls begin to go through these changes themselves. So how is it inappropriate for them to read fictional books that include the topic? Many parents believe it is not and even encouraged their children to read the books, but the other parents who found it offensive ruined these parents' children's right to read. Therefore, in the long - run, censorship is wrong. It restricts the rights of the audience and of the writer, which prevents growing experiences for both. If everyone was to ban one book they found offensive, the world would be without any books and become quite dull. No one would be able to read and no one would be able to express themselves freely.

All of the materials in a library should have to be checked out of the library before anyone can take them out of the library. The librarian should make sure that anything that goes out of the library should have to be checked out before a student can take the materials out of the library. The topics that are going to be talked about are: why materials have to be checked out of the library, what happens if you do not check out the materials, and what happens if you lose the materials that you check out of the library. Materials that the library has are for everyone to check out if they want to. So, then the librarian will be able to tell a student if they want a book, music, movie, magazine, etc., whether the material is in or is checked out of the library. Then, the student will be able to check out the material or can ask the librarian to hold the material when it comes back in for the student. Then, the whole school can be running smoothly since the librarian can keep track of the materials that are in the library. If you do not check out the materials that are in the library, nobody will be able to see where the materials are at. Which means, if you checked out materials out of the library, the librarian can track it down for you. So, if you do not check it out, the librarian will not be able to track down any of the material that is in the library. So, then the librarian can not tell a student where the materials are at and then the materials are out of the library and no one can check it out. Then, the librarian has to wait till the person that took the materials out of the library brings the materials back to the library so that it will be able to be checked out by the person that wanted it when it was out of the library. If you check something out of the library and you lose it, you will have to pay for it. When you lose something from the library, that means that no one will be able to check it out until it either gets returned or you have to pay the librarian the money for a new one. Then the next person that wanted it will have to wait even longer to get the materials because you lost the library's copy of the materials that you checked out. Then the librarian will have to make sure that the next person that wanted the materials will be able to get it whenever it came back in the library. Then, the person that lost the material should not be able to check anything out of the library anymore. They can only sit in the library to read the materials that they either want to read or have to read for a project for a grade for one of their classes. Also, if you do not check the materials out of the library, and you lose it, then the librarian will not be able to track down the materials for anyone that wants it so they can check it out. These are just some of the many reasons why you have to check out materials from the library. There are a lot more reasons you have to check out materials from the library. So, then the librarian will be able to keep up with all of the materials that are in the library, and any person can check out any material that they either want or need for a class and it does not have to stay in the library whenever you want it. This system ensures the proper management and availability of library resources for everyone.

Communities are home to many different types of people. Certain groups of people find some things offensive, while others consider them completely normal. These differences often lead to conflicts. The materials are there for a reason, and they should be accessible to those who want to engage with them. If someone finds a particular item offensive, they can simply choose not to use it. By keeping the materials on the shelves, libraries can ensure that all members of the community have the opportunity to explore and learn.

Censorship in libraries is a very controversial topic that has conflicting views. One side, in favor of censorship, firmly believes that some literary material contained within a library could be offensive to some individuals, and that it should be removed or censored. The other side, in favor of free speech, strongly believes that all literary material in a library should be kept, whether it is seen as offensive or not. Of these two sides of such a controversial issue, it is clearly evident that censorship should not be instilled within libraries, because of the right to free speech, the true meanings and expressions in literary works must be upheld, and it would take away the opportunity to read such a work truly from an interested reader. The first reason why the censorship of literary materials within a library is an unjust endeavor is because of the right to free speech. This fundamental right belongs to all citizens of the United States, and shouldn't be taken away just because one person might think something is offensive. I have often observed that many people will often attempt to steal this right from others, and this instillation of censorship will do just that to the authors. This is the first reason why the censorship of literary materials within a library is an unjust endeavor. The next reason why the censorship of literary materials within a library is an unjust endeavor is because this censorship would dull down the true meanings and expressive themes that literary works are meant to express. An example of a story that would suffer from censorship is the famous 'The Catcher of the Rye.' Such a novel, though containing offensive language at times, would not read the same if such language was omitted and removed. Instead, J.D. Salinger's expressions within the story would be dulled down immensely and be nearly silenced. This is the next reason why the censorship of literary materials within a library is an unjust endeavor. The last reason why the censorship of literary materials within a library is an unjust endeavor is because it removes the availability of the book from an interested reader. Many times I have seen people blatantly throw a tantrum over an offensive literary work. I have been offended by things that I have read before, and instead of demanding its removal and crying for a less offensive substitute, I simply either stopped reading the work or read through it anyways. A person must know that the use of offensive language within literary works rarely is intended to attack the reader, but rather to strongly get a point across. If a person finds the material too offensive to read, then they should simply stop and find a more suitable work. By remaining calm and passive about these things, it keeps the literary work on the shelves in its true form for other people who wish to read it. This is the last reason why the censorship of literary materials within a library is an unjust endeavor. It is clearly evident that the removal or censorship of literary works in a library is a bad idea as a whole. The decision to censor literary works would be bad because it would strip the author's right to free speech, it would dull down the author's true meanings and expressions, and it would remove the opportunity to read such a work from an interested person. The removal or censorship of literary works would be a terrible decision that all would regret in the years to come. This is why the censorship of literary materials in libraries should be firmly opposed.

They need to try and limit everything that is offensive, to try to stop anybody from getting harmed. By being more vigilant, libraries can create a safe and inclusive environment for all their patrons.

Should there be censorship in libraries? Many individuals will answer this question in diverse ways. I firmly feel there should be absolutely no censorship in libraries. Allowing censorship in libraries is a blatant intrusion of our rights. It blatantly contradicts the fundamental freedom of the press. If someone desires for their opinion to be read, they should inherently have that right. I also strongly feel that censorship in libraries goes against the freedom of speech. After all, what is writing, but written speech? If someone wants to say something, they should be able to express it freely. If a mute person wants to convey a point, they should be able to do so by writing. What some people @MONTH1 consider offensive, others @MONTH1 not. If someone finds it offensive, they should simply choose not to read it. In conclusion, libraries should remain a place of free access to all forms of knowledge and expression, without the constraints of censorship.

'And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us'. This quote truly sums it all up. This book contained many vulgar words and even a racial slur, but I was mature enough to handle them. Just the other year, the librarian, whom I stay in regular contact with, asked me if she should take the book off the shelf. I told her no, with my reason being that I found it to be a very captivating book! I myself as a kid have looked through the dictionary looking for 'bad words'. Does that make it justifiable to remove? Even the books we read in school today have 'bad words' in them. When I was a freshman in high school, my @CAPS1 teacher talked about how the school board tried to get rid of 'To @CAPS2 A @CAPS3', because it had racial slurs and much racism involved. She was very against getting rid of the book because she found the novel to be a very engaging read for her and her students. Books just can't be taken out of the hands of high schoolers because some overly - strict adults think it is offensive, when in reality, they teach great morals and lessons for the youth. If you take a look at politics, you can see that not everybody has the same opinion, and some can be very vocal about theirs. The same idea applies to any topic in the world today. Somebody thinks one way, and someone else thinks the complete opposite. This is the problem with taking books off the shelves. One person thinks it is a very offensive book, and the other thinks it is a very beneficial book. My personal opinion is that a book is a book, and people are going to interpret them differently. So, if one book can get taken off the shelves, then this will just start a chain reaction until every book is gone. There is no point! If someone shouldn't read that book, then they simply shouldn't be allowed to. In conclusion, we should preserve the diversity of books in libraries and not let over - sensitivity lead to the loss of valuable literary works.

Have you ever walked into a library and spotted a book that you wouldn't want your child or any young one to pick up and read? There are several books in the library that are suitable for young children to read. I don't believe that a certain book should be removed from the library just because it is offensive to some or not suitable for children. However, there are a few things that can be done to keep those books away from your kids or any child. The possible things that could be done are: move those books to a higher shelf, designate a certain area for those books, or put an age limit on those books. The first way that you could keep an offensive book out of your child's, or any other child's hands is to move those books to a higher shelf. Doing this will effectively keep those books out of your child's sight and reach. That will prevent them from getting their hands on those books and reading them. The next possibility to keep offensive books out of your child's or any child's hands is to designate a specific area for those books in the library. Doing this will create a 'barrier', so that you could tell your child to stay out of that area and keep a close watch on them to make sure they don't go in that area. You would also know exactly where those books are, so you could ensure they don't venture to that area. The final possibility to keep offensive books out of your child's or any other child's hands is to put an age limit on those books to keep the children from being able to check - out those books to read them. This would require the children to be a certain age before they can check them out, thus preventing them from reading those books. These are a few possible solutions that could be used to keep offensive books out of children's hands and prevent them from reading those offensive books that you wouldn't want them to get a hold of and read. In conclusion, these measures offer a practical way to balance access to all books in the library while protecting children from inappropriate content.

Many people hold different views on censorship. Some people believe there are movies, books, newspapers, etc. that contain subject matter that is not appropriate for some viewers, and that the creators should limit their writing on certain things or avoid them altogether. Other people believe that people have the right to say what they want, when they want, on a topic they believe to be true or not true, or very important to them, which is also known as freedom of speech. Also, people recognize that yes, there are some things written out there that perhaps should not have been written, but they have no control over it, and to some people, it @MONTH1 be appropriate. I do believe there are stories written that are not appropriate. But I know that even though I find the subject to not be appropriate or of any use to me, another person will. I know that every person out there is different and has their own beliefs on different things. If people had the power to control what books, magazines, newspapers, and movies were in libraries, then @PERSON1 was right, 'We would have no books left on the shelf for any of us'. Certain books, newspapers, movies, and magazines could be beneficial to certain people and be of interest to them, no matter what the subject is or how inappropriate it @MONTH1 be, as long as they are of the right age. If the story is simply about drugs, sex, alcohol, and violence with really no redeeming value, then yes, I do believe it should be taken off the shelf. You never know who could get their hands on that movie, book, or article. It could be a little kid, and we don't want to expose them to such content. People have many different beliefs, and I do believe we should not take anything off the shelf that could be of use to anyone. But I also do believe there is a certain limit. In conclusion, finding the right balance between freedom of expression and protecting the public, especially children, from inappropriate content is crucial.

@CAPS1 happened to using books and films as simple entertainment? Why are we now so cautious about @CAPS1 our children pick off the shelf? Society today has transformed the way we once regarded our sources of entertainment. Books are now viewed with suspicion, and once - harmless movies and magazines are full of material that no one should be reading or watching. Music used to be a beautiful form of art, but now when you turn on your radio, @CAPS1 do you hear? Mindless jumbles of words linked together with curses and other trash. Should libraries use caution when renting something to someone who shouldn't be using that material for harmless entertainment? There once was a young girl, fourteen or fifteen, who adored reading and listening to music. She was bright but shy, and she used books as her companions. Each day she walked to the library for a new story to immerse herself in. One day she came across a book on the top shelf of the fiction section. The book looked well - used, for its spine was badly split and several of the pages were nearly falling out. She reached for the book, intrigued, and flipped through the pages. Her innocent and naive mind was exposed to a world she didn't know. After reading the book, she was filled with a sense of guilt. It wasn't a good book, but one that was laced with a harmful message. This young girl, once pure and simple, now knew things no one at that age should know. So, why wasn't there a warning of some sort? The difference between writing something offensive and being offensive is that the writer usually doesn't intend to be hurtful or rude. The author most likely intended for the piece of literature to be enjoyed with a light - hearted attitude. However, the comparison between writing something offensive and being offensive is quite different. When you read something in a book or magazine that disturbs you, put it down or throw it away. No one is forcing you to read the material. Yet, the real question is: @CAPS1 about our children? How do we keep them safe from offensive literature? And @CAPS1 about music? Or movies? Remember the old black and white films? How, no matter @CAPS1 the plot or storyline is, the two leading roles somehow fall in love in the end? The ending title fills the screen just before the two actors share a kiss and then the screen goes black. Mind, there are still movies with happy endings and a positive message. @CAPS1 about the other films? Some of the biggest blockbusters are those which have either violence, some form of racism, and/or sexual content. Personally, going to the movies to see a new action movie that looks thrilling and entertaining should be a fun experience, but where does the fun stop? After the guy in the first scene has just been brutally murdered? Or after the two lovers share a private moment that should be kept that way? And @CAPS1 happens when this movie is released and checked out from the library by a young boy who just wants a fun sleepover with his friends? How do we keep these sorts of material away from them? Libraries should exercise major caution when printing labels to place on their books, movies, magazines, etc. Librarians should make sure that the book a child hands to them is safe to read for that age level. Also, they should check the ratings on movies or make them unavailable to certain age groups. Parents should also be cautious when letting their child go to the movies with friends. Make sure they see something fun, but with a positive message. Should libraries take certain material off their shelves? I don't think so. However, be careful @CAPS1 you read or watch, for it might not meet your expectations. Use the internet as a source to find reviews on books and magazines to see how well it was rated and then decide whether it is an interesting read or an amazing film. Have fun, but be vigilant. In conclusion, while we should not overly restrict access to media, we must take steps to protect the vulnerable, especially children, from inappropriate content.

Books, magazines, and music should be removed if they have something offensive to a person or a child. Such media can cause children or adults to have a vivid imagination and might make them think that inappropriate behavior is acceptable. All these things that are not for proper use should be disposed of where no children or adults can access them. I believe that this kind of content can harm people as they grow up or make adults think it's the right way to act. Books and music should be removed if they are not used for something beneficial. Books and magazines that have no useful material and are used for pornography or other inappropriate content should be taken off the shelves. Kids and adults have active imaginations, which could sometimes lead them to hurt others, including family members. I do not believe that books, music, movies, or magazines should be removed from library shelves if they are found offensive. First, you have to carefully consider what is offensive to most people, and who should be the ones to determine if it should be censored or not. People should be able to decide for themselves if they can or cannot get an item off of a shelf, because they might not even consider it offensive. If you are a parent, you have the right to not let your children watch or read certain materials, but you can't get it taken off the shelf because then it prohibits other people from being able to get that same material that they think is acceptable. Things that are offensive range from cussing all the way to extreme violence. Some people may not mind that there are a couple of bad words or a little violence, but others will find it very offensive. In my personal experience, I tend not to think that a little cussing is offensive, but I do know some people who balk even hearing one minor cuss word. Many movies nowadays are made up of content that is mildly offensive, but only if you take it seriously. The movies make fun of things that people might find offensive, which probably offends those people even more, but they do not have to watch it if they don't want that movie! It just depends on the person and what they have grown up around, or what they think is right or wrong. It is either your own responsibility or a parent's responsibility to determine whether the content of a book or movie is appropriate. Many times parents use the argument that children are too young to make the judgement on a book or movie, and that is very true. So most children movies and books are appropriate, and do not include content that children are not quite ready to handle. If you are older, then you can probably make the decision to read or watch something because it is more appropriate for your age. Many times you have already been exposed to the ideas prevalent in books and movies because those things are already in your life. It comes down to who the movie is for and what content you think is appropriate for their age. The idea about taking these books off the shelves would be disastrous. This book has many valuable ideas and lessons, and is considered a great piece of literature. These parents wanted the book to be banned from all schools and all libraries all over the country, and that would be infringing on other people's rights of freedom of speech. The parents can say what they want about the book and not let their own child read it, but they cannot stop that opportunity for everyone else who wants to read the book. Taking it off the shelves would be taking off those ideas as well. Literature and every other movie and type of literature is what shapes a culture. There have been so many movements over time, many started with literature and it affected the culture and the people. Censorship would just take away a part of our culture, which would be devastating. You should look at your own life, and think about what you find offensive. Then step into someone else's shoes that does not think it is offensive, and see if it is worth it to take it all away from everyone. Almost everything could be considered offensive to at least one person, but it is your own responsibility to decide whether it is appropriate for you or your child. The shelves should stay full of books, movies, music, and magazines. It is our way of expressing freedom of speech, and that is an integral part of our country and our culture.

Censorship in libraries is good in some ways. People who like to read books should have a wide variety of books. People should have a right to listen, read, and watch whatever they want. It is people's own choice to decide what they read, watch, or listen to. Sooner or later, they will find out about these problems. If you want to help your kids, keep them off the streets because reading about these issues in a book is a lot better than them experiencing them in the real world. You have to prepare them for the problems ahead. If you don't, they might get hurt a lot worse than by just reading a few little offensive words in a book, magazine, or movie. In conclusion, removing books from library shelves due to offensive content is not a practical solution as it won't protect children from the real - world problems they will eventually face. In the book Fahrenheit 451, all books get burned regardless of what they contain, and the people are constantly sad and depressed about everything. Books are an important part of our lives. In conclusion, a balanced approach to censorship is needed to preserve the richness of our cultural and informational resources.

What is censorship? Many would say it's a book without cuss words or it's a movie without blatant racism. For me, I think censorship is covering up the truth. Taking books off a shelf at libraries because someone thinks they are offensive? I don't think that is right. That's just the opinion of one person, and I'm sure other people won't share the same view. Dear Newspaper, I would like to start off by saying that books, music, movies, magazines, etc. are great resources for kids in libraries. It's wonderful that kids have a place to go during their free time when they have nothing else to do or when they need a quiet place to read. Some people believe that certain materials, such as books, movies, magazines, etc., should be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. However, I do not believe they should be removed. People are mature enough to be able to handle offensive material. Instead of removing the offensive material, there should just be a warning to let readers know that what they are checking out is considered offensive. These days, people are mature enough to read offensive material. We see many types of offensive material every day. For example, when we watch the news, we often see numerous offensive pictures or videos. There are also many news stories that many people consider offensive. When a person checks out an offensive book, they are doing so because they want to. Libraries should not revoke a reader's right to read what he/she wants. Before a person checks out a book or movie, they should look into it to make sure they are okay with what they are getting. This can prevent many problems. For instance, say a young reader sees a book that they think looks interesting. If they don't read into it a little bit and just take it home, they may later find that it contains offensive material. However, if they read a little bit about it before they check it out, they will find out it contains offensive material, and can then make the decision on whether or not they still want to read it. There are many ways libraries can prevent children or other people not mature enough to view the offensive material from seeing it. They can put a warning label on the book or movie to inform people that that particular item is considered offensive. Libraries could even put an age limit on checking out offensive material. Either of these ideas could be an effective way to ensure that only mature people are checking out anything that is considered to be offensive. Libraries should not have to remove books, music, movies, magazines, etc. that contain offensive material from the shelves. If a person wants to check out a book that is offensive, they should be allowed to check it out and read it. Also, people should be intelligent enough to look into whatever item they are checking out beforehand so they can be aware of the offensive material. However, to make things even easier, libraries could just put a warning label on offensive material to prevent some people from reading it. In conclusion, respecting people's ability to make their own choices and using proper warnings is a better approach than removing offensive materials from library shelves.

Censorship to most people means much more than the average three - syllable word. It means giving up the right to say and think however you want. To most, this idea is not a good one. When one is censored, they are essentially giving up the right of freedom of speech. In this essay I will discuss three cons of censorship in libraries. One reason censorship should not be allowed in libraries is the lack of freedom of speech. Decades ago when it was set into place that anyone was allowed to practice their right to speak freely, the idea of censorship was not in the plan. As Americans, it is our right to speak and write however we want without repercussions, however offensive or non - offensive the material may be. As Americans, all should realize that everyone is different and not everyone will agree with one another. Does that mean that just because one person finds something offensive, then an item should be taken off shelves? Absolutely not. Freedom of speech is our birth right and we should be allowed to say or write anything without being censored. '...But if I have the right to remove that book from the shelf-- that work I abhor--then you also have exactly the same right and so does everyone else. And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' Katherine Paterson. Author Katherine Paterson simply states that if she has the right to take any book off the shelf that she doesn't like, then everyone else also has that same right. As previously stated in the paragraph above, it makes no sense to rid a book just because one person finds it offensive. If that was the case, I could find ten books in our library that I find offensive, and the next person could find fifteen books that are offensive and so on. Just as Katherine states, 'And then we have no books left on the shelves for any of us.' And the last con of censorship in libraries is the lack of perspective and learning a book brings. As an avid book reader, I couldn't even begin to describe all of the vocabulary words and new things I learn from reading one book. Just recently I read the book To Kill a Mockingbird. As I was reading, I began to have a deep hatred of the main character. Later I found that the book was incredibly offensive. However, from reading it, the book provided much insight into the 1930s' life that I knew nothing about. It gave me a great deal of information that to this day, I use. The book made me reflect on myself and how eighty plus years changes people, Americans more specifically. In conclusion, censorship in libraries undermines our freedom of speech, depletes the library's collection, and limits our learning and perspective, so it should not be implemented.

It seems today we attempt to censor everything, but are we going too far? Could it be that we have crossed the line and are no longer protecting the children, but are instead holding back our society as a whole? In my opinion, censorship of literature has crossed the line. A library is, essentially, an incredibly valuable resource to each generation. In some cases, it still is, but when books are being withheld due to the fact that it might offend someone, we are holding people back from the knowledge they could gain from the work of literature itself. We attempt to placate everyone in today's society, therefore we censor several things that are not politically correct. If future generations are unable to learn what we have through these writings, then they will lack the insight we had gained. Another reason is, to be perfectly honest, history and society have not - and very well might never truly be - politically correct. People take umbrage to certain words, and consequently, some libraries will remove the book featuring said words from their shelves. After this is done, what have we really accomplished? Have we made the world a better place by attempting to hide a part of history? That is debatable, but by the same token, in school, we must learn about the Holocaust despite the fact that it upsets many people. We must learn about this because it was an important part in history that needs to be remembered in hopes that nothing so terrible as that will ever happen again. So, if we learn about an entire subject which happened in another country but affected the entire world, should we not learn about our own faults in history? The times we have oppressed people, the terms we used so commonly we attempt to hide now. Has it really helped us? No, for until people recognize a problem and furthermore are reminded of how wrong it was, they will not understand it. Napoleon once said that history is a story written by the victor, but is victory so sweet after our history has been rewritten? If everything that offends people is censored or taken away, we will have nothing left. For if one person is allowed to say what is and isn't acceptable, then others will partake in this as well. It would become a new fad, and people would find a problem with just about anything. So, essentially, by censoring works in libraries, we are holding back the future generations from all that they could be. We are forcing them to be ignorant of society's problems. In the end, we must ask ourselves, was it really worth it? I remind you, a library is an invaluable resource that should preserve the unvarnished truth of history for the betterment of future generations.

So, in reality, some things should be kept, and others taken away. People spend a significant amount of time in the library for many different reasons, and that will never change. Movies are a good source of entertainment and learning, and that won't change either. So, I guess I'm half - and - half on keeping or getting rid of offensive materials. We need to make careful decisions based on the age and needs of the users to ensure a beneficial library environment.

Another reason that no books should be removed is simply because everyone has unique preferences. In the world, there are books that certain people would enjoy more than others. Every person should have that right. If people start removing materials that are offensive to them, then nothing on the shelves would remain and not one person would have the right to have access to the materials they desire.  In this world, diversity exists everywhere. People have and always will want, need, and desire different things. Works of literature are just one of them. If people begin to eliminate offensive materials based on everyone's frustration or displeasures, then no books will remain on the public shelves. Therefore, materials such as books, music, movies, and magazines should never be removed from public places. These things are necessities to the world as they enrich our lives and broaden our perspectives.

Do citizens have the right to remove books, magazines, and other materials from library shelves simply because they personally disagree with the content? The question of library censorship doesn't have a clear - cut answer. Some individuals firmly believe it's within their rights to eliminate books, music, and movies that they consider 'offensive'. On the other hand, there are those who argue that library censorship is wrong and that people should have unrestricted access to any material they desire. Censorship essentially acts as a barrier, preventing those eager to learn about different worlds from accessing knowledge.  In today's society, there are virtually no limits to human creativity. The human imagination can craft beautiful literary masterpieces and music, but it can also generate content that isn't suitable for all age groups. Library censorship is often seen as a way to shield young and inquisitive minds from this 'unsuitable' material. However, what might be inappropriate for children could be perfectly acceptable for a mature adult. Censorship is purely a matter of personal opinion.  For example, if a person strongly believes that a higher power created the world in seven days, they might find a book or movie supporting the theory of evolution offensive. Similarly, if a parent doesn't want their child exposed to a certain type of media, they'd prefer that it not be visible in the children's section of the library. But it's unfair to others if all related content is removed just because one person has an issue with it. If someone doesn't want to access certain 'offensive' subjects, they can simply avoid them. It's not their right to deny others the opportunity to educate themselves on those matters.  Writing is a powerful form of self - expression. It allows individuals to convey their feelings, thoughts, and share knowledge about the past. But if written works aren't shared, how can people form their own opinions when they're not exposed to diverse viewpoints? It's unjust to prevent someone from learning about a particular subject just because a few others oppose the content. If books and movies that one person finds unacceptable were removed, then everyone else could claim the right to have their disliked material removed as well. Eventually, there would be nothing left in the library because everyone is offended by something.  One of the great things about being a citizen in our society is the freedom of speech. By living here, we have the right to read and learn about whatever we choose. Censorship restricts the learning opportunities of those who are eager to expand their knowledge.  Parents are often the most vocal advocates of library censorship. Their concern about protecting their children from explicit or graphic material is understandable. But just because a parent doesn't want their child to see a movie about a controversial topic doesn't mean they have the right to stop others from viewing it. Children need to be exposed to different ideas at some point to develop open - mindedness and acceptance. Libraries are a valuable source for young people to learn about different religions, beliefs, and customs. It shouldn't be up to parents to decide what goes on the library shelves. If they don't want their children to access certain subjects, they can keep them away from the library.  In conclusion, library censorship is a subjective matter. Citizens have the right to read, listen to, or watch whatever material they want. While it's reasonable for parents to shield their children, it's unacceptable for them to prevent the entire community from learning. The freedom to express oneself through literature is meaningless if that literature can't be shared. As Katherine Paterson once said, '... And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us,' highlighting the potential consequence of excessive censorship.

What if someone found your favorite book offensive? Inappropriate materials do need to be kept from the young minds of children. On the other hand, you cannot shield people from things they should know or already know. Everyone has different things that they think are offensive. So one person might think a book is so bad it should be recalled from the shelves, but another person @MONTH1 sees no problem with it. Children need to be protected from materials that @MONTH1 could hurt them in some way. Children do what they see and hear, so they are liable to try and copy harmful things they read. Bad influences can even come from magazines with famous celebrities being caught breaking the law or doing bad things. Young minds see that as 'cool' and @MONTH1 might try to follow that example. However, children and young people see and hear a lot worse things at home, on television, and even at school than in some books. Children need to be protected, but you can't baby - proof life. They will be introduced to plenty of bad influences in their lifetime. It should be the parent's job to teach their kids to say no and stay away from bad things. Kids can learn so much worse things from just sitting at home than from something at the library. Libraries are places for public use, and the public covers a wide amount of different kinds of people. Someone will always find something bothersome with something or another. People have different views, beliefs, and religions, and books on these might be offensive to some but a part of the lifestyle of another. Like the quote by Katherine Paterson said, if we take off the shelves every book or material that someone finds offensive, there will be no books in the libraries at all. Yes, there are books that are not always very presentable to a certain group of people, but they should have a right to be read if there is someone who wants to read them. It is not the library's job to be prejudice against certain books just because someone doesn't agree with it. Books should be as diverse as the people who are reading them. Also, children are protected from books if they have learned morals that allow them to make mature choices. By promoting a balance between protection and access to diverse materials, we can ensure that libraries remain valuable resources for everyone.

I believe that any book or movie that is in the library is in the library for a good reason. The world is filled with a wide array of things that can either hurt and make a person feel bad about themselves, or make them feel like they're on top of the world. Yes, there are indeed things that children can see and things that they are not supposed to see. Those inappropriate things are most likely not exposed to the students until they reach a mature and responsible age. Life is full of diverse experiences, and as children grow up, they are going to be taught and shown things that parents might find uncomfortable. Such as: Books that show people with disorders, books about romance, movies with cussing and sex scenes, and violence. Some parents don't even want their children to see a simple kiss on the cheek, which I find really strange because things like that are bound to happen in life. On the other hand, if your child is doing things that they shouldn't be doing, then okay, take action. I also agree that children shouldn't be taught about sex or shown what females and boys have on their bodies. Their minds shouldn't even be set on that. Books, movies, and TV shows shouldn't be removed because they show what life is about and what is going to happen when you get older. In conclusion, we should trust the library's judgment in curating its collection and let children gradually learn about the real world at an appropriate pace.

Debates are a main part of our society today. Everyone has an opinion on how things should be in the world, and no one is necessarily right. Books that show how other cultures behave, which to the people being described in the book might seem offensive, are important because we as people need to absorb as much as we can about other cultures. Our businesses are operating in other countries, many people living in the United States speak multiple languages, and people have the right to read things that might in fact be offensive to a race of people. Businesses thrive in other countries. A significant portion of our country's income comes from our factories and companies in foreign lands. China is a place where much business happens for the United States. If we, as Americans, can't learn about the Chinese culture, how can we learn their business methods and way of life? To the Chinese, these books might be offensive, but to us they are learning tools describing Chinese culture. Being bilingual is a trend that millions of people adhere to. High schools require that we learn some foreign language, even if it is only the basics. The schools do this so that we can go to other countries in the workforce. Learning about their language and habits comes from books. The Mexican population might not like the way we depict them in our stories, but this is necessary to learn about them. In the United States, there are all kinds of freedoms that we as Americans use freely. Freedom of speech says that we can say whatever we want when we live in the United States. Books are not excluded from this rule. I'm sure that other countries have offensive books about us. It's a common theme around the globe. Businesses thrive in foreign countries, so we must be able to read some books about them, even if they seem offensive. Learning new things is something that every school teaches and there should be no limit to what we can learn. If a book has vulgar language and sexual scenes, it should be taken out of the children's section of the library, not banned completely. This is the same case with other populations of people. They cannot take offense to what we have to say, because worse has been said about them than what we can possibly put in a book. Learning is a necessary tool in our society and nothing should be restricted. In conclusion, we should embrace the opportunity to learn from diverse cultures through books, even if they contain potentially offensive content.

Books are very important to our society. They hold a special place in our hearts, and contain much of our world's knowledge. Everyone has their own opinion about what should or should not be placed in books. I definitely agree that little children should not purchase a book that has explicit content in it that they should not read. However, some people, myself included, have checked out or bought books and then realized what exactly was portrayed in those books. I do not believe that anything that contains certain contents should be removed from the shelves. I can think of many books that could be taken offensively that are still on many school library and public library shelves. Any books about the Holocaust and even the African American civil rights movement, such as 'To Kill a Mockingbird' can be taken in the wrong context. These books do contain language that is not appropriate for children. But we do still see them on our shelves. Why? Because those books, and many others, are very important to us. Books should stay on their shelves because, as Katherine Paterson cleverly put it, '... And then we have no books left on the shelf for any of us.' This means that if everyone took out books that they felt were personally offensive then there would be no books. Books are vital to learning things. We put all of our knowledge into them, even hundreds, if not thousands, of years ago. When the libraries in Alexandria were burned and/or destroyed, we thought our knowledge was gone forever. Thank goodness for the back - up system that no one had known about out in the desert. I myself have read the Bible. I believe it whole - heartedly, but I do know of people who do not believe in God and have taken some things that are said in the Bible to be taken personally. I believe that the Bible is the most important book in the world. Without the Bible no one would know of the wonderful things that our God above has done for us, and what he is doing for us now. However, some people can take what the Bible says to be offensive in regards to homosexuals and divorces. But would we allow the gays or divorced men and women to take the Bible off of the shelves? Of course not! If we would not allow them to take off that ever so important book, then why should we allow to have other books to be removed? Books are so very important to us and our world. They hold our world's knowledge, and they also hold our hearts. Just think about what our world, our knowledge, our society would be like if we did not have these precious things. Can you imagine it? I cannot. Books are one of the most important things that we have in our world. Just because someone finds something offensive in a written work does not mean that everyone else will, too. Books, if they are offensive to anyone, should be kept on our shelves for our future generations to come so they can learn and grow on our knowledge of our past. In conclusion, we should preserve the diversity of books in our libraries for the sake of knowledge and future learning.

In today's world, children are exposed to a lot more inappropriate things than in recent times. They hear things from older siblings, see uncensored programs on television, hear words in music, and even learn things from books. An issue at hand is whether or not libraries should or should not dispose of inappropriate books, movies, music, and magazines. Children can read whatever they like if their parents give permission, but in today's society some parents do not take the time to care, being consumed in their work. One way society can take care of this problem is setting age limits on books. There have been times when my mother will not allow me to read a book because it dealt with issues that I was not ready to learn about. Although I am lucky that my mother cares about what I read, some parents are not. This is why an age limit would be helpful in keeping our youth modest. The librarians, or a national book association, could decide if the content of a book is appropriate for a certain age. This would take care of children reading about bawdy issues that they should not know about. Also, Christian books should be more readily available. These types of books teach good morals and how to live a good and full life. In schools across the country, many Christian authors are not in the public school libraries. By putting these types of books into the libraries, students would be more aware of them and would most likely have an interest in them, learning from them. Another issue libraries have is music and movies. It is nice to be able to go to the library and check out a CD or even a movie. But, some of these have terrible language and scenes not appropriate for children. What can the general public do about this? Well, demand that all music and videos with content not generalized for children be removed from the libraries. This would keep children from seeing and hearing actions they should not copy. There are ratings on movies for a reason, so why not use them. Anything above PG - 13 should be a definite no in libraries. If the movie has content that any child under thirteen should not see, then the movie should be out. Magazines also offer a source of learning. Some are very educational, and give the students ideas to go and come up with a new invention or a way to help others. But, some have content that are not suited for children. Thus, like the books, the magazines should also have ratings. The magazine Playboy, for example, has articles that are too bawdy for students to read. Magazines like this should be put in an adult section where students cannot look at them. Magazines also offer pictures that, in recent times, would have been illegal to put out. But, in today's standards, they are fine to put in magazines. These magazines should not even be allowed in the libraries across our nation. America's standards on what is okay to read, look at, watch, and listen to have changed drastically. Children are learning things they should not know about, until an older age, at a very young age. Society needs to put strict restrictions on what is right and what is not for children. I personally believe that there should be very strict restrictions on what children are allowed to watch, read, and listen to. My parents were very strict about this and, in the end, I feel this has benefitted my learning process. Also, I feel the libraries should rid of books that, in olden times, would have been a shame to read. Parents today are not as in sync with what their children do as they were in recent years. So, society needs to put a strict rule on what libraries carry and what they do not. In conclusion, by implementing strict content regulations in libraries, we can better protect children from inappropriate materials and promote a healthier learning environment.

This is going to be an essay about if people finding something offensive in a library or in music that it should be censored. It is also about if you think it should be taken off the shelves because some people find it offensive. The way I look at it, or my own opinion, is that they should censor most things from libraries and music, but not get rid of it because one person finds it offensive. If you think about it, those uncensored materials like books that some people find offensive might be a perfect fit for someone else who can relate to them as they were growing up. On the other hand, they should be more careful about it so when younger kids listen to the radio or are reading a book they don't get the wrong ideas. We should censor things but only to an extent and not go overboard with it. In the long run, it might help with creating a more clean and safe population because we are censoring things so that people don't hear bad things and only hear the good in life. You never know, you could make a big difference by doing that. The reason I wouldn't go out and censor everything is because you can't stop everyone from doing it. You can always give it a try but that's one of the main reasons why I wouldn't try and get rid of it just because a certain person might find it offensive. I can understand if you took it off the shelf because someone found it offensive, but only move it to a place where no one will find it offensive. I'm not saying it's wrong to do that, but I think it could and probably would make a lot of people angry. But hey, what can I say? What has the government done that we don't like or can't do anything about it? And that's all I have to say about that. In conclusion, a balanced approach to censorship that respects different perspectives while protecting the young is the most reasonable way forward.

Books, movies, magazines, music, etc., make up a substantial part of our entertainment system in our daily lives today. Whether it is informational or purely for entertainment, numerous forms of entertainment can be found in your local library today. In contrast, in the past, most libraries primarily contained only books. However, our entertainment today is significantly different from what it was back then and will also be quite different from what it will be in the future. In today's society, books, magazines, music, movies, and so on can be readily found in your local library, and they contain a wide variety of materials. Some materials could be informational about our solar system or the intricate details of the human body. Other materials could be thrilling fiction stories filled with action, horror, or heart - warming love. Some materials could also be filled with true, life - changing, and inspiring stories. Whichever it may be, these types of things may come off as offensive to some people more than others and may not be appropriate for younger ages. Certain books, movies, magazines, music, etc., containing offensive, inappropriate, or rude material shouldn't be banned from libraries just because those younger than adults should not read them, or because those who dislike the material believe that it does not belong in the library. Generally, most libraries are quite large and are well - organized into various sections throughout the building. One area might be dedicated to fiction books and another for non - fiction books. Another area could be for children's books, and yet another for magazines, movies, music, etc., all based on different types and genres. Simply do this for those materials that should only be read by adults and not for children or teens. Take the books that may contain offensive material, or may be inappropriate for those younger than adults and place them in their own divided section in the library. When a book from that section is being checked out, merely ask for an ID from the person checking that book out to make sure that they are of age. This can also apply to movies, magazines, music, and so on that are placed in that section. Some materials found in libraries that may be offensive to one person may not be offensive to others. Taking those offensive materials out of the library won't benefit everyone and may disappoint some of the people who don't find that material offensive. Placing these certain materials in their own section is the best way to go to benefit everyone. As you can see, just because one person may find certain material in magazines, books, music, movies, etc., offensive, rude, or inappropriate, doesn't mean that everyone else does. It also doesn't mean you should completely take out and get rid of all the materials that are found to contain offensive or inappropriate material. Dividing those specific materials into their own section, and regulating who can check them out is really the best way to go. It benefits everyone at best so that those who want to read that material can still go to their library and check out that book, magazine, and so on, and those who wish to not have anything to do with that certain material don't have to worry about finding material that is offensive or inappropriate, because they will be in their own divided section.

It is a library, so it should just offer things that would increase intelligence, not decrease it. The censorship is pointless. You should do what you want at your own risk. Things in movies, books, magazines are part of the world. Why try to block out negative things when they are all around you? If someone finds something offensive, then let it be. There are many offensive things in today's society. You pick up what you want to read and make the choice on your own. If you are capable of reading it or if it is the right decision, check it out. You enter the library at your own risk and choose what criteria or selection you are going to choose. The library is full of different opinions and a lot of different likes and dislikes. If you should not be looking at something, then it is your opinion to take what you want out of it. Everyone enjoys different things like movies, books, magazines, and music. If the library had a censorship, they would lose a lot of materials all due to the opinions of people that did not care about others' opinions. Everyone enjoys different things and wants a wide variety of the things they like. The library is where you go when you need books, movies, and etc. Why close someone's opinion of a book selection? What if that is the only type of selection, or book they like to read? I believe that the censorship should not affect the library. The library should offer different sections for certain age groups. The books, magazines, and music at the library should all be at your own risk to checkout them. Everyone has different opinions at the library. The censorship would be a bad decision if they did go through with this decision. The library would not offer as many things and most likely less things would be getting checked out. Therefore, I do think that the censorship should not remove books on the shelves at libraries.

I personally think certain materials, such as books, music, movies, magazines, etc., should not have to be removed from the shelves if they are found offensive. First of all, how do we precisely define offensive? Is it something that discriminates against a certain group of people? Is it something that creates negative attention? Is it something we simply don't like? Anybody can walk into a library and find something they did not like, but that does not automatically mean it is offensive. The national geographic magazine often has pictures of naked people, and so does the Playboy magazine. So, which one would we have to put censorship on? The answer is we don't put one because this would start a big argument about which is offensive and which is not. It would cause a conflict between two different sides. It is only offensive when we make it offensive. We do not have to look at something we don't like. We all have a choice and we can choose not to pick up something we might think is offensive. The Muslims may not get along with the Jews, but if both were in a library together with both of their holy books on the shelves, they cannot say one's book is offensive to another because it does not agree with theirs. We sometimes forget we have the amendment that allows us to the freedom of speech and press. We may not like what one person publishes, but it doesn't make their work offensive because it might be for a certain group that likes it, which is not offensive to them. Everything in the library has a purpose, and if it does not fit our purpose, then there is no way it would be offensive to us. The library is a place for books, music, movies, magazines, etc. We come to the library to check out books for a research in order to learn. We also go to the library to read the newest book of a series. Putting a censorship on these things would not enable us to do these. We can't finish our research project because someone thought one book was offensive, or we can't listen to the new album Dr. Dre released because some people think the lyrics are too offensive. Putting a censorship would upset the general public more than not having a censorship because if everyone can check out what they want from the library, then everyone is content. In conclusion, censorship in libraries restricts our access to diverse materials and goes against the principles of freedom of speech and the purpose of a library as a place of knowledge and entertainment.

We all hope that one day our children will not pick up a book or a magazine they're not supposed to read. Children don't know any better. But why should we have to have movies, books, and etc. censored just because there are little children everywhere? If I had the right to keep the books and etc. on the shelf, I would. I think that we should be able to have books that are uncensored on the shelves. If everything was censored, we would really have nothing substantial to read or to watch. Having everything censored is just not fair to the world. Everyone should be able to watch whatever they want without it having to be censored. If people's favorite movies or music was censored, it probably wouldn't be as enjoyable to them anymore, and they'll most likely just stop watching or listening to it. I don't believe that they should have a censorship in libraries. Certain materials like CDs and songs do come off a little offensive sometimes, but that's just life. If you think it's offensive, then just don't listen to it. That doesn't mean that they have to take it off the shelf. Maybe other people like that kind of music or etc. That doesn't mean they have the right to just take it off because of that. If they did, that's just really unfair. Children nowadays see more and know more than what they are supposed to know. For example, cursing. If a child happens to see cursing in a magazine at the library and their parents get mad that it was in the magazine, the parent shouldn't really be mad and take that as offensive, and think that it's not supposed to be there. The library shouldn't have to censor things because of that incident. The children will hear it or see it again sooner or later. I would keep the right for the libraries to have things uncensored if I had the decision. These are some of the reasons why I think they shouldn't have to censor movies, music, etc. in the library. In conclusion, censorship in libraries limits our choices and goes against the idea of personal freedom and the diverse nature of the library as a source of various materials.

Libraries have a wide variety of material from books to movies. Most of this is intended for a general audience, and many people can read or watch whatever they want. Some of the literature and other material you may find in libraries, however, are not intended for certain people, such as young children. Censorship takes material that these certain people should not read away from everyone. Many people want censorship not just in libraries but in many aspects of life. Censorship is not bad per se, but it does restrict people, who would normally have access to a certain topic, to a general category. Not everyone likes to read the same thing as someone else. Apart from likes and dislikes, there is the problem of offensiveness. Everyone finds something offensive. Just because you find something that makes a bold statement does not mean that you should persecute someone who is interested in the subject matter. For the matter of protecting children against something they should not read yet, it is quite simple. Libraries often have dedicated children's sections where children can choose material appropriate for their age range. More often than not, I enjoy reading what I enjoy far more than something that is forced upon me. Censorship takes away from the enjoyment of reading. By not having censorship, everyone will be happy in the fact that they get to read what they like. This also allows a wide variety of books to reach a wide variety of people. In conclusion, censorship in libraries restricts the free flow of knowledge and entertainment. By maintaining an uncensored library with proper age - appropriate sections, we can ensure that everyone can access the materials they desire while still protecting the interests of younger patrons.

I do not think that materials, such as books, music, movies, and magazines should be removed from shelves if they are found offensive. I think this because people have different views and beliefs on certain types of things, whether it's related to religion, culture, and sexuality. Some people can be offended by it, but others might be informed and learn new facts that they didn't already know. People are not going to look at things the same way. Everyone has their own way of life and thinks differently. If one person feels the book was offensive to them, then they might want to take it off the shelves. One by one, people would find other materials offensive, and what does it leave us? No more books, music, movies, and magazines. Let's face it, everyone has different beliefs, values, and purposes. But taking materials off the shelves because they found it offensive is ridiculous to me. I say if they find it offensive, don't read the book again or the magazine again. If you feel offended over a movie, don't watch it again, and the same goes for music; don't listen to it again. It's as easy as that. Materials give us resources and we learn new things. If we didn't have materials like books, music, movies, and magazines, we wouldn't be as well - informed as we are. America is about being free and having the right to speak our minds. So putting materials off of shelves is not the answer. In conclusion, we should respect the diversity of opinions and keep these materials available for those who can benefit from them.

Yes, we should keep the books, music, movies, and magazines. The magazines and music might not be suitable for some of us, but most people use music to concentrate on doing work, and magazines help us in getting topics for class work. Why would someone take books or anything that helps us in life? So the person who wants to take books away should leave the books or anything else alone. So, to this, yes, we should keep the books, music, movies, and magazines on the shelves. We need to start fighting for what we want and how we want it. In the end, these materials are valuable resources that contribute to our learning and enjoyment, and we should safeguard their availability.

Different Than Everyone Else Why do people find small things offensive? My opinion is that everyone has their own idea of what can be offensive to them.
